GAME: Dominant Species
RANK: 49

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
This is a deep game with decisions resulting in some very subtle shifts which aren't immediately obvious. Very interesting therefore - at least for the first few plays. If it doesn't become obvious/boring then and holds it's promise then my rating will rise. Two things to watch for though. Analysis paralysis can be significant and so can downtime (particularly as it can be a little difficult/tedious to keep track of dominance in a region)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Waaaaay too long... If the game could be played in 1.5 hours or less it would be a 9 or a 10.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
A really good mix of war game and euro mechanisms with a very intriguing theme make for a great game. This game is one of the few games that makes area control enjoyable to me. The excellent rule set allows for a decently quick understanding of all of the actions (considering the game depth), and the player sheets give a perfect length description of the actions so you rarely have to flip through the rules to check something. The only thing that brings the rating of this game down a bit is the 3 hour length, as it stops me from getting it to the table as often as I would like.   
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
What a beast. The Euro answer to TI3? But not as long or complex. Yet at least as satisfying, though doesn't generate stories the way TI3 does. I like them both a lot but this is more my flavour. Like pistachio vs chocolate. or something.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9

I enjoyed my first play and so did my gaming group.  We played with 5 players and my best guess is that playing time is about 4 hours but could be quicker with some players getting ready for their turn while the person in front of them finishes their turn.

Simple to teach and play, no rules issues, constant player interaction and really tough decisions all the way through. also works from 2 through to 6 players. A 10 out of 10 from me.

RATING: 4
First, I want to say that Combat Commander is one of the best games the human mind has ever produced.

But Dominant Species has the serious blahs. There's this cool and intriguing area control game involved, but players are forced to play a surprisingly involved and annoying worker placement game in order to get to it.

I hate having to jump through beaurocratic hoops to get to the good stuff.

RATING: 8
Dominant Species is a war game with an animal theme on it.  The game is extremely deep and has a long play time of 3 hours (at least, depending on the AP of your group).  Because of this it's difficult to get it to the table.  It is a great game, and would probably not turn down a game (with the right group of people).  However, I might consider trading it away at some point because of how little it gets played.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Finally got in a play of this well-reputed monster of a game. It was indeed quite solid, but terribly lengthy. I can't say there was much that could be thematically trimmed away although the end of game score-every-tile was an extra nail in the coffin to me. It gave me an epic feeling at glacial speed. The complexity of calculations at the result of actions and domination cards encourages lengthy think-a-thon turns which I truly wish could be addressed. It would make for a much improved experience and dramatically shortened play time. Yet for all that, I quite liked it. Would I play it again? In the right mood, I certainly would.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
2010/10
After 1st play:
At Dominant Species you twist and twist and twist and then do a little tweak and finish with a somersault. There are so many ways to affect the situation on the board that you easily tie your brain into a neat knot.

The heart of the game is pure area control. What makes it more complicated than any other similar game is that each area can be controlled in two different ways. Before scoring there are several phases each turn and every single one of these phases can affect the situation considerably. Therefore, it's really hard to plan ahead.

But still I enjoyed the game more and more as it went longer. The art of the game is functional, but there's no way you could call it beautiful.


2013/01
8->9
If I just had time, I'd play Dominant Species any time. Unfortunately 3-5 hours is not something you always have at your disposal.


2015-11-04
To my big surprise I sold this in an auction. Might be that I'll regret it later, but at this point of my life I just felt like getting rid of games that haven't seen any or very little play in the past 3-4 years. It seems that nowadays the games hitting the table are action packed sub 90 minute games instead of longer ones like Dominant Species. And the fact that you essentially get the same experience from El Grande but in much simpler and more forgiving format, made the decision easier. I might get the iOS app of Dominant Species, which should make the game run faster since less time will be spent on calculating who's in control and who's dominating each area.

 If I only had more space to store my games...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Truly a game of 'survival'!

As the ice-age encroaches can your species adapt and migrate quickly enough to maximise the dwindling resources?

Perhaps a strategy of 'quiet attrition' over 'out & out dominance' is key in the early part of the game with a view to 'rapid expansion' [particularly of the Tundra] at the 'end game'- avoids 'tall poppy' and maximises the shifting VP distribution.

More than enough variables and permutations to ensure a 'different' game each time.

The only [minor] criticism would be that there are too many 'Dominance' cards to choose from each turn - maybe 2 or 3 instead of five may accentuate their power but lesson the number of 'major events' per turn. [edit.] Having played it a few more times I think the Domination cards work well, also acting as a game length limit [when they're gone, the game is over] also for varying the 'end game' scenario, dependant on what crds [or combination of cards] are left. The domination cards also add one of the 'random' elements into the game - along with the 'element' re-seeding at the start of each round.

It has become more enjoyable with each playing.

Note: Comments liable to moderation following more plays.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
A very good mix of mechanics that leads to very complex and subtle layers of interaction between players. Unlike anything I've seen so far. 

It's a long game but it's definitely worth the time.

+ perfect match of theme and mechanics
+ it feels EPIC, EURO and very THEMATIC at the same time (How cool is that!)
+ highly interactive (no matter what action you take, it will have negative consequences for someone)
+ very intense (the game wants to crush you, the players want to crush you, you really need to survive in this game)
+ huge replay value
+ unique, very original game

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Third printing ordered via P500.

We've had a few games now, and I'm confident in giving in a 9 for now.  For as long as the game takes to play, it feels like it plays very fast, which really impresses me.  You're constantly taking small turns and making decisions, and any time you're not is almost certainly filled up with considering your next action.  I get bored very easily during long games with lots of downtime, and I'm very pleased to see that Dominant Species doesn't have this problem.

I've never played a euro with this much direct competition before, and it's awesome!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 5
A wargame masquerading as a euro.  Very not for me.  I've played it a few times now and remain unconvinced.  Others will love it, I loathe it.  Biggest gripes:  Becomes bash the leader & often involves some king-making.  Swings from cards can be monstrous.  Control is illusory.  Come-from-behind wins are possible largely because those in front are busy getting smacked.  To me, that's not a fun game design.  But like I said above, others will love this.  So definitely give it a play or two or three and see whether or not it's for you.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Bad production (for eurogame standards), ugly but functional board and tiles (I have the first edition). Unique double majority control system. Nice, diverse and deep gameplay, very susceptible to kingmaking. I have played it with 2, 4, 5 and 6 and I liked it in every configuration, but it can get too long (a full game can be very satisfying, but often I would prefer to reduce the number of cards and initial cubes for a shorter game).

En una segunda partida (acabada) se convierte en un juego más rápido y divertido. El único problema es que el que domina la tundra se puede escapar y no hay forma de alcanzarlo.

RATING: 6.75
Not a fan of games where the scoring escalates exponentially and the brain explodes trying to calculate how to win in the last two or three moves. I prefer games that score a bit less to begin with (no one likes to lose because they got off to a bad start!) and ramp up gradually to compensate, but overall reward the most consistent player. Good game otherwise.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
One of the best recent eurogame designs that incooperates elements of Civilization, Wargaming and 'settlers-of-catan's' way of presentation. In some way, this game does give a nostalgic feel towards an old game....Tyranno Ex. 

No dice, no CRT charts, no chit-pull on who goes first......

An excellent game design that is clean, unlimited replayability, player interactions and multi-facet strategy to winning.

Downtime is minimal till last 1 or 2 turns but is acceptable.

With this game, El Grande looks like child's play.

A game that I will be playing for years to come.......awesome, just awesome.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
This is currently my favorite game. There is so much going on here that it's easy for even experienced players to fall into analysis paralysis. Multiple paths to victory, multiple viable strategies, plus ever changing tactical situations almost makes this a war game. If you have the time I highly recommend it. But be warned this thing is a long long game when you have more than 2 people playing.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
One of the best area control games along with El Grande! Elements of worker placement are there with the selection of actions and of course the domination cards that are beautiful and many of them very deadly. What did you expect? It's a battle for survival of your species! This one is deeper than El Grande and lasts longer (like twice the time longer) but it's also an excellent game. Quality components once again from GMT and after the 3rd printing is prettier in my opinion than when it first came out. I can't recommend this enough!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
I've only played once and loved it. The only questionable part to it was the 20 minutes of end-game scoring, which seemed to do nothing more than to take the position of the player on the scoring track and multiply by two - at the cost of 20 minutes of doing math. And I'd be upset if the scores did change that much during this phase, since it's really an area control game. If there were some fiddly way to not control area through the bulk of the game and suddenly cash in at the end, I don't think that it would go well with how the rest of the game plays.

I'd probably suggest ignoring the end-game scoring and just accepting the scores as they are at the end of the final round. As said - at least in my one play - it didn't actually change the order of the players at all. So it just added a bunch of time for no purpose.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
This game is incredible. The only thing keeping it from a full 10 for me is the length, and the fact that teaching it to new players can be a big of a slog, and I have seen people get completely turned off by both the length and an incomplete understanding of scoring mechanics. That being said, if you're willing to play it a couple of times to really get the framework down, it is an EPIC gaming experience, one that deserves to be in every serious gamer's collection.

Played the 3p 2 animal each variant and it works VERY well, and can allow for some interesting combos and interaction. Came down to a food chain tie break, awesome experience.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
There is a lot to like about Dominant Species!  The game takes a little while to learn (30-45 mins), but isn't particularly hard to play once understood.  It is a 3+ hour game, with some potential for Analysis Paralysis (AP) that I hope reduces as my friends become more familiar with the game.  Play is broken up well, however, so it is rare to wait long before doing something.

Dominant Species is an Area Control game (El Grande) with 
a lot of dynamics. The board, animals, resources, etc are all shifting due to player actions. This creates an intense and lively game that feels much shorter than the actual time it takes to play.

RULE NOTE: Be careful about scoring a hex (based on # of species/blocks) vs. Domination (based on adaptations/resources) - the same player does not always have both!

LEARNING NOTE: Highly recommended to play an abbreviated game with a friend (1 animal each, 1-2 turns, do 'end game') before trying to play with a group.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

The box states this a Chad Jensen game. I know now who to avoid!

RATING: 9.5

Tips: Put the action pawn from the Dominance action on the hex that's scored. Put a spare coloured cube on the animal's token on the initiative track (and maybe on the food chain too) as otherwise it can be hard to remember who's who.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
First Play, November 2011, Comment: A good game with some clever mechanics. 7 of 10.

Second Play, June 2012, Comment: A better game than I  realized after the first play.  This game is an excellent mix of theme, originality, El Grande, and Caylus. The game plays like a slugfest, punch after punch, which can be fun with the right group.  Raising it to an 8 of 10. 

Third Play, June 2012, Comment: Greater appreciation for the many layers and complexity of game play.  Raising it to a 9.

Fourth Play, June 2012, Comment: First 5 player game, not as good as with 4. Later rounds of game can be decided by 1-3 card plays, and thus, players need to take their time on these moves.  If they don't play very carefully, game outcome becomes a bit randomized, calling into question why the preceding 3 hours of game play were even played. Seems like a slight flaw.  Lowering to an 8. 

Twelfth Play, August 2012, Comment: Okay, whatever faults it has, and there are some, this is just an incredibly interesting game to play and consider from a design perspective.  Back to a 9.

A few thoughts for those players who find the game too long, chaotic, or vicious, with too many options for king making.  Because these complaints are essentially directly linked to the cards and card effects, and some in our group, have these issues....to improve the game for our group, we typically take out the three extra action pawn cards (which lengthen the game), and if we are in the mood to diminish the nastiness, we also take out the Blight and Catastrophe cards, or perhaps 2 other semi-nasty ones.  This tends to dial down all of the aforementioned problems.  In sum, with card selection/reduction options, this game is VERY customizable, something that you should understand straight up.  Have problems with some of the cards?  Take them out.  The game can stand on its own merits, without playing with ALL the cards.  Enjoy the version you make.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5

Tried it again and now it is easily the best game I have played. It is an extremely dynamic game that may at first seem too random but really just rewards anticipating all the card effects. It's just hard to get to the table at times.

RATING: 8.5
Dominant Species won my heart pretty quickly.  The first game we played, I knew I would want to play it more.  Granted, we had a few rules wrong, but it likely wouldn't have changed the outcome much.

The second game, rectified and sporting a full 6 players, practically ate my brain.  We pretty much all loved it (birds got understandably angsty after he got combination mass exodus > cataclysm'd around the 2/3rd mark) even though it really did require a ton of mental focus.  The board is crowded, species are always dying, and things are never QUITE going as well as you'd like.  And it's perfect that way.

Fun, rewarding, aggressive.  My 2nd favourite game.

RATING: 3
I wanted to play it, and was excited by the theme during rules explanation.  In practice, I found it to be a tactical downtime fest which quickly wore out its welcome.  Despite the plain production, just a little more theme might have been enough to suspend that disbelief.  At this point I think there should be a name, like AP (analysis paralysis), which denotes a game that encourages a player to apply lots of calculation to a decision only to have the game world change entirely as a result of subsequent player decisions.  Fool me once, etc.  Even with a much more brisk pace, it's hard for me to picture finding the decisions interesting and valuable.  Glad I tried it, though, and I'd still try the card game,

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A tough, heavy, but nicely balanced game. 

Quite literally, survival of the fittest. The action selection and execution mechanics are reminiscent of Age of Empires III, with the game essentially revolving around action order selection, plus two different kinds of board area control. But there's lots of cutthroat competition, with species dying off all over the place. The whole thing is very thematic, and the dominance cards provide added variablity between games (although they can also introduce some imbalance, depending on the game situation).

I only did one play with three, and it did feel like it would be a lot tighter with more players, which should make it more interesting, though potentially also with more downtime (we finished in around two and a half hours, with two newbs). There was still lots of competition on the board though, so I think the game should scale nicely at least with 3-5.

Edit: One more play with four, I'm starting to feel the game might be slightly too long - it gets a bit repetitive towards the end. Still liking it a lot, more plays will tell how it goes.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
An excellent game that somehow kept six people interested for six hours. With something like Illuminati I play for one and a half and already I'm reaching for the Valium, so this is quite something. Also, the scoring was really close for a game with no obvious catch-up mechanic. I thought it was great!

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Waited through a few plays of Dominant Species before commenting. 

This game is incredibly good, but almost feel like it's too complex to REALLY sort out a long term strategy. This could either be considered a good or a bad thing. The game forces you to react to your current situation and make the best of it. 

That said, there's a decided lack of RNG in this game, and so it gets plus points for that.

Dominant species gets better with each play, and deeper with more experienced players. There is a major learning curve that admittedly I'm not even to the top of yet prior to being able to form a strategy and see it through. In most cases, you're reacting to the game state rather than actively driving the board.

What I find incredibly hilarious about this game is that so many games love to claim that they are the perfect cross of an "Ameritrash" and a "Euro". This game is truly a cross between "Euro" and "Wargame"


------

This has been in rotation for a long while now. We play it every so often. It's still a great game, but every time I play it now, it always feels like the game lasts one turn too long. I'm starting to wonder if just removing 5 random cards at the beginning of each game could introduce some variance and replay value to the game.

RATING: 10
Un juego especial. Realmente bueno Todo está perfectamente integrado. la mecánica de Mayorías integrada con la de Colocación de Trabajadores; puteo junto con apoyo solidario; asimetría y evolución de las especies junto con eventos...

Acciones sencillas pero directas, sin la exclusión de nadie pues las acciones se pueden repetir y eso ayuda a jugadores que sufren con juegos como Caylus o Agricola.
Acciones que modifican el tablero (losetas) y a las especies (su adaptación), que las matan y que las anulan eliminando su ecosistema. que permiten puntuar y conseguir eventos, el orden del turno. Es que todo funciona bien.

Me parece un juegazo. Duración justa, destrucción de neuronas comedida, risas en algunos momentos y que permite a seis jugadores compartir mesa cosa que ahora mismo en el grupo es esencial. Un arte realmente estupendo con unos materiales supercuidados. Absolutamente recomendable. Un diez

RATING: 7
An acomplished design, with many clever features.  But, like History of the World, you need to be prepred to invest in the journey. take the hits (its a war game in disguise) and enjoy the flow.  I did, but not sure how often I want to invest the time.  As insects, I spent most of the game a distant sixth. only to pull it back to lose on the tie break of charated strength.

Rating based on my desire to play - as it is described.  But as a game design I would rate it as 8/10.

Second game, knowing the plot, was a lot more agoninsing and engaging.  But big potential for AP.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Quite some rules to remember what everything does. Takes quite a while to play. Because most of times when a player gains or loses an adaptation token you have to check the domination markers on the whole board and adjust accordingly, also when a new token is added to the main board the same checking must be made but this time is easier because it only matters on 3 tiles at most.
It's a very well thought out game.
It's an area control game but where both quantity and quality matters. You want to be able to have many species on a tile, for scoring purposes, but also be more adaptable to the environment in that tile than the other players, so you can claim domination cards when the scoring round comes.
Everything works well together. Requires some long term planning and short term as well. Available on the IOS.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.3
This one could probably be a ten after a few more plays.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
An excellent worker placement and evolution game.

Epping Good Games sale table, 14/9/16. Had $55 on it and I was considering it when I was told the price should be halved to $27.50 (thats about 75% off RRP)! No brainer (although I still went through the motions of considering it).

https://www.boardgamegeek.com/geeklist/61422/item/2811139#item2811139
Regrettably confirms my original instincts which should have prevented me from buying it. However it was a bargain and it looks great! ;-)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Nagyon nagy élmény volt! Ez az első olyan játék, amin el kell gondolkodnom, hogy talán még a Caylusnál is jobb... Ehhez persze még játszanom kell vele, remélem lesz alkalmam minél több féle létszámmal kipróbálni, de már a kétszemélyes is nagyon bejött.

Jöjjön a részletes ajnározás: először is a játék nagyon szép. A doboza az újfajta fényes GMT-s doboz, amit nagyon szeretek. A tábla is első osztályú, a felépítése nagyon logikus, letisztult. A kártyák és fák is jók. Biztos van, aki szerint ez így absztrakt, de szerintem sokkal átláthatóbbak a kis kockák, mintha pókok meg dinók lennének helyettük:)
Nemcsak a játék külsejére, hanem a tartalmára is találó a letisztult szó, kevés játéknál érezni, hogy ennyire egzakt, jól letesztelt. Worker Placement játék, végig ugyanazok az akciók állnak rendelkezésre, többségük nagyon ötletes. Maga a témaválasztás is jó, bármennyire szeretem is a történelmet, néha már unalmas az 1000-dik római meg egyiptomi játék. Az absztrakt külső ellenére is átjön a tematika, a kiszorítósdi, a szaporodás, és a nagyon jól kitalált dominancia-mechanizmus. Szerintem zseniális a jég terjedése, és a létszám vs. dominancia kettősség, egyik közvetlen győzelmi pontra váltható, másik pedig kártyákhoz juttat. A kártyák nagyon egyediek, nem egy kaptafára készültek, és nagyon erősek is szinte kivétel nélkül.
Ennyire dinamikus játékot még nem láttam, egyik pillanatban egyikünk dominált a teljes térképen, másik pillanatban a másikunk, ebből következően nem sok esélyt látok arra, hogy egy játék mondjuk a felénél eldőljön... Nehéznek tűnik elhúzni. Nagyon kíváncsi lennék, hogy ha valaki tiszta stratégiát játszik, az mennyire kifizetődő (pl. mindig jegesedésre vagy versenyre rámenni). Elsőre úgy tűnt, hogy túlságosan taktikai játék, bármilyen stratégia 1 kör alatt dugába dőlhet. Nincs a játéktáblán, ami tuti a miénk, talán csak a megszerzett pontok (bár kártyával még azt is csökkenthető)... Amit kifelejtettem, hogy a 6 állatfajta speciális előnyei is nagyon ötletesek.
A játék alapja a konfrontáció, ahogy azt sejteni lehet a címéből, a sértődékeny embereknek annyi:)


Féltem, hogy nagyon nehéz lesz a játék. Nos, a szabály maga kifejezetten egyszerű, hála a nagyon logikus szabálykönyvnek (a 20 oldal fele példa és szemléltető ábra). Viszont a 12 akciót és a táblán lévő viszonyokat átlátni már 2 ember esetén is komoly teljesítmény. Csak bevállalós eurogémereknek ajánlom!

A szabály egyelőre csak angolul lelhető fel. Ezt leszámítva nyelvfüggőséget csak a kártyák (27 db) jelentenek, meg a segédlet (tudtommal készül a magyarítás). A 2 személyes játék bő 3 óra volt (nem fix körös a játék).

Ha mindenképpen hibát kellene mondanom, akkor hármat tudnék mondani: a dobozban szűkösen fér el az anyag (micsoda hiba:)), a 12 féle akciót kicsit jobban "kitáblázhatták" volna, nehéz megjegyezni, hogy melyik pontosan mit csinál, kellett pár kör, mire beleszoktunk. És végül az is hiba szerintem, hogy ha nagyon buta emberek játsszák a játékot, előfordulhat, hogy sose lesz vége, mert nem fogyasztják el a paklit. De ez legyen az ő bajuk:)
---
Még annyit, hogy a pakli nagy ötlet, bár épp hibaként róttam fel egy sorral fentebb, mivel akár a végtelenségig is húzható emiatt a játék, de annyi előnye mindenképp van, hogy nem függ a játékosszámtól a játékidő! Sőt mivel kevesebb akció jut egy emberre, lehet hogy nagyobb létszámnál még gyorsabban is lemegy az egész.
---
Na kipróbáltuk 4 fővel, sokkal hosszabb, mint ketten (5 óra volt kb. tisztán), mivel sokkal nehezebb átlátni, egy akció végrehajtása több idő.
---
5 fős játék: mindenki vezetett legalább 1 kör végén (6 körös játékban). Ilyen létszámnál már elég hátrányosnak érzem a később következő fajok helyzetét. (Nem nagyon van más ilyen Worker placement játék, ahol nem tudsz egyből kezdővé válni, hanem csak araszolgatni tudsz a sorrendjelzőn, már ha az előrébb következők egyáltalán engedik. Tehát simán lehet, hogy végig utolsóként lép egy faj. Nem biztos, hogy a képességei ezt a hátrányt kiegyenlítik.)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
Love this game.  So much happens, and there are so many ways to win that this game is great.  The theme of evolving your species is fun and adaptation is the name of the game.  The length on this one is a bit long, and the end game scoring is a little confusing for those just starting.  This is also a challenge to teach and learn since there is so much to keep track of, depsite the fact that all the info you need is listed on the board itself, it is still daunting for a new player to jump on board.

RATING: 8.4
Clearly one of the good area control games. There are interesting mechanics and I like the cards and the duality between elements (dominance) and quantity of species (direct scoring). This duality however offers a bit too many choices. I'd like to see a connection between these two fields of conflict.
I found the worker placement choices excellent. Although the elements system...I think it should shrink a bit because the choices there are a bit confusing.
Never try the 2/3 player variant where each player controls 2 animals. 
Thematically it reminded me of evo and valley of the mammoths. A bit overpriced. Graphic design is good (I'd like an area in each tile to place the cubes that have already moved for that round), and I wouldn't mind some illustrations at that price.

RATING: 8
This is a game designed with ambition!!
It is a great and unique game, with LOTS of player interaction and lots of chaos to control, and a very tactical nature (it is a game about adaptation, after all...).
In the very first game I was playing the Mammals, was behind in initiative order and got crushed by repeated cards played by my opponents. This probably becomes less of an issue with repeated plays, but I found the turn order mechanic and card strength as possible flaws.
Anyway, the game is clearly subject to a problem of analysis paralysis, since every single move of every single player can definitely change the board position. So, it is a very long game!
Need to play more games to fully grasp, but I sense the potential of a rise in my initial vote (7.5)...
Update july 29, 2011: after the first few frustrating plays, I can feel the game grow on me. Now it is a 8.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
el grande meets AOE3. I prefer el grande for the territory control aspect, and much prefer aoe3 for the action selection.

the game works, but is waaaaaay to long for what it is. 3 plays of el grande in that same time would be a lot more satisfying. also, for such a long game randomness with card draws and general lack of control over your fate and being on the mercy of others is a very big drawback.

this feels like a nice enough 1.5h game, but at 4.5h I am not at all sure I'd want to ever play it again.

RATING: 7
I've only played this game once and I look forward to playing again but only with the right circumstances, ie other new players. To be honest, I'm scared of this game. It's a solid 3 hour time commitment, which is fine except that the game can be pretty unforgiving. Slip up in the first half hour and you get to sit back and watch yourself lose for 2 1/2 hours. I'm determined to get competent enough to hold my own, however, because the game has so much going for it. Great theme, great combination of mechanics, and a really cool set of variable player powers.

UPDATE: I've owned this game for almost a year and I still haven't played a game to completion. It isn't for lack of trying, either. In fact, I really like this game a lot and I'm dying to find some players. The trouble is my wife doesn't find it fun... like AT ALL. Hrmph!

Dominant Species is basically the worker placement version of El Grande.  I'm not really a fan of randomness, kingmaking, and/or screw the leader.  However, this game does offer plenty of interesting decisions.       

Game length is also an issue, especially the last turn.  Choosing where to migrate before end game scoring can drag something awful, but that's the price for playing a more complex version of El Grande.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
12/2012 - first time with learning game with 3 players. Love the game. Close score with winner leading by 4 and 2,3 tied at end. Mammals, Arachnids, Insects. When learning, we take a seriously AP approach to figure things out and get the rules right - even breaking to consult BGG for rules questions/errata mid-game. That 5hrs doesn't include the 1.5 hr read-through/discussion. Worth it. Figure we can burn through this game pretty quick now, having a much deeper understanding of the mechanics. Nice flow in the changing conditions - 4 major shifts in land control throughout the game. Funny that we didn't see enough usage of Competition and Migration categories. Heavy activity in the Speciation and Domination categories. 

2012-12-15 3-player, crushed by player playing heavy Domination strategy. I took the Ice-sheet approach and nearly caught up in the end with complete domination of the Ice-sheet space, but, naturally, got killed on the domination points for each tile.

2012-12-18 - 3-player, shortened game (mid-week game nights are tough with this one, just outside the edge). Won this with sheer volume of tile domination at end-game scoring assisted by other two players duking it out in what use to be sea dominated territory. Just that they didn't spread out enough. I Wanderlusted 3 times on that last round with high scoring tiles which sealed the deal on the tile placement as well as the tile scoring.

RATING: 9
First Play: I came last, I made some horrfic mistakes and it is probably the best game I've ever played. 

The placement element has many options that really do need to be properly balanced with whats on the board. There may be a tendancy for AP with some players so a timer might need to be shipped in but once the mechanic is run through this is an incredibly slick game.

The limited randomness with card and tile draws is all manageable. You see whats coming out and need to legislate for it. If you are weak in one area defend it. If you lose that advantage then thats your fault, and no one elses.

A brutal savage game of ultimate screwage. Genius.

Played the variant where 4 cards are removed (3 x AP gain). This does provide a shorter game and a flavour of the full version but there does seem to be a large ingredient missing and given a choice I'd rather play the full game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Overall, a decent game, but I would recommend you try before you buy.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.1
A real beast of a game. It's a strange mix of euro and ameritrash with a dash of randomness. The result is an amazingly deep game that is captivating for the whole duration. It very much has a bash the leader feel and when everybody is after you there's not much you can do. But over the course of the game things seem to balance out. One bad thing I can say about the game is that the possibillities are so overwhelming that it is not a wise idea to play with AP prone people. Definitely a game to play with a timer as things can get out of hand quickly. Another minus is the tedious task of keeping track of dominance in all the different territories. I've heard people complain about the components. But allthough minimal they are very functional and give the game a clean and crisp look. I like them.

Gameplay: :star::star::star::star::nostar:
Replayability: :star::star::star::star::halfstar:
Fun/Social: :star::star::star::star::nostar:
Components: :star::star::star::halfstar::nostar:
Rules: :star::star::star::star::nostar:

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
After playing various times, this is another game that I have a love/hate relationship with. On the one hand, the innovative design, the player interaction, the special abilities each animal class has, the majority versus domination concept, the area majority / worker placement mechanics and a theme that hits a home run with me, makes it a sure winner of a game in my book. On the other hand, the unpredictability and the randomness set forth in some of the cards and player interaction has left me a bit frustrated. Maybe it's the Euro blood in me, but I prefer to be in control of my destiny.

For example, in a six player game played by my friends and I, on the last round the card that randomly lets you pull out an element from a draw bag and place it on your animal/class player board was played. My main competition/opponent happened to pull out the exact element needed (an element on my player board) to directly compete with me in the domination of the tiles we shared. The board completely changed in that one instant from me having dominance to him having dominance. Then, of course, the card that scores dominance and triggers the end of the game was played. Needless to say, it cost me the win. If my opponent would have pulled any other type of element from the bag, it would have been a different story.

Despite the aforementioned, I rate this gamer's game highly because of the innovation it brings, the tough tense decisions that have to be made and the sheer fun factor. Despite the game having a 4 weight on the Geek, I found the rules intuitive and very well thought out. Maybe I need more experience to mitigate the chaos and randomness? Maybe the challenge is in managing what other players and cards will bring?

Anyways, beautiful design! I can't wait to get it on the table again!

RATING: 1

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
So, finally got this played last night. With 4 players, which should be the optimal player count.

This is clearly a "big game", it feels rather epic and I appreciate that. Of the other games I have tried, I think it comes closest to games like A Game Of Thrones and Eclipse. I think if I had tried this game a year ago I would have been over the moon about it. At that point in time I was really in love with games like A Game Of Thrones and Eclipse and this would have fit right in.

For some reason I have steered a bit away from those type of games. I still really do enjoy them when they get to the table, but that doesn't happen very often. But they do give you that epic feel which not a lot of other games do. Thinking about it, I think Twilight Struggle might be sort of filling that whole for me, even though it is a whole other kind of game.

Anyway, this is a great design and a really liked it a lot. In the game I had built up a HUGE lead and felt 100% certain that I would win, but I had forgotten that there is a final round scoring where I do to the bash the leader phenomenon had very few cubes left on the table and hence got overtaken by ONE measly point.

I did think that it went a bit long. I think our game lasted about 4 hours and I think the suggestion made by someone here to remove the cards that give an extra action pawn is a good one.

My concern is that this is gonna be tough to get to the table in general.

RATING: 9
Love this game! 

Really filled my desire for a euro with constant in your face combat. Sure I have euros or hybrids where you you slowly undermine the other player's engines or just deny them of worker placement spots, but here your literally wiping their species off of the face of the earth for the rest of the game! Sometimes in HUGE quantities by just taking away a single food source their animal needed to survive. I don't own anything like it and it's fantastic.

The actions are easy to understand at a basic level. There's no 'bad' action to take, simply things that are better for you current situation. Even though I had a three hour game, all of the individual plays felt quick, especially since it's a good idea to watch what other people are doing - keeping you totally engaged. And even though the screenshots of this game looked kind of bland it looked better than expected in person and it was nice being able to play a game without all this glossy chrome layered on okay gameplay (miniatures, lots of art, what have you) and just being able to enjoy the fantastic mechanics of it all for the first time in a while.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
I don't understand what space this game is trying to occupy?  Is there really a demand for a longer, more chaotic, less interesting El Grande with a better theme?  I keep waiting for another area majority game worthy of being in my collection, but nothing yet has offered something distinct enough to warrant playing instead of El Grande and it has been over a decade.

Let's start with the most obvious flaw, the game takes 3+ hours which is most definitely not the right length for this type of game.  A good area majority game has a lot of take-that, kingmaking in it.  These are aspects that demand a fairly short running time, even El Grande is slightly too long in my estimation.  There are numerous stories on BGG of people being out of the running early and while that seems unlikely it is clear that at the end of Dominant Species you can't plausibly say that your score reflects the proficiency of your play.  There are just too many things that can potentially hose you in such a long game that you can do very little about.  Such things are thematic for a game about evolution and by the scores on BGG a lot of people like the experience, but as a game Dominant Species fails.

A large part of my disdain from the game comes from how much of a Frankenstein of prior games it is.  The domination cards are identical to El Grande's action cards except without any attempt to balance them (I am sure many people consider this a good thing).  Then the glaciation clearly takes cues from a number of games, Trias comes to mind if only for the thematic similarity, and the worker placement portion is SO obvious, not containing an iota of clever design.  This is a common fault with worker placement and it is why the system needs to hibernate for awhile and rejuvenate itself before returning.  Then there is the whole domination mechanism that the game wants you to constantly track for reasons that I do not understand.

Lastly, I am not sure the theme is really that good.  Elements seem to have no affinities to the land area they sit upon.  And why are completely different phylums competing?  I think the game would be far more interesting if it tried to work in some of the symbiosis that obviously occurs in nature rather than some weird competition between spiders and apes.

Anyways, Dominant Species is not worth the time or hefty price tag.  Go play El Grande instead.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
For Rich
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
What a masterpiece!! One of the best themes out there. Lot of people are calling it abstract but I strongly disagree. Sure your species are just little wooden cubes, and the land tiles are just hexes, but the way it plays out and how the mechanics force you into certain situations really makes you feel like your struggling to survive as the ice age approaches. It can be very tough for new players to know what the hell to do (unfortunately I am still in that category) but what deep heavy 3+ hour game doesn't have this characteristic? The king making and overall chaos issues don't even bother me just because it is so enjoyable to play. Because of the length and the overall feel to this game I would put it up beside Through the Ages as my "epic" go to games. This category is reserved for games that melt your brain and completely wear you out and Dominant Species defiantly does both.

The night after I first played this game I could sleep. Just laid in my bed staring a the ceiling analysing my first epic game of Dominant Species. I strongly feel that the amount of sleep one gets after playing a board game for the first time is inversely proportional to the quality of that game. This shoots Dominant Species to the top of the charts.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
An area control & worker placement game with bite (nastiness).  The worker placement mechanism in this game is similar to the Age of Empires III board game, which I like.  At times Dominant Species is very intense, but ultimately I think it may be too luck-heavy and chaotic for my liking and for the length of the game (3-4h).

The element (food) chits are drawn from a bag (chit pull), and they can be heavily skewed; Your primary food type might come out all at once or it might not appear for 3-4 turns in a row.  The cards (which are received for having dominance) tend to cause lots of chaos.  In fact, some cards seem to be too powerful.

You really need to focus on the element (food) discs when your permanent food comes out or you'll get hurt by the wasteland and decimation actions.  You may need to stall (and not produce your cubes/species on the board) because your permanent food type is not getting drawn from the bag.  In this case, at least you can score some points from land tile placement (via glaciation or wanderlust) while you await better times (food) for your species.

RATING: 8
I really enjoyed this one, playing with 3 players each controlling 2 animals. For quite a deep game, it has an  easy to understand ruleset. The complexity comes in how all the moving parts come together - there all lots of potential actions and things going on all over the board. This leaves a deliciously painful set of dilemmas as there are always more things that you want to do and in more places than you have actions for. It can be quite brutal if you get screwed by the other players, and some of the cards are very powerful if you get them at the right time (although you know what's coming up in the turn to compete for). Can't wait for next time...

RATING: 7.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Wowowow my favourite game ever!

Dominant Species is a worker placement game with the Species Evolution theme pasted on. I don't know about you, but I feel the theme is more present than I expected.

So, you are an animal species trying to survive the Ice Age, by adapting to the ever-changing environment, fighting with other species, migrating to places where your species can flourish, etc

The worker placement engine is great. The order of events make sense and it create a brainfreezing challenge (and that's the only problem with the game... it is AP prone) for the players.

It's a GMT game with very good components. The artwork is simple "a la GMT style". Nothing astonishing, but quite clear and simple looking.

The variety of strategies is amazing and each animal has a special power. Everygame looks different than the previous one.

The way the board evolves during the game, makes you feel that the world is really changing. And with that all the struggles that comes with it with our species.

Great great game! It's heavy, but I don't think it's that hard to get into. Not for AP prone players (it can really be a bad experience for them and other players)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Dominant Species is making a fantastic first impression.  It's a game of constant aggression and success to you needs to come at the cost of the other people playing.  The systems mesh perfectly and the time spent (over 7 years in development from what I understand!) shows with the smoothness of play and the way that all of the systems work together to create an ebb and flow that one would expect from the evolutionary theme.  I love the fact that this game has the "pebble in the pond" effect down perfectly.  Decisions made have impacts that you may not be aware of until much later.  Amazing game!

My initial impressions based on my first two two-player games is very positive.  I think that this game is going to be a big hit with my group!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Dominant Species offers a variety of strategies and options, that are balanced well. High player interaction, deep tactical decisions and variety of options with excellent balance between animals and strategies make this an outstandig strategy game. The theme is well integrated into the game, because it feels like a game of survival and starvation, with new species quickly appearing and disappearing. DS manages to integrate powerful instant-effect or permanent-effect cards into the game without being broken. You're often offered two or three strong options.
The conflict for Action Spaces is high. Additionally you often want to take 6 actions desperately so always have tough choices to make.

The problems it has are that an annoying part of tactics is correctly counting and memorizing cubes and additionally taking the cards into account. This is somewhat unsatisfying.

The scoring mechanic isn't too intuitive, because "Dominate" vs "Dominance" is confusing.

The only unfair mechanic seems to be Survival Scoring since only 1 player is rewarded, which can be harsh.

Overall an extremely good game.

2pl 3pl 4pl 5pl 6pl

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I try not to buy games on impulse anymore. But when I first read about this I was fascinated by the theme and the mechanics. It reminded me a bit of "Revolution: The Dutch Revolt" with its multi-phasic and interwoven structure; but here, each player will only be able to participate in a limited number of the actions (phases). I expect that the "action draft" here will be a brain burner (experience may well modify that - the question is to what extent). At first blush however, this sounds delicious!

I'm not usually a big fan of chaos, but as a war gamer I can tolerate some ("Warriors of God" is at the upper end of my tolerance level - "Settlers of Catan" is way beyond it). This appears to have a fair dose of it which has been remarked upon quite negatively by some. This could be the kicker but I'll have to try it on for size. It really depends on the game and how all the moving parts come together and the impact the chaos has on the arc of game play.

In any event, when the game was up for reprint I jumped all over it. I now anxiously await an opportunity to get it on the table. The initial rating is simply anticipatory - I hope and expect it to go up...
++++++
Got the game on the table and my heavens it is a brain burner! This is going to take some playing into. Every action you take ripples down the action tracking board, and on the playing field, and "dominance" calculations have to be re-assessed constantly. We found it engrossing but long. Some folks are not going to be happy with the calculation heavy nature of this game - and beware if you have folks in your group who are either prone to AP or who relish mini-maxing calculations to the last decimal! It was very interesting to play but I'll need to play a lot more before deciding where to place this game. Still, one of the more truly innovative designs that I have seen in some time!

Ed Note: Couple of plays in now and a couple on the iOS app. I'm totally convinced this is a top shelf game, but some of the earlier reservations remain. The game invites more players rather than fewer but that means long game times. One idea I'm toying with is to clear the board of cards during reset to limit the game to six turns.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Пока 8, но, думаю, с большим количеством сыграных игр вырастет и рейтинг. Мой внутренний дарвинист ликует от этой игры.

RATING: 8

I would not recomment to play this with people prone to AP.

RATING: 7
Provisional rating - I need to play more.

First feel is very positive, theme fits the mechanics and you feel engaged the whole game, and you don't have to keep checking the rules.

Not a game for someone with AP! and I'm not sure I'd want to play with more than 4, just for the game length (unless all were fast players).

I like it - definitely a hybrid, there is conflict here, you can really mess with other players directly and indirectly. Seems to scale ok too with the number of players.

I like the random chit pull for the 'enviroment', but I like the way the chits move down, so you have some control and some prior warning of problems coming up.

Feels a bit like Age of Empires III mixed with TyranoEx.

** Update, definitely flavour of the month - playing this every week :) There is a nice mix of strategy and tactics - yes you have to optimise your actions each turn and react to what others are doing, which cards are available this turn and what element disks are where - but you can also have an overarching strategy you try to follow and I like the simple way each animal plays differently. Rating increased 

** Update, now played it with more - and it is a different beast, but I like it. You can't play each animal the same - and being later in the turn order makes it very unlikely you'll move up unless animals going before you prioritise something else. Not that going last is a disaster, food chain to break ties is a help, it just means you have to take a different approach

*** Update - shine off a little bit, mostly time taken to play, plus I think I prefer Age of Empires for the action placement mechanic.

RATING: 8.2
Apparently its a time sink- so be it:) Not all in life is quick quick.

3-4 is the sweet spot?!?

This game was a pleasant surprise.  This morning I got to work through a few rounds and tried a couple of different species.

It reminded me of Age of Empires in the sense of a worker placement.  There is interaction though that somewhat reminded me of Axis and Allies.

What I really enjoy is the sense of clawing for survival.  I think with two many AP players though the game could bog down so with higher numbers I can see me putting out an hour glass.

I think the components are great and for me it all just works.  It was easier than Age of Empires in the sense that all the actions come as a result of the placement of action pawns. So much of the game is all about population manipulation and then timing placements of cubes/species to ride along for a scoring op.

Fun!!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
How can a game look so unappealing on the board, full of cubes, cones, and hexes, yet provide such an engaging, strategic, and [i]thematic[/i] experience.  Simple, make each turn tell a story.  Food sources die out, forcing species to evolve; the ice age expands, forcing species to find new land and procreate.  At the end of the game, as the glaciers become the dominant landmass, the game turns into not running away, but living, fighting, and dying on the new harsh landscape.  The species that adapts/survives the best wins.  All with cubes and cones.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
One hell of an area control game and I think it's an impressive design.  But my feelings on it have declined since my first play almost 5 years ago.  Mainly it's tough to get to the table.  The rules aren't all that complex but the game is quite heavy so the first game(s) feels like you're just along for the ride.  So you need to get multiple plays of this with the same group to appreciate it.  But that's tough because this is also a long game.  The theme comes through more than you might expect but it's still pretty abstract.  The main mechanism of the game has a programming feel- you select actions worker placement style, then after everything is selected the actions are executed.  It's very cool, but despite your planning things will go haywire as your plans clash with your opponents' in unpredictable ways.  And that's all fine too but in a game this long and heavy I wish it felt a little more controlled and less swingy.  Overall, I think there are better games that give a similar feel in less time and with less complexity.

SOPHIE
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Un juego de evolución prehistórica, con una mecánica de colocación de trabajadores similar al Age of Empires III. El tablero consta de una serie de losetas sobre las que los jugadores van colocando sus especies.. las losetas se pueden evaluar (va por mayorías).. y cuando eso sucede, se distribuyen puntos entre los presentes, y se adjudica una carta a aquél que tena la dominancia (esté más favorecido por los recursos disponibles en la loseta).

El tablero es modular a base de hexágonos.. y en los vértices de los hexágonos se ubican los recursos de los cuales se "alimentan" los especies. 

Es un juego bastante estratégico. Duración media - larga (3-4 horas), pero muy absorvente. Altamente recomendable. Es un gran juego, aunque me parece caro para la calidad de los componentes y el diseño (muy pobre).

RATING: 4
This is one of the most unpleasant experiences I've had from a game.
It more or less defines everything I don't like about 
heavier euros - too many choices, with no basis in reality
helping to direct them.

Pity. I love the concept of evolution games, and not
one has gotten it 'right' yet. DS though manages to put
all others to shame. It may be a fine game for people who
love nothing better than to count and recount all the time.
But, that's just too much effort for me. I'd far prefer
just working on a spreadsheet and making my decision once.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Simple to explain....just 30 minutes. But a whole lot of 'think' behind playing the game. It's El Grande on steroids, throwing in worker placement and a double area majority control (species presence and element matching). Our first game took 4.5 hours which is a bit long. However, the game play is tense and entirely engaging.

The cards are a bit chaotic. The swings are rather large with some devastating cards depending on which round it appears (Blight + Catastrophe + Ecodiversity + Biodiversity). We will try with the variant of not including the cards.

Not sure which came first (the chicken or the egg) but the theme is original and integrated, in otherwise what could have been a mechanically detached euro.

Update: after four plays, it is more apparent that the cards are not as chaotic and swingy as first thought. The biggest knock against the game is the random factor of elements that get drawn. The only other knock is the computing of dominance which gets a bit tedious.

The play time with 4 players is under 3 hours.  With the right group and a few plays under your belt, this can be down to 2.5 hours. And I'm really digging the theme. Lurve it.

The game is not noob friendly. They find it too swingy, chaotic and devastating. And yet, I don't find that at all after several plays. The most frustrating aspect is when the elements you need don't appear.

Update #2- I would really like to rate this game a 9 or a 9.5, but the random elements really prevent this from ascending to higher greatness. If your core elements don't come out, then you're really behind the 8-ball.

Update #3: Dropped rating from 8.5 down to 8. The game has lost some of its lustre. Playing with experienced players now. The random draw of elements nearly break the game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8

RATING: N/A
*  $70
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Fascinating, immersive, at times completely chaotic -- and yet you know EXACTLY how you got where you are.  One moment everyone's in Happyland with plenty to eat and everything they desire; the next they're looking at total devastation and wondering how they're going to get through the next turn.  Die Macher with animals is an accurate description, but a heck of a lot easier to "sell" to players.  A long game that doesn't FEEL long. With more play, this could become a 9. 

Brilliant design feature: the action chart on the board that condenses most of the (fairly complex) rules and makes what could have been a difficult game easy to pick up, even for players used to lighter fare.  And while the graphic design at first looks underwhelming, it suits the game perfectly.

Update: After teaching this game several times, I finally got to play it a second time.  Two-player game (without the optional rules), I got an early advantage, and against all odds, my opponent could NOT turn it around.  In a four-hour game (which ended after 1 am), that could have been misery -- and yet not only did we both enjoy the game, we sat up for a good half hour afterwards dissecting it.  THAT is a good game.  I don't have a lot of 9s, but one more game like this, and this one's joining the ranks.

Update Two: I've played several games now, and it just gets better, even when I get destroyed. 9 it is.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.71
Really Nice heavy worker placement. The way the games evolve is notably good and make your decision matter.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This has been the most played game from the Essen 2010 purchases.  And for a 4 hour game this is truly incredible.  One of the finest games ever to have entered my collection.

Since writing the above I have since played with the recommended four cards removed and find it an even better game.  Firstly it reduces the playing time to a more acceptable limit without giving any feeling that the game has been shortened.  What is more, removing cards that gave some players more action points than others would be a recommendation in itself because such cards unbalance an otherwise superb game and would have been better omitted from the outset; so nothing lost there

FURTHER THOUGHTS:  Unfortunately not such a good game (overall) as I originally thought.   The game mechanic is truly excellent but the game is spoiled by the incredible imbalance of the Event Cards.  This is a 3+ hours highly tactical game but a player can be put right out of it near the end, thereby giving no time to recover, by the fall of certain of these cards.  This is totally unacceptable in a game of this complexity and length.  Yet alongside these devastating cards there are others that are extremely mild in their effect.   It is no surprise that a player falling victim to these  damaging cards after 3 hours of mental slog never wants to play it again.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I love this game, but it burns... bad!  I know many people who are very much undecided about this game.  Then again, they tend to play it with 4-6, and I've only played it with 2.  With 2, it's plenty hard enough (I think I've won once).  Unlike most 2 player area control games, this one is actually good, because you have to manage two types of control simultaneously.  This doubling is the games main innovation imo, and worth getting the game for even if it doesn't come out too often.  Unlike many similar games, it is possible to come from behind, but managing the short and long games is very hard to do.  Don't underestimate the Survival card - letting someone hold it for a few turns can be devastating, especially if they are spread out thin.  Honestly, no game in recent memory gets my blood up like this one does.  It does have plenty of chaos even with 2 (mostly in the form of the random element draws), so if you are skeptical of this one, play first with 2 or 3.  Fun, but long (expect 2-2.5 hours with 2) and HARD.  A design I greatly admire.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
I watched several BGG review videos of this game, thought it looked so fun and complex, heard from so many people how awesome it was, and was excited to finally get this as a gift. 

On our first two-player game, I found myself annoyed at having to CONSTANTLY recalculate dominance for every hex,  frustrated at how long each turn was taking, and generally moaned and groaned for the greater part of two hours. Yes, we ended the game early because no one was having fun. I hope that we'll have a better go at it next time, but it was unfortunately not a good first experience. Too bad, because the third printing is beautiful.

RATING: N/A
A Euro that's better than the European Euros. The gameplay matches the theme perfectly. Super deep game with a lot of decisions for present and future.  Optimally 4-6 players is the way to go.  I highly recommend a couple practice rounds to learn the terminology on the board.  This is a serious strategy game that requires thoughtful play but worth the effort. Each turn is an adjustment to the other species play which fits perfectly to the theme. You can set up tricks and traps when you get really comfortable with the mechanism. This is a flat out winner for sure. Warning, this is a heavy game that can be a real brain burner.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Awesome game!  A little odd in that it feels like it's supposed to be a heavy strategy game, but the amount of chaos ends up putting it more on the tactical side of things.  There can be a small amount of planning ahead, but you're pretty much riding the waves.  Nevertheless, I have a lot of fun playing it!

The game basically boils down to a worker placement/area majority game, where your worker placements allow you to tailor the world to your liking, adapt your species for higher survivability, and add more of your species to the world.

There are two kinds of things you're fighting for.  One is simply having the most guys on a tile, which allows you to score points throughout the game.  The second part is having the best match to the environment on each tile, which gives you "dominance" of that tile, regardless of how many guys you have on the tile.  Dominance allows you to take advantage of dominance cards, which have rather powerful effects!  Dominance also will score you a potential boatload of points at the game end.

Overall, a very cool game that's actually rather straight-forward despite the initial glut of choices you're presented with.  A few turns in and you'll be rolling along just fine though.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: N/A
*$
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Updated 10/28/10.

I’ve dreaded writing this entry.  So much has been written about [thing=62219]Dominant Species[/thing] in the past month by people whose commitment to and understanding of gaming makes me feel intellectually Lilliputian.  I’m not sure I can add much of value.

But I will try to follow the advice of [user=johnrayjr][/user]
He said:
[q]…try to capture what makes a game tick in the NtY lists each month…[/q]

Dominant Species is an epic game. It takes hours.  It is hard.  It is tense, and I mean brow-sweat-inducing.  And -- as any game about classes of animals struggling for survival in the face of an impending ice age should be -- it is ruthlessly interactive. Those are the games [u]virtues[/u]. 

From a design standpoint, the game is one of those rare, obvious-in-hindsight innovations.  Stripped bare, [person=6331]Chad Jensen[/person] essentially replaced the cards in card-driven games with a worker placement-driven system of action selection.  In doing so, he not only exponentially expanded the options available with each action -- resulting in greater control, and richer gameplay – but also he produced one of the most natural and intuitive uses of worker placement on the market.  

Here, worker placement drives the action, but does not draw attention to itself.  It is the crank that winds the music box, not the music.  To this task it seems ideally suited.  Indeed, something about its implementation here satisfies both my enjoyment of worker placement and my love for programming games (such as [thing=38453]Space Alert[/thing]).  Moreover, the menu of actions from which players select is arranged as a logical hierarchy (with choices at the top requiring only a fraction of the gut-wrenching mental energy of choices at the bottom) that effectively provides a built-in tutorial for the accompanying board play.  The angst of action selection also allows players to really identify with their species’ standing in the world (whether desperately needing to flee to parts unknown or ruthlessly exploiting a position of momentary dominance).  The result is a special kind of thematic immersion. 

From an experience standpoint, I can’t help but link Dominant Species to [thing=12333]Twilight Struggle[/thing], though I’ve heard comparisons range from [thing=25613]Through the Ages [/thing](with a map!) to [thing=93]El Grande[/thing], The Director’s Cut.  Both Dominant Species and Twilight Struggle are incredibly satisfying to play because of their slowly developing narrative arc.  I’ve encountered few games that can simply allow a compelling story to unfold through good play.  Although both are long, neither seems to outstay its welcome.  Both produce precisely the kind of atmosphere that I enjoy most: palpable tension.  In both, that tension is manifested in a struggle for survival that is appropriately thematic for each, and that I find just engaging.  Lastly, each game has a large number of strategic options that are all sufficiently interconnected to allow for maximum flexibility in response to randomized elements. Neither is a game that asks you to commit to one of a few well-defined strategies, with just a little flexibility at the margins (I’m looking at you, [thing=35677]Le Havre[/thing]).  Instead, both games seem to be about carving out a unique path in a seemingly unconstrained strategy space by layering small decision upon small decision.

I can’t say enough good things.  I love that it provides the ability to force other players into a decision between benefiting you with their actions or depriving themselves, whether through secondary and tertiary majorities, or through adaption and dominance.  I love that the random and unequal dominance cards incentivize short-term goals –- often, just avoiding the havoc another player is soon to wreak -- that are otherwise in tension with ideal long-term planning.  I love that players can control the rate at which species enter the board, providing a Euro-like resource management throttle that is particularly effective because of the game’s length.  

For our learning game (with 5 players) we randomly removed 10 of the cards from the deck. It didn't seem to have a negative effect on the game's balance (we kept the Amphibians out).  But the resulting game, though still fun, was less epic than it should have been. I wouldn't play that way on a regular basis (I would compare it to Le Havre's short game, which I've come to enjoy less and less over time).  We all agreed that the game would be much better at full length with additional strategies to develop and a wider variety of actions to take.  Additionally, the game is so gripping that it's hard for me to ever view additional length as a negative.  We all lamented seeing the Ice Age card come out, even after 3 hours.  It's a bit like having the SuperBowl go into double overtime -- no one is mad that they have to watch [i]more[/i] great football.

There are already a lot of threads on the artwork and components, so I’ll just briefly mention that I really, genuinely like the aesthetic of the game.  I dig the clean, simple, and understated look, and it was a [i]selling point[/i] of the game for me.  I also tend to think that (1) too many games are made worse by their attempts at art, and (2) the increasing emphasis on game appearance is eroding the appreciation for a strong link between mechanics and theme (replaced by an appreciation for a strong link between artwork and theme). 

To the extent that anyone is worried about this, I can attest that the game looks professionally produced in person. No one will laugh at you at game night for bringing a homemade game (and this is coming from someone who owns several small publisher games that he won't bring to game night for fear of being laughed at :blush: ). The photos here are accurate with respect to the colors and artwork, but the components certainly do not look cheap on the table.

Other than [thread=538033]Cavum[/thread], which eventually became my idiosyncratic 10 (we all have one, don’t we?), no game has jumped so quickly to the top of my personal rankings.  I hope I can get it to the table with much more frequency going forward, as right now it’s really the only game I want to play (it may have even ruined Essen for me).  Dominant Species is a special game.  It’s certainly not right for those whose ideal game is a 60-90 minute straightforward Euro with predictable mechanics, streamlined gameplay, and animeeples.  It is long, complex, tense, and confrontational.  Because of all that, it is also ultimately rewarding in a way that few games can manage.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I love who everything is interconnected. All the possible actions are all inter-related, making the potential combinations of actions you can take huge. Actions X, Y, Z will combine to create huge effect A, or you could take actions P, Q, R to make huge effect B, and the list goes on.

This game melted my brain. Seriously, I have to take a break half way through to stretch my legs and eat. Especially eat, I burned up a lot of energy playing this game.

The sheer power of some moves was impressive to witness. Often times this is the Dominance cards (like Catastrophe), but sometimes it's an impressive move like a double Wanderlust for 13 points and two territories that only you can enter. Or a well-timed and well-placed Glaciation.

It includes moves for a short-term goals, but also for long-term goals, particularly the goal of being well-placed for the final turn, because coming back on the last turn is definitely possible as long as you've set yourself up for it.

Which is one of the game's two biggest flaws. The last turn is too important, things can happen in the last turn that can make the rest if the game seem irrelevant.

The other huge flaw is just how complicated thus game is. There are so many concepts that need to be learnt before you can even start playing. Not an easy game to get to the table. The length doesn't help either.

While I love the look of this game, I want to draw particular attention to the ebb and flow of the two-player game. The Dominance markers flow back and forth across the land like a rising and falling tide during the game. It is very aesthetically pleasing to watch.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3.5
Some people like purely tactical games that take 1+ hour per player...I just don't.  There is not enough time in life to play a game like this.  I need a game with some sort of arc.  I hate games that are long and include one or many of the following things:

1. A player can be eliminated from the start by some conniving player.
2. A person who has no chance of winning decides the fate of the other players (kingmaker).
3. You have effectively no expectations of what other players are doing because there is no strategy.
4. Games that feed AP instead of introducing mechanics to defeat it.
5. Games where the person who has the least done to them wins.

This game has parts of all 5 of these. And I'm sorry, but the worker placement game is neither new or interesting, especially when you have 1 action that is far and away better than the others that will, due to needing another action to change turn order, go more often to a single player at the table.  The cards are so imbalanced and random, that they decide the game, and they are only marginally associated with an AP placement!  Of course, the rest of the table will counteract a high score by bashing that player to smithereens...so maybe you should turtle and hope to win in final scoring...wait, how is this fun again?  Not to mention, the pieces just make this a fiddly mess.

If you like shitty games like El Grande, Eclipse, and Age of Steam, you will probably like this one...just strap in and watch the 4 hour snorefest that you have no control over.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Unbelievably good.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
[b]First edition copy with the improved tiles from the 2nd printing.[/b]

[i]NOTE: to responsibly shorten the game, remove the cards: Intelligence, Parasitism, Omnivore, and Immigrants[/i]

My first play of Dominant Species was easily the most excited I've felt after a game in a long time. It is also one of the few, rare games that justifies the approx. 4 hour playing time. I gotta imagine playing time gets better with familiarity, but there's so much to think about and the available actions are so many, that every game is going to take quite some time to get through.

What's to like? It's area control and worker placement... two things I like very much because it keeps everyone involved. Despite the "spartan" appearance of simple tiles and wooden cubes, this is also one of the most thematic games I've played in a while as well. It just goes to show that theme is not always in the "glitz" of components but is ideally reinforced by the game's actual mechanics. Dominant Species has theme in spades...

I had read a comment somewhere that asked essentially, "What does DS do that El Grande doesn't already?" There's an easy answer to that question in my mind: glaciation. The gradual creep of the glacier keeps everyone on their toes, forces tough choices, and generally provides an overall storyline to the game. It also shakes things up and provides opportunities (particularly via "survival") for someone to get back into the game. For so many moving parts, I'm shocked at how well everything fits together.

This is a wonderful game, and also possibly the heaviest game I own. I can only hope that I get to play this with some regularity. Based on the enthusiastic response it's getting from others, I think that might actually be possible.

There's only a few nitpicks with this game--I already mentioned the length, and for those prone to AP, the pacing of the game can really drag. Also, if an extra action pawn card pops up in the first row of the game, it gives the starting player an easy grab for a significant advantage that will last all game. The easy remedy for both is to eliminate a few cards from the deck and also ensure those extra pawn cards are not in the first batch.

Random comment: for 1st edition owners, the thicker tile set is worth it... slightly. They do make picking up elements and tiles much easier. It's probably not worth $20, but if you can get it cheaper, do it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.25
£40
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I really liked the game and even though it was long it didn't feel as long as it was. The biggest problem for me was that the element draws each round were random and very few seeds came out early in the game to help me as birds while my opponents had most of their other elements come out and were able to specialize rather quickly. For such a long game this randomness hurt the game for me a bit.

I also found tundra to be very important and probably want to focus on more in terms of getting the survival card each round, which is something I stayed away from in the first game. 

Really the only thing that bugged me about this game, and the primary reason for the rating, is the calculation for domination. While it makes sense, I found it very fiddly in the fact that it happened constantly throughout the game round as tokens were placed or species were moved around. I feel like if this would only happen at a specific point in the game, like everything else, it would speed up the game tremendously.

The leader (Insect) had about 30/40 species eliminated, was a veteran and wanted to end the game soon as he was not going to be able to come back.  Result: He leapfrogged far into the lead at the end game scoring.

So no, I don't think the playtesting managed to get a relevant scoring system into the game.  Too much last-second bonuses that minimize the gameplay during the game.

RATING: 6
