=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Area control where points are being spit at you from every which way. Glaciation, wanderlust, domination, survival, certain dominance cards, and, in the end-game, dominance scoring and tile scoring. The profusion of points is, in some ways baffling, and in some ways makes the game work; there are always second, third, and fourth best options if things don't go as you planned. And they won't go as you planned because the player-induced chaos of the action pawn system is quite astounding.

What is left is a game that pushes you to make educated decisions about what people (including yourself) should do to score the most points, then manage to that goal, but be flexible. The grand bonanza of points at the end seems to force a more strategic approach than is would otherwise be required of the very tactical battle for round-to-round points. This mostly resolves a gripe that I have about games with such fine-grained scoring. [Note: I'm a soccer fan. I love the massive shifts of a game's texture based on a single score. Basketball bores me no end as it is a relentless drumbeat of relatively meaningless scoring increments. How can you get excited about a game where the best you can do at any point is the score 3% of your final score?]

Flexibility is not just necessary when all the pawns are down, however. As animals claim their spots, they are tipping their hand to what their plans are. One can then react accordingly and rejigger the hypothesis of round outcomes, always with an eye to folks that might impede a critical aspect of one's plan and another one to see if better (or other, perhaps smaller but non-exclusive) opporunities are surfacing.

A typical gripe I have with multi-player spatial control games is that success tends to depend on the perceptions of one's immediate neighbors (e.g. Antike). And, often, once committed spatially, your ability to change the dynamic is very limited. DS, by contrast, allows for a great deal of flexibility as you can speciate pretty much anywhere. Of course, you'll typically want to speciate around an element you have, but it certainly gives you flexibility to get in and out of positions.

I am very much on the fence about this game. On the one hand, it is outside of my comfort zone for length, for the sheer number of moving parts, and for the fineness of the scoring. On the other hand, I really appreciate what it does in creating a highly complex machine where anticipating your opponents is difficult, doable, and rewarding. It offers coattails to spot and ride, threats to make and follow-through on, threats to respond to - either preemptively or reactively - with a rich array of fight or flight tools, and generally a very good balance between managing the immediate, medium, and long-term threats and opportunities. In the end, it'll start at a 7 - better than Brass and Die Macher, but flawed with regard to my personal predilictions to land much higher.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Great game, but I often find myself reluctant to play it when it is suggested.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
A fairly straight forward but surprisingly well detailed and designed action draughting game with a large but constant-length queue depth (unlike Caylus where the queue grows as more buildings come out).  Like all action draughting games (worker placement, a silly term), it is just an iterative trade-off between opportunity cost and prioritisation.  I find nothing inherently interesting there other than the implied negotiation (moves as offers) that comes along with most area-plurality games.  The decision spaces are a wee bit too long to be easily called tactical, but also far too short to be called strategic.  Figure 1.5-2 turns, with most sitting at the 1.5 end.  A game of layering small 1+ish turn vignettes.

In character this is an action draughting area-plurality game done as viewed by a classical wargam designer -- which is a rather charming combination.  The gross acceptance of randomness, which one assumes comes from the wargame franchise, is troubling.  The random Domination card draws are one thing, but much larger is the random chit pulls for elements.  Together they kill any ability for more than trivial forward planning and thus remove most of any interest I may have in the game -- which is not to say I had much to start with.  I could easily see value in a variant in which the elements and cards are pulled one round in advance (current turn plus next turn).  

In summary: A prettily rendered, well designed, tactical action draughting area-pluralty wargame with a deep constant queue that has few reasons for interest beyond charm, but it is unusually charming.  Currently rated at 6.0 (and edging onto 6.5).  Likely to fall to 5.5 as the charm wears off.

UPDATED RATING: 6.5. The charm is winning for now, but this is clearly a game which one fails to lose rather than a game one wins.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
:coffee: My ongoing pained relationship with this title has a lot to do with the fact that I recognize the show-stopping brilliance of the design but have not, historically, had much fun actually playing the thing. I'm coming around a bit on the latter point -- DS is, if nothing else, a very well-designed abstract puzzle-game that hits notes I like with regard to a minimal role for dumb luck and a whole buttload of player interaction, and playing with four players as opposed to six took some of the chaos, ratcheting it down to "heavy brain burn" from "convoluted to the point of pain."

But in the end I keep thinking I'd rather play Agricola (etc.) if I want crunchy heavy worker placement and I'd rather play the COIN series games if I want Euro-influenced multi-player conflict simulation...

RATING: 7
This is an interesting design with an interesting (though non-narrative) theme.

At it's core, this is a swingy multi-tiered area control game, heavier on tactics and lighter on strategy but there is something about it that is so engrossing.  It may be how it blends the worker placement mechanism to influence the area control aspects.  It may be how the limited actions constrain your choices.  I think it is most likely trying to manage the ebb and flow of your progress in the game.  I enjoy games with strong timing aspects, and you must manage events to do well in Dominant Species.

RATING: 8.7
This is one of the better worker placement games, although I'd rather remove the point scoring system. I like that dominance outdoes population during the game, but at the end the true winner should be the most prolific animal. Getting points is sort of a theme breaker for me. Still a great game as is though. Also, this game works best at three or four players. The initiative order is VERY important, and almost impossible for someone to move from space six to near the top over the course of the game with only one spot available. Especially because it allows you to select another option with the same pawn after performing initiative.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Likes: The elements mechanic; this isn't just a area control game with just whoever has the most pieces in an area scores best in that area, because the fact that animals have to also balance their spread with matching of elements make this a very interesting game. It is worker placement in a way, but the game doesn't focus on getting more workers like others in the genre; any extra workers have diminishing returns as some spots just aren't as strong and the game really only rewards a couple at most. Oh and the theme is awesome.

Dislikes: Game length can be a turn off for some. Also, the blue and green bits are close enough in color that one can get them confused in bad lighting.

RATING: 10
On 2 January, 2014.

Dominant Species (3rd edition) was our pick for Christmas. I had high expectations towards the game and I really looked forward to get it.
My first impressions are really good. The game is great, plays well and it's fast. I have a similar feeling like in the case of Caylus as far as the rules are inherent part of the game. Everything works properly and oiled and I really like this. The rules are exceptionally easy to learn and teach. Dominant Species has an inherent logic that not only fits well to the theme but also is understandable and natural. Nothing feels forced or out-of-the-theme. Concerning the evolution and struggle of animal classes, the theme is cool and unique and feels great. It really gives an unique experience and doesn't feel pasted on. 
The quality of the components is over the top. I really like these wooden cones and cubes and all the others. The artwork on the cards is just amazing! Being my first game by GMT Games I really appreciate the effort they have taken to produce this game.

RATING: 7.5
Received on Prize Table @ Great Lakes Games 11/06/2010
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Amazing simulation of how species have evolved in time. The mechanics are perfectly uniformed on ecologists concepts of the "Speciation" and "Domination", so you can really approach the game as you will probably do with the real study. It's quite complex manage all the things you can do to be the dominant one, but the rules are quite easy to understand and in few turns you have only to think about your best strategy to dominate. The game takes up to 4 hours (sometimes 5) to get to the end, after that it leaves you a nice sensation of an evolving world where different species have just rushed to survive better than the others one. It's enjoyable also in less players than six, so if you to have a play with a single friends in a face-to-face conflict, you can do it without lose the depth of the game system. Unfortunately, it is out of printing right now and it's really hard to find one out in every board game shops, but we hope that somene, sometimes will reprint it for us (maybe with some modifications inside in grafics and rules). Until then, the lucky that own the game, hope enjoy it with their friends!

RATING: 4
Egy játék után azt mondom:
- nagyon ütős, hogy minden mindennel összefügg
- nagyon elveszi a kedvem tőle, hogy minden kör első fele a stratégia kitalálásáról szól, a másik fele meg taktikázásról, ami teljesen átüti az addigi stratégiai gondolatmenetet. Sokszor azt éreztem, az akcióválasztásnál elég lenne véletlenszerűen (pl. kockadobással) felpakolni, a lényeg rész úgyis a taktikai, akcióvégrehajtásos résznél van.

Szóval hatalmas fantázia rejlik a játékban, de valahol félresiklott a dolog...

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Update: 
10->9. Sorry Dominant Species, I only have room for one 10 boardgame rating, and Terra Mystica is now it. We're still friends, right?
------------
My 10 rating refers to exactly 4 players, and with the semi-official variant of not using the Domination cards that grant extra AP. Any deviation from that and the rating goes down.
-------------
Update after 6-8 plays:
Yeah, this is it. Rating -> 10. Yes, it's 4 hours, yes it has luck and lots of chaos, and even kingmaking (oh the horror). And yet it's my highest rated boardgame. The decisions are just that interesting, competition that tight, and overall that engaging. And fun! Each game can unfold in entirely new ways. In our last game we had a tundra front that essentially became impenetrable, with the other side getting virtually all of the new land tiles until that side of the board was completely full, and the majority of animal populations thus on the opposite side of the board of the tundra front (and open spaces). Amazing. The assymmetry of players and the randomness of the elements and cards guarantees a fresh game every time. But there are [i]enough[/i] random events that I don't feel the randomness overbears on a game, even at this length. And the random events are never specifically targeted at a single player, which I like. Thus it's not as directly impactful to individual players as say Die Macher. This is my first boardgame 10, joining my only other 10: Tichu.
--------
Wow. I've never had such a favorable impression of a game just from reading the rules. This game hits all the right buttons for me. I generally like worker placement, and this is no exception. I really like how your worker doesn't specify exactly what's going to happen (for almost all positions), so you can't really do all the calculations of what will happen. It does have a fair bit of "choose who you hose", but more often than not there's some impact to you, rather than being totally arbitrary. Thematically and mechanically it all comes together beautifully. For bonus points, downtime is extremely low.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Bought this in London. Heavy game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Downside? Mechanically complex, and very long playing time.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Putting Dominant Species on my want to play-list was a bit of a risky undertaking: it is a long game, and I had no idea whether I would like it or not. I knew only vaguely what it was about... only that it had shot up in the rankings and was spoken of very fondly by many.

After having played this beast, I think my attitude is on the warmer side of lukewarm. My main beef is that you do a lot on a rather small area of the board, making matters a tad fiddly; but far worse, you guesstiplanimate a lot of things in advance, then have to play somewhat reactively to adapt, and then a whole lot of controlled or semi-randomly controlled Bad News rolls over the playing area, shaking things up considerably in the process. That is in itself not so bad, but I think that this game could easily take an hour or so less, and still be satisfying. (I gather that there's an author-endorsed variant to remove the cards from play which would remove their swings of fortune as well as shorten the game.) In the end though, I was wondering what the long-term appeal of this game is supposed to be. It is rich in conflict, and the game clearly expects targetted extermination of species by the other species in order to prevent people from walking away with the game. That, in effect, turns DS into a game of pretending you're not in the lead, running away to hidey-holes, and then preparing for a big push near the end. Sound familiar? It should: It's called 'Power Grid'. This game is played in half the time, and follows exactly the same scheme, but then without conflict.

I find it interesting to speculate on the game's exceedingly high position on the ranking list. Spot #17 (at the time of writing) basically puts it at 'the best money can get'. I'm not sure that's warranted, really; and it cannot be denied that the game's origin (with a P750-scheme) gave it an extremely strong push forward: people pre-ordering a GMT game are not exactly run-of-the-mill customers. I think that, all things considered, DS should be ranked somewhat lower: it is, in the end, not a very diverse game, and does appear to contain much strategic variety.

I definitely think it was a good idea to try Dominant Species, and it was also definitely easy to get into despite its fearsome long play time. Once you've gone through a turn or two there is little which is unclear or needs to be referenced. But repeat plays... For now I'm curious how the shorter variant would play out; that would definitely help in getting this game to the table more often in the event I would be able to get hold of a copy. I'm going to be generous with my rate for the time being.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
What's not to love? Excellent Design.

Everything is integrated and balanced (over the long game).

Scoring is simple. Based on tile type, majority, then ties broken by food chain order. 

Dominance is great, simple multiplication and addition. Do you score the tile where you're Dominant, but will score less points because there's a really awesome game changing card available? (most likely YES)

If you play with 2 players, definitely control 2 animal types each, for a total of 4 animal types in the game. Then each player will score their lowest for final scoring.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
Wow, grossly misleading rating of this game, Euro fan boys must drive those ratings, a Euroboy's wet dream. A truly overload game that gets bogged down via of second grade math drills, yes simply math, (x*y)+(w*z)+(..*..)+..., yada, yada, yada, over and over and over. You have to know your values and those of other players. 

Expect a play board aka the earth that you will stare at, a lot, like a deer in headlights, expect an AP board where you place your actions that you will stare at, like a deer in the headlights. Expect when taking the action more staring at the play board aka earth more deer in the headlights. You can expect a long play time

Does the above seem like a lot of repeat wordage? You got the feel of this game.

There is just too much bookkeeping to really be truely enjoyable. This is a game best played on a iPad where this burden is removed from the players.

It is somewhat an elegant game where the actions seem "nature", makes sense. The animals seem balance as does overall game play. There is some randomness of cards drawn, elements, tiles, but it is minimum. All information is visible, so very Euro in design rather than German, read where some labeled it American-trash, this isn't true. This thing is just an acquired tasted.

This game is missing some parts.
If you play this thing, buy 10mm or 8mm (same as cube size), dices, about 20 in each animal color, use these on the tiles as dominate count counters. You can then easly see the dominate count of each animal without having to remember or keep asking another player to do the math over and over or doing it in your head. 

This game to me is unplayable without this. These are values that drive the game, it is obscene to think that someone would enjoy needlessly recalculating this and this info isn't recorded on each occupied tile. This should help reduce the play time via of some of the 750-850 calculations and recalculations required to play it. Do not play this with 6 players, 4 would be the maximum.

You have been warned.

This game and Caverna are the reasons I stopped watching Dice Towers.

RATING: N/A
2012 Secret Santa
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This game really does have it all - deep strategy, tension, integrated theme, attractive components...wow.  It's nearly perfect, and is truly a gamer's game.

I say NEARLY, because to me it's a bit too long for its own good.  I would love to see a variant that tightens the game up a bit - perhaps reducing the number of dominance cards based on the number of players.  At the current length it becomes easy to tune out while other players are locked in analysis paralysis.  We also have a small complaint about the cones - they look very cool, but are hard to pick up and move!  If this was consistently a 3 hour game and I could get a grip on those cones, it would be a perfect 10 to me.

That being said, this is a triumph for designer Chad Jensen, and especially to GMT, which picked a sleek minimalist look and an incredibly well-written set of rules.  Game of the year, indeed.

RATING: 9
Thus far (two plays), this game appears to be exactly what I'd hoped it would be from reading the rules/reviews.[1] The play-length is nothing to sneeze at, but it's way shorter than (eg) Twilight Imperium or Age of Renaissance. The abstract presentation works well, though I wouldn't mind slightly more detailed /interesting terrain tile designs. My 5-player game wasn't as engaging as my 4-player game; I'm not sure how much of this was due to increased play-time and how much was due to intrinsic changes in the way the game plays with more people.

[1] = a strategic-and-tactical game with mostly-orthogonal competitions of "area control" (who has the [b]most presence[/b]) and "area fitness" (who is [b]best suited[/b]) taking place simultaneously, along with a strong scoring/advantage mechanism which rewards [b]both[/b] victors in a given area at the same time (though in different ways), plus dynamic board (for purposes of both competitions), dynamic fitness criteria for each player, and some other stuff which fits the theme nicely.

RATING: 7
Not a bad worker-placement game.  I like the different species fighting for multiple scoring opportunities and the action decisions are numerous and, for the most part, important.  It runs a little long for what it offers and the randomness of some of the chit pulls can really hurt a given player, making it a little frustrating for some from time-to-time.  But it is a good game to get on the table with a 4-player group to have some fun.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This game, is what Age of Empire  should have been. As always, area majority is not one of my favorite mechanic, but that's only one of the mechanic. The other is worker placement which I love, and so many other little things. There are so many clever ways to play, so many little things to track by your brain. Experience will clearly helps you to guess/prevent/piggyback your opponent moves. Beautiful mechanism.

Unfortunately while the theme feels wonderful at first game, it becomes less recognized and more about mechanic. Since it's area majority, so mostly it's about move/remove pieces, and such. Opponents play WILL affect you, good or bad. Having said that, this game is really brain burning (a big plus for me!) and take quite long (doesn't matter for me). So while it's a good game, it's not for newbie for sure.

RATING: 10
An absolutely epic worker placement/area control conflict game.  Totally engrossing start to finish, and way too much fun.  My wife is obsessed, we have played 4 games in less than a week and I am not complaining at all.

This game is really special in that while maintaining worker placement for action selection, player interaction is ramped up to 11.  Absolutely every move another player makes has dire repercussions and could spell gruesome loss for you and your animals.  

There is a lot to keep track of, but it all feels pretty natural (aside from overlooking the odd endangered species mid turn).  

Best with all 6, plays in less than 3hrs with experiencerd tables.

RATING: 9
Thoroughly engaging and immersive. Some of the cards can be over-powered, but in different ways depending on the game and who chooses them. While I appreciate the 'open information' (I'm looking at YOU Age of Empires III and the hidden natives), and the ability to 'count down' to the end game (which like Power Grid) can see huge lead and momentum swings, the chaos factor works both ways. It ensures replayability, but keeps it from being a true 9-10 for me (that and the 4-5 hour play time). Still a very good game that I currently look forward to each play.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
A heavy, long brainburner. Requires a few plays to fully appreciate. On first play it will seem extremely chaotic and unbalanced due to the cards. The key in this game is to plan carefully (because you have to assign all your action pawns before you see the results of your actions, which means you have to take lots of things into account) and check out the cards before planning your moves (their effects can be really powerful, so you really need to prepare for them). The game won't work if you just put your pawns here and there hoping for the best. This works with games that have less player interaction, but not in Dominant Species. I love this game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I think I've yet to play a game that churns my brain as hard as Dominant Species does. There is no hidden information. Every decision is calculable, even if most are prohibitively complex. The board is a delicate ecosystem that can tip in any direction at any moment. Players live in fear of what cards will emerge. Spiders out-think monkeys. Sweat drips onto player aides.

But I like that feeling. Maybe not all the time but I do like it. Sometimes my brain needs a good ass-kicking. Sometimes I need to be made aware, even if painfully, that, on average, I only use 10% of my brain. No game is as good at achieving that as Dominant Species. It is in a class of its own.

But: it's a long game, especially with six players, which is where it's at its best. It's not only long--it feels long. And it would be irresponsible to fail to mention that not all friendships can withstand this game. You've been warned.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
This game is simply too long because (1) it induces hilarious amounts of analysis-paralysis (AP), and (2) it is designed to be long.

(1) I know that there are some badasses out there who really can continue to effectively evaluate different placement options hour after hour, but I am not one of them. In this game, every worker placement action has you thinking about species-elements, resources, domination, wasteland, depletion, dominance cards, the point track, food chain order, tundra expansion, penguin scoring, tile type, migration, pawn execution order, speciation opportunities plus all the other stuff I forgot.

After 2 hours of this brain-burning, I just throw up my hands and utter a vulgarity. I like giving my brain a workout, but this game truly induces magnitudes more AP than Caylus, Agricola or Puerto Rico.  Those require thought, and a little AP now and then, but they are still manageable for normal people.      

(2) The 180 minute playtime is a minimum, not an average.  Why is the game so long?  There are 2 big reasons (beyond the AP discussed above): First, certain players will get more actions as the game progresses. (sidenote: this benefit is unbalanced).  More actions mean more playtime.  Second, you end the game by getting through the domination-card deck, but only a maximum of 5 domination cards will be taken each round. There are lots of those cards.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Solid and interesting worker placement game. Competing species is a fun theme. The event cards are extremely powerful, and we jokingly call them 'magic super spells'.

The problem with this game is the length. With turn order changing each turn, reminding people whose turn it is takes a remarkable amount of time. This length problem is compounded by the complete perfect information of the game. To play optimally you MUST plan out your entire turn, and the turn of others ahead of time.

The food chain that breaks ties is a neat idea, except that there are so many exceptions to it it's an unnecessary addition.

The game is also confusing in that each tile has 2 owners: the dominant species, and the most numerous species. A shame this complicates the scoring so much.

Although most of this review is talking about the problems with the game, it's still a good game.

Tl:dr solid mechanics and fun theme unfortunately can't justify the game's length. Would love a shorter version of this.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
Plays: 5+

I don't play many games that can run 3+ hours, but this one is so very worth it.  The gameplay revolves around incredibly powerful cards that can cause huge swings.  There is an incredibly clever mechanism where your species (and the earth) evolve allowing you to spread further, or forcing you to withdraw.  There is very little direct conflict (though there is some), but it is definitely highly competitive and interactive.  One of my favorite games.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
I actually think Dominant Species is a fairly brilliant game, but it plays a bit too long and I feel like the end-game scoring feels really chaotic.  So many of your points come in at the end of the game that it can almost feel like it trivializes everything else that has happened up to that point.  That feeling could very well go away with more familiarity with the game, but I found it to be a little bit of a turnoff.

Still, everything that happens in the game is pretty cool.  Seems to be best with two or three.

RATING: 2
I really disliked this game.
It was a 6 player game. Turns took forever, and I didn't care about everyone's moves since once it got to my turn again the board will be upside down so my plan would have to be though of again at the beginning of my turn anyway. The Dominance cards made the game to swingy and even more random.

That is the thing, the game was way too chaotic, and for something of this length (5 hours) I expect more control over the game.

Art is disappointing, I expected some cool animals in there. The mechanics are interesting though,

Everyone at the table kept saying that there was strategy, hidden underneath you just need to look for it. I kept saying it was so random I will just think of what to do when my turn came and don't worry about the next turn since there was no way to remotely predict what was going to happen next....I won.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
It tells an interesting story, I think, about how we might view the concept of evolution, or even also diversity, when you look at it, that all the different animal classes in this game are considered to have equal odds of winning, you know? And not only that, but that, also, we use the same pieces to represent all the varied animals here. Diversity, evolution, both of them perhaps mean little to nothing compared to tactics, strategy, and seizing of and adapting to opportunities and changes.
"You know there are no green mammals. So, I think, it says something fascinating about the player who insists on playing for the mammals and using the green pieces."
The game, unfortunately, produces too much deep, analytical and time-consuming thought for it to be brought out much.
"You almost never see it -- much like you never see a green mammal."
Though, I will say, with the quality of different Euro mechanisms going on here, I would love to spend all day putting out a play of this.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6.5
Rating based on one play. Very long playing time, analysis-paralisis and the definite possibility of one player far overcoming the others in the point track to the extreme of knowing who will win even hours before the end brings my rating down. I find it a bit boring that you can pretty much predict when the game is going to end, since the glaciation card will always be the last. Also a dinosaur on the cover of an ice age game? The artwork could be better too. Some cards seem like obvious choices, while the rest are too situational or plain underpowered.

I would greatly enjoy coming across a game that more accurately portrays the realities of population dynamics and genetics while staying playable, and this game didn't quite tick it for me in this sense either.

Those are the things I didn't about the game, but as a whole I enjoyed the experience, I like the theme and I think the game has its merits, making you feel how your species exploit new areas, compete for resources and dominance and strive to get away from the ever growing tundra...

RATING: 5
I generally like heavier games.  However this one just has way too much "stuff" going on (half of the time, you're paying attention to the elements surrounding the tiles, the other half of the time, you're minding the majority of cubes on a tile).  I should count up all the different actions one can take on a given turn (rough estimate is near 30!).  It encourages AP, and I find myself just not caring much and just going with my gut when making decisions in the game (but, that's not the way to win).  It's tedious to constantly have to calculate dominance on each tile throughout the game. The game has too much chaos in that the game state can change so rapidly and dramatically that it's difficult to plan anything.  On top of that, it's fiddly with cheap components.  Specifically, the tiles are very thin--almost prototype quality (which I could easily overlook if the game were great).  It's a game that I respect the designer for, but is just too much for me.  As for area majority, I'd rather play 2 or 3 games of El Grande in that duration.  Or with 5 players and 4 hours, give me Die Macher.

RATING: 10
It's a very dense game, but I think most of it is in the strategy; anyone with even a little bit of ecology knowledge would likely find most of the actions and flow of the game fairly intuitive and I think helps the theme to really shine through. It is by nature a very mean game, since a lot of the time you're just trying to kill everyone else off in the quickest most damaging ways. You're constantly having to formulate some plan, and reformulate it when someone takes the action you wanted from underneath of you, or maybe does something that makes you taking a certain action useless.

It can, however, get really mathy having to check dominance in each area all the time.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.8
[October 2016 - 9.8]
It's like El Grande on steroids with a lot more to think about, but so, so good when you settle in.

[December 2015 - 9.3]
I really enjoy this game for both its simplicity and complexity. Plus, as many have stated, it's a wonderful balance of a Euro with interaction and conflict.

Simplicity: As my friend likes to say "the game runs itself" with the action tree on the board -- only dependent on which actions players choose. Then, the order of play and actions themselves are largely all taken care of.

Complexity: There's a lot of keep track of and a boatload of strategies to win -- a lot dependent on what your opponents do. In this sense, it reminds me of another one of my favorites, Hansa Teutonica. The area control aspect of the game -- species count vs dominance -- reminds me of Tammany Hall, where there are really a couple of battles being waged with the same pieces. I also enjoy the side battle for the tundra and the bonus points.  

There is great propensity for 'analysis paralysis,' but my tip is to 1)Focus on the current round 2)Think about a few places you can score -- both on your tiles and an opponent's tiles. Another way to speed up gameplay is to use dice (20d are best) to signify the dominance score of the leader on each tile. That saves constant re-counting and remembering who's in the lead on which tiles.

My only gripe might be that the cards are pretty over powerful. I see that there are 'no-card variants' so others must agree. Because of this, it's pretty crucial to be early in the dominance scoring and therefore crucial to be earlier in the initiative order. However, I'm sure there ways to balance things out, and the group needs to be aware of keeping leaders in check. However, don't focus too much on the current leader, focus on who's charging to lead the next round -- typically the controller of the tundra or the person who has two action pawns in the dominance scoring.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
The implications of decisions one makes in this game are deep. This is a brain burner, and I'm often exhausted afterwards. But we love it.

RATING: 3
This game has one of the most unintuitive rule sets I've ever come across. A huge portion of the game is collectively trying to determine who has dominance in each region and making sure nothing is being done incorrectly.  Very few games make me feel more like an accountant at work during tax season. I'm befuddled at how this could be rated so high.  Thousands of games exist that provide the same amount of depth but with more intuitive rules (and less of them).

If you enjoy games where getting better is largely about figuring out how the rules work, then this is your game!  You're in the majority here of the BGG so take my personal opinion with a grain of salt. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8.5
An epic game on an epic topic. Only played one 6-player games so far, so the rating may udge around a bit.

Lots to do and think about so a little bit overwhelming for the first half of the first game trying to see how the actions and mechanics all fitted together to give VP's. The mechanics implement the theme quite well although the cubes are a little bit abstract to do so in this regard - some plastic animals woudl have been cool.

Game length is a slight concern to the extent that I can't see this making the table with anyone other than 'gamers' but still a great game.

Interested to see what I feel about this when I play it again as since my one play of this I have grown a bit weary of the really tight worker-placement type games.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Played our first session of Dominant Species on Saturday - five players - all experienced Eurogamers - two of us are also long time grognards.

The game is well designed, the rules are clear, well laid out and quite intuitive. The in-game decisions are challenging and tough as you try and weigh long-term benefits against short term gain.

I didn't expect this to be a great game but as a supporter of both GMT and Chad/Kai (Combat Commander is one of my top 5 games of all time) I thought I'd P500 it to "support the team". Although it is a good game it is too long. The "sweet spot" timing-wise for Eurogames is about 60-90 minutes for a 4-5 player game, in my opinion. It takes a real game design genius to engage all the players for 60-90 minutes - only God could design a game which keeps everyone fully engaged for 3-4 hours! Although Chad is semi-divine, I don't think you've pulled it off here...

As soon as our game was over, a couple of the players said they would play again if we shortened the game by doing something like the following:

Remove 5 Dominance Cards

Shuffle the Ice Age card into the bottom 5 (or 10!) cards.

This would of course make the game quite a bit shorter at the cost of impairing long term strategy, but in these players opinion, the game isn't worth 3-4 hours effort for the fun returned.

I offer this honest assessment of our group, who has played just about every Eurogame produced since 1998, in a positive constructive way. If this were a 90 minute game I would give it a 9 (excellent) rating on Boardgamegeek. As it stands, I give it a 7 (good).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
This is a game that I feel I should really love or really hate.  Somehow it falls in between.  It's a lot like El Grande but with more mechanisms and variables to limit where, how, and why you would choose a region to take area majority.  Unfortunately, with so many variables and mechanisms, it is not at all clear what will be the repercussions of everyone's move.  So you kind of hope for the best and see how much you screw or get screwed over.  It's a long game though..that cannot be denied.  There are simply too many options to think it all through.  And really you have to think it through or get butchered by careless mistakes.  There can be some serious AP here.  But that aside, it's a good game...I like the mechanisms they've chosen to constrain actions.

Update - dropping this from 7 to 6 and could drop further.  Just not my type of game any longer.  Too much "take that".
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Dominant Species was quite a surprise for me. I had not played a Chad Jensen game before, and was only knew him as a war game designer, so it was only vaguely on my radar. On a whim I read the rules for the game and was floored for two reasons: First of all, the rules were among the best I had ever seen, and secondly because of the clarity of the rules I was easily able to tell this was going to be a great game.

[ImageID=805598]

I pre-ordered it immediately, and when it showed up the following week I made sure to get it on to the table ASAP. The night after my first play, I went home and wrote a review ([thread=561327][/thread]). Since then I have played the game eight times, it was my most played game of the month, and each of these plays has only reinforced my opinion that this game is a masterpiece, a game that combines a number of disparate elements together in such a way that those who can appreciate heavier, more complex and interactive games will not help but be impressed by the design. This game alone was enough to turn my opinion of this year’s games around; if it was the lone good heavy design this year I would consider this a great year for games, the strong crop that looks like it is coming out of Essen has merely reinforced that opinion. 

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Players are trying to gain victory points on an ever-changing ancient earth.  Players play a class of animal (reptiles, arachnids, etc) and try to propagate their animal species across the hex tile representation of earth.  Habitat chits exist on the hex vertices, and you need matches with your animal mat to ensure ongoing survival in a adjoining hex.   Players take actions to manipulate the earth, the habitat chits and their species to try and earn majorities, and hopefully gain access to the enormously powerful Domination cards.  Rock solid worker placement/area majorities game - at it's heart a pretty theme-less Euro cube-pusher with area majority scoring, however it's been dressed up nicely with some nice scientific terms which disguises the bland theming underneath.  Enjoyable, and very well presented.  Great set of rules - you get the impression a lot of time went into testing and getting this right.  I'm not totally convinced the 3-4 hour playtime is right for this type of game (I'd rather play Die Macher if I had time for a long Euro).  If you play with a ruthless group who pounce on weakness, you may be in for a miserable time.  Other than that, if you don't mind the playtime, go for it.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 4
In essence this is an overly-long and heavily-themed variant of El Grande. As the glaciers expand, species move into uninhabited biomes and compete for survival. Decent, but very chaotic and features the "I took that action so now you can't" mechanism that has been overplayed since Wallace games and Caylus were all the rage. Still, better than most of the genre but it's a genre I'm not inclined towards.

RATING: 10
Very cool game, which no one wants to play with me. Other than it's length, the reasons for this are unclear to me. This game is almost perfect. Everything is interconnected and matches the theme perfectly. Every decision you make influences the balance of the ecosystem, which is about to establish on the game-board. The ever-present struggle for dominance and fighting off extinction, with on-crawling glaciers which turn your precious habitat into tundra, every aspect of this game oozes theme and complex awesomeness. My only complain about this masterpiece is that the presentation could be a little less dry. All those wooden cubes of abstract shape may scare away potential players. Maybe this game needs some cute little Animal Meeples like Caverna.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Intuitive worker-placement engine which drives the placement of cubes onto hexes for two types of area majority scoring - quantity and quality.   Very thematic implementation, and one of the best rulebooks I've seen in ages, clearly written with tons of examples.   The game is a bit too long, but this can be adjusted by taking out 5 or more random cards before playing.   My one major complaint is that you are constantly needing to calculate and recalculate dominance across all the hexes when elements are added/subtracted from the map or from the player sheets.  It's simple math, but can become a nuisance.  With good players, it's less of a problem.  But as a result, AP-prone players could kill the experience.  The dominance cards are extremely powerful, which will be a criticism of the game for some folks, so you cannot neglect turn order if you are trying to plan ahead.   But it's more of a tactical game anyway, there's not a lot of long term strategic planning.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 4

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I'm not entirely sure why I love Dominant Species so much. I think it's the idea of a swarm of aqua-spiders suddenly infesting the entire ocean and completely exterminating the innocent deep-water lizards. Seriously, you can describe everything that happens in the game as a dramatic change to the ecosystem of this world, and it's hilarious.

Couple this with some great worker placement. Competition for first place ("speed") is deeply valued here for the sheer variety of the actions and how much clever play can benefit you. Correctly dominating, keeping your creature adapted to the world, and freezing the face off opponent species - it's all good stuff.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
I've tried this one a couple times, but don't seem to enjoy it.  First off, it's really long and [i]really[/i] thinky.  Not normally a killer for me, but it is when combined with the second point: it's also really dry and abstract.  Oh, and it can also be punishingly difficult.  This is not a good combination.

Mostly, the design choices in this game rub me the wrong way.  Cubes are removed from the game when game when they die.  Fair enough, the species goes extinct.   But you have a limited pool of cubes to begin with.  What, the genetic diversity of insects is capped at 80?  I think not.
At its core, it's an area majority game, but a 2-tier one.  You have to have the most cubes to get most points, as usual.  But you also need a region where you can achieve 'dominance', defined as having more food sources of your type than anyone else.  This gets into the whole other system the game uses.  One third of the game is really manipulating these food type tokens.  You put them on & off your sheet, on & off the board, and so on..  The procedures for doing so aren't [i]that[/i] arcane, but it's still more complex and multi-step than I'd prefer.  Dominance is also almost entirely separate from regular cube scoring.  As long as you have at least 1 cube there, you're eligible.  
After you're done juggling those, the rest is manipulating cubes and tiles.  Cubes have more procedures as to where they can be placed and removed, and soak up actions to do so.  It really felt to me like it was easier and more profitable to kill off guys than to place yours out.  Once again, the theme falls flat.  When one species establishes a predatory relationship with another, they're not engaging in some xenocidal war.  They're not trying to wipe out all of the prey species: that would deprive them of a food source.  
Anyway, the last part of the game is tiles, and if you take the actions, you have tremendous freedom to shape the board.  It seems to me a little too easy to deploy tiles in a chain and create your own little backyard at the edge of the board, away from the advancing glaciers.  This lets you create a small paradise for your phylum that you can score points for repeatedly.  
Oh, and after all that is the cards.  These can be seriously swingy, and you really have to fight for area dominance and pick order to get them.

Anyway, my training in biology means I like the theme & the idea, and some of the execution, but the rest of it is a big mismatch.  The actual gameplay is way too tedious and fiddly for me to really enjoy playing it.  It's probably a good game, but not one I'm ever going to have fun with.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
4 Plays:

Great game but I can't get it to the table because of the length. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Okay, I'm very surprised at how good the game is. The gameplay is simple yet there are so many tough decisions to make.

The artwork is very bland, almost like a prototype, but people seem to be okay with it.

One problem that I have is the need to constantly check which species belong to which player and also colour. I wish the species are colour specific. 

The event cards seem to be a little swingy. The effect is freaking powerful, often end up in huge blow. 

The fact that the game is playable with six is a huge plus, and the amazing thing is that it shines with that many players. Playing with six will definitely be a long one, however both my six-player games ended at about three-hours long (which is not the usual).

RATING: 8
A long game, easily over three hours, but simple to explain and the flow of play is very natural and it keeps the players constantly involved and thinking. Great theme, I'm a sucker for games about evolution, and I got the third printing which has great looking components. The game can be a little swingy with effects clearing sections of the board and making major changes to the map, but you still feel like you have enough control over the situation to adapt, which after all is the whole point of a game about adaptation.

Not sure how often I'll get to pull this one out because of the length, but it's definitely a game I'd recommend playing if you can.

RATING: 7.88
Highly thematic, card driven, area control strategy game. A thematic euro hybrid almost on the brink of being a simulation of wildlife biosphere. It has teeth and claw (quite literally) and it can take several hours even with 2 and 3 players. I am probably never going to play with 5 or 6. It would be chaos.

[b]Favorite mechanism:[/b] Programmable action track that executes from top to bottom and from left to right when the action phase begins.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Mechanically this is a pretty heavy worker placement style game that could bog down with players that need to calculate every move. Thematically i find it a bit weird that I, the player represent some invisible force deciding how my species group will choose to evolve (is a choice actually involved in this process?). It does follow the basic precepts quite well though, do you want to specialize or be a generalist? The best strategy is to avoid hard competition. In play your going to try and control areas of the board and match icons to stuff on your player mat. Its quite cut throat with some reward cards and some aggressive actions. In some ways it feels like another more complex passing of El Grande given you are trying to cover the board in cubes.

RATING: 8
Finally got to play this and with 6 players to boot.  This is, in no loose terms, an epic game.  I'm sure it plays fine at other player counts and it seems the consensus is 4, but playing with all 6 for the first time made this an unbelievable six-hour journey.  That's probably a player problem, but in defense of the game, it certainly didn't feel like six hours and that's when you know you're completely engaged.

With 3000+ comments on it, there's not much for me to say other than that this is an incredible design.  The only hitch is that without prior plays, forming your strategy and making your opening moves can be a daunting, confusing task.  Not until the game is well under way will you be able to figure out just what you ought to be doing.  The action display keeps everything moving at a decent clip and with so many options available, it's easy to get lost in the movement of its parts and forget about the goal.  Sometimes you just want to do something just because you can, but it can horribly fail you in execution (such was the case when I sacrificed a crapload of birds just to get a few measly points).

RATING: 7
I really enjoyed this game - the components and theme really work and the gameplay is solid. However, I really dislike teaching this game - the number of steps per turn is daunting and trying to help new players understand what they mean and the importance of each step is just impossible. It was a tough decision to let this go, but I did not want to continue teaching this game every time I wanted to play. Lastly, the cards can be gamebreaking if everyone is not aware of what they are capable of. I feel that with experienced players, choosing the first domination slot would be the first move, simply for the benefit of the card.

60-90m, best with 4-5 players. 5+ plays.

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
2014-10-27 : Wonderful worker-placement area-control game where all the mechanics interlock in a beautiful and streamlined way. 

Every round you find yourself in the position where you absolutely, positively have to do 3 things and you only got 2 actions left - that's something I like a lot in a game. Graphics and layout and especially the player board which in essence contains all the rules are great (3rd edition) 

One thing that could use a little clean-up is terminology with regards to the words animal and species and in one or two cases the text on the cards could have used a couple extra words.

Then there's 2 things I don't like about it 

1) The dominance cards are too powerful and feel like they can almost randomly muck-up a perfect play. Toning them down a bit, or a lot in some cases, would improve this game's rating from an 8 to a 9 

2) The tie-breaker rule - why couldn't this have been some player accomplishment like number of domination cones or most species on the board ? Picking food chain feels like a lazy design choice that should have been last in the list of tie-breakers.

RATING: 7
Played a 3-player game with 2 experienced players.  Although they explained and helped, it was a very frustrating experience for me and I didn't do well (no surprise!).  I didn't completely understand why they were doing what they were doing and what I could be doing to score more points and position myself better.  The game feels fast, not long, and a day later I realized that I should have been exploiting my special status as top of the food chain on every round--which I didn't.  I also didn't understand the Glaciation action, or to be exact, how I could use it to my advantage and my opponents' disadvantage.  I also didn't try to get the Survival card which was another option open to me.  All in all, I can't rate or even say if I'd like to play again.  Lots of moving parts--which are interesting, engaging, and move quickly--but require experience to understand how they all flow, mesh, and coordinate, to aid a player in performing well.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Here's how I envision this game's creation. Chad Jensen was sitting around one day eating a Reese's Peanut Butter Cup and he looked over to see a copy of Age of Empires III on top of a copy of Primordial Soup sitting right next to the couch. Or maybe he accidentally box dumped one game into another. You get the reference.  

I may be a prude, but I think tactical and chaotic gamestates have their places. In a worker placement game is not one of those places. I also tend to believe that chaotic games should be shorter in nature. There's so much happening that AP is basically guaranteed, which is again not going to help the length. In a nutshell the game seemed to be of acceptable design. There's nothing really super new or Earth shattering, but Eurogames have established a standard that this is completely acceptable. For me personally, this game was a total miss. What I disliked from AoE III is here in larger numbers, and the take that nature of the action cards was just another nail in the coffin. Many gamers will find an excellent game in this box. I did not. For me it was too chaotic, too long, and too short on ability for strategic planning.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 3
This game is more than merely random. It's arbitrary. And that's not good for a long game. I half suspect the length is the designer's attempt to even out the randomness but it doesn't work because the issue is arbitrariness, not randomness. 

Random chit pulls of elements combined with AP, metagaming and kingmaking makes a poor game. Oh, and it's fiddly too, like to calculate dominance, so much so that there's a rule that dismisses it as a problem.

There's no reason to play this as long as El Grande and Die Macher are available.

RATING: 6.5
Game takes far too long to be worth while imho. Elegant rules, but the well balanced play is overshadowed by the LONG length of game (3 hours for our 5 players) - it's constantly difficult and time consuming to assess dominance on each hex as the game progresses, long bouts of analysis paralysis and a lengthy reset phase at the end of every round really hurt the gameplay.

The board and components are visually amateurish - bad illustrations on the cards, ugly typography and poor visual coding really hurt the visual appeal and make it hard for new players to pick up the mechanics. The box art is fantastic, wish the game components had the same appeal.

That said, it could make a great smart phone/iPad game if a computer was the score keeper and the art was updated.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
No game in my experience provides a higher rate of gut-churning decisions, and if you base the quality of a game on that, then this is one for you.  You will spend a lot of time agonizing over the next decision to make and the one you just made.  I used to think that I didn't like worker placement games, until I played this and realized that this action selection could actually be used in a game with gobs of interactivity.  The best I've played of this type.

It's beautiful to look at, pretty abstract, but hella mean, which helps the hours fly by pretty well (although in a six-player game, it seems almost inevitable that one player will get shafted and wish death on the rest of the game).  The cards are not a luck element - you simply have to manage your position better, or punish other players for not taking the other several actions they needed to take along with that sweet card.  The element draws do seem to be the primary luck issue, although I don't think they are determinative by any means.

There was a brief time when I thought the glaciers were a kludgy catch-up mechanism, but now I think they are grand, and the most strategic part of the game.  Only problems (which prevent me from putting in my all-time favorites) are the enormous difficulties in plotting outcomes in the last turn - making it impossible to make a move you feel good about (and causing terrible AP to those who suffer), and the possibility that the game will start to seem repetitive after several plays.  Whereas each game should present different tactical challenges, I worry that it does not offer strategic variety and is ultimately the same game with players being shunted into the slightly different scoring roles.  Maybe that's no different than any other game, but as marvelously fun as this is, I have some concern that people might play it out.

Having just taught myself Francis Tresham's Revolution: The Dutch Revolt, I see a lot of similarities which helped clarify my feelings about DS.  This game is extremely dynamic compared to Dutch Revolt, while sharing a lot of core ideas.  It is fairly easy to move pieces across the board and into new areas.  This dynamism strikes me as a strength and weakness: Stengths - well dynamic, fun, allows players to easily shift short-term aims, creates lots of tactical opportunism; Weaknesses - difficult to plan ahead too far and a lessening of importance of early game decisions and positions, previously mentioned filtering of players into repeating scoring roles.
  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
This is a game I respect more than I like, quite honestly. The gist of the game is not being able to see what the consequences of your actions will be until they happen. So each turn you’re just doing what seems best and then hoping most (or some) of it will work to your favor. It’s like running an obstacle course in the dark and seeing who gets through best and who gets a two-by-four to the face.  It took me a while to understand that you can’t foresee much so your efforts are more about damage mitigation than opportunism. In fact, being too opportunistic early on just rewards you with a bullseye on your back. 

Personally, I could do with less chaos and less play time. I’m firmly convinced there’s 3 hours of gameplay here “squeezed” into 5-6 hours of time. All the gyrations the players must go through are to see who can earn the right to dominate and thus get to play a really powerful card that’s going to tilt the table vastly in one direction, thus rendering a lot of the previous gyrations null. Then you start the next turn and do it all over again. It feels like the game could be half as long and still render the same experience. 

You repeat the slugfest until you get to the final, critical turn when half the game’s points are at stake, and here’s where you need to be as opportunistic as possible while hopefully relatively insulated from catastrophe. The effort to fight through the game to be in position to win on the last turn feels like a boxing match. It might be 5-6 hours of mental pugilism, but if you can be the one left standing at the end, well, it’s extremely satisfying. I’ll play it on occasion when I feel like putting myself in the ring for the thrill of testing my endurance.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9.75
I love, love, love:
- the theme and asymmetric players
- that it's a nice mix of strategy and tactics
- the mechanism of placing all APs then doing actions
- the many layers of choices involved
- the equal weight on number of species and dominance, so you can't focus entirely on one or the other
- the swings in dominance between players
- the board is gorgeous to look at as the game goes on
- the Domination Cards can really swing things around if played right

I dislike:
- the game can go on a while(?), but fortunately, we usually play two-player and go through the Domination Cards quickly, so the game isn't usually an all-afternoon affair

Final verdict: A game of chess but so, SO much better.

Variant suggestion: Randomly remove 1/4-1/3 of the Domination Cards to decrease play time? Will have to play-test.

RATING: 8
This is a very well designed game. The special abilties of the insects and the arachnids are very powerful compared to those of the reptiles and the mammals but this is balanced out by the food chain where mammals break all ties and insects lose all ties. 

This means that insects and arachnids need to have a lot of species in an area if they want to score well and mammals and reptiles can sometimes cheekly move in a single species and clean up on points. 

Tundra tiles cripple your species as they are all wiped out bar one however there is a series of bonus points available for most species on tundra to compensate.

Over speciation can result in you running out of new species to put on the board and thus expanding into newer point-scoring areas.

So no. .Too long for that kind of game.

Initial rating = 5 (which is quite good for its length!)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4.5
[Solo play and two player observations only]

Pros
-Highly strategic worker placement; rewards thoughtful play
-Interesting theme that blends with gameplay
-Lots of options for actions, each with their own use
-Good mechanical gameplay design, e.g. clearly lots of thought put into the order in which actions execute
-Some nice artwork (I have 4th edition)
-Numerous components (even if simplistic), good rulebook
-Supports 2-6 players, scales fairly well (fewer actions per player)

Cons
-Heavy thinking game and long game (and down) time not suitable for everyone
-Can induces analysis paralysis since there are quite a few options. Also hard to instant remember what each option is (e.g. wasteland and depletion...hmm which is which again?).

-Constant need to recalculate dominance in each tile. Tiles are also very misleading since quantity of your population doesn't matter for dominance (you can have 50 cubes on a tile, but someone with 1 cube can out-compete you if they have just 1 more element matching)
-Somewhat fiddly (constantly moving cubes around)
-Theme mis-match: land tile are only variable by how they score and how easy it is to expand population on it. They don't have any inherent benefit towards any of the elements or species. A "Desert" tile doesn't necessarily start with a sun element, and it can just as easily be surrounded by 6 water elements as 6 of any element.
-Weird use of glaciation - how do animals control the rate and location of glaciations?

-Species don't feel very different. 
-Evolutions are lame, just one off abilities or tacking on an extra element (as opposed to new powers)
-Missed potential for combat. You just remove 1 cube.

-Components barely fit into box unless insert is removed
-Use of cubes instead of animal meeples (though that would be quite pricey since there are lots of components).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Rules Complexity: :star::star::star::nostar::nostar:
Strategic Depth: :star::star::star::halfstar::nostar:
Luck Factor :star::halfstar::nostar::nostar::nostar:
Negotiation Factor: :nostar::nostar::nostar::nostar::nostar:
Amount of Downtime: :star::nostar::nostar::nostar::nostar:
Fiddliness: :star::star::star::halfstar::nostar:
Replayability: :star::star::star::star::star:
Component Quality: :star::star::star::nostar::nostar:
Player Interaction: :star::star::star::star::star:
"Take That" Conflict: :star::star::star::star::nostar:
Theme Integration: :star::star::star::star::nostar:

This is a great worker placement / area majority game with no hidden information. But it may not be for you if you don't like long games that feel somewhat chaotic. There is significantly more player interaction than other popular worker placement games like Caylus and Age of Empires 3, and most of that interaction is very confrontational. This game can get very mean!  In my humble opinion, this game is easier to learn than most heavy worker placement games, and the rulebook is very straightforward and well-written. I'm tempted to knock it down half a point in my ratings because it takes significant effort to constantly re-calculate who has dominance on each tile based on the elements, but the fiddliness could be worse.

Components are very sturdy, but not that pretty. If they had had some kind of minis to represent the various animal types, and something that made more sense than wooden cones to represent domination, it would have taken this to the next level!

RATING: 9
Have played it a lot. Always enjoy it. Dislike that the Domination Cards cause huge swings in the game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
The theme in this game fits very well. It involves playing as a family of animals (reptile, amphibian, mammal, bird, insect, or arachnid) where you populate the world with new species of your animal and try to dominate the world to survive the ice age. It takes a while to play, feels a bit like Agricola, but it isn't tedious. This game includes plenty of choices, and for the overcautious could lead to AP, but there seems to be enough leeway where making a poor choice once or twice won't ruin the game, so AP should be avoidable if you have the right attitude.

RATING: 7.1
Lembra muito o [thing=22545][/thing]. O sistema de "locação de trabalhadores" e resolução dos mesmo é muito parecida, com uma grande diferença: as ações são muito mais interligadas umas com as outras, isso é muito legal, inclusive algumas ações influenciam os 3 turnos seguintes nessas "actions boxes".
Outra característica importante do jogo é que ele tem uma disputa de área enorme, não somente controle de maioria nos territórios como no AoEIII. Toda rodada tem muito conflito e mudanças no tabuleiro pois disputa-se simultaneamente o controle da maioria no território e a dominação das especies no território. 
Essa dominação lhe dar importantes cartas de evento ao final da rodada. Estas cartas controlam o tempo de jogo e, na minha opinião, deixam o jogo "muito caótico". Elas estão totalmente dentro do tema, se encaixam muito bem mas é difícil planeja algo por 4 horas e toda rodada ser surpreendido por um evento devastador. Por causa disso, pegar as melhores (primeiras) cartas é decisivo. Para pegar as primeiras cartas deves-se ser o primeiro a jogar. A vantagem de jogar primeiro passa a ser DECISIVA e para jogar primeiro demora muito e o custo é muito alto, achei a única falha do jogo pois, diferentemente do AoEII em que você assume o primeiro lugar na iniciativa ao escolher essa ação, no DS você apenas avança um espaço na iniciativa. Então uma coisa ficou muito amarrada a outra, fique em primeiro, pegue as melhores cartas, mantenha-se em primeiro, pegue as melhores cartas, etc. Isso ocorreu nas 6 ultimas das 8 rodadas de jogo.
Tirando isso, achei o jogo fantástico. São 4 horas de um bom jogo. Dou um 7.0 só não é maior por que é caótico e por esse problema da iniciativa.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Chaotic area control with an elegant workerplacement twist. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Dominant Species lets you replay evolution. If that sounds grand, it is. The game is epic both in a thematic sense, spanning several 10,000 years, and in actual play time during which players strive to become the dominant species on the planet.

They do this by placing workers, selecting various actions that allow them to have their species adapt to changing conditions, migrate, breed, and so on. The main part of this battle for survival happens on the modular map. This part of the game employs a two-dimensional area control mechanic in which you can either be the most populous species on a tile or be the best adapted (or both, of course). The map play is highly interactive with everyone trying to broaden their niche, deliberately making conditions less favourable for other species, or simply outright attacks.

Dominant Species has a ton of moving parts which is the main reason a game takes as long as it does. Analyzing the current state of affairs (and drawing sound conclusions from that) is hard. However, all of these parts fit together very well. There don't seem to be any dealbreakers, there are mitigation options for pretty much anything, and even the asymmetric species powers are balanced.

Overall, the game implements its theme amazingly well. At the end of the day it is still a multiplayer conflict game with all the issues that entails but it does also include a completely different layer that stays interesting even when the conflict does not.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
An absolute brain-burner. Good game, an area control monster with some particular twists. Cards are too powerful and destroy your long term strategy so you need to adapt.

Ein Wettstreit der Arten in der Frühzeit der Erdgeschichte als WP und Mehrheitenspiel, das im Spielgefühl erstaunlich gut darwinistische Lebensart widerspiegelt. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
At first I thought this was another action selection game - and actually it is. But it might be the most thematically linked and well-thought out action system game I've ever played! The theme is perfect.  Even though I'm pushing little cubes around, I really do feel for my animals and species that breed, dominate and go extinct through every round. The impending Ice Age feels crucial and adds much tension to the game. The player interaction works well. The cards - while screwy and provides lots of swings - adds character to the game. Such a well thought out game; I'm truly amazed. I can see where analysis paralysis could definitely slow down any player, but it would pretty much destroy somebody who can't think through a game like this. There are many actions one can take and different routes to success. There's always one thing you didn't see coming though, and that can be frustrating - even when expected. All that aside, a top game with clear rules and lots of room for thought and experience.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: N/A
Box has minor corner damage
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A modern classic that feels quite old presentation wise, but is still up there among the best area majority games I have played. 

The turns are quick. The worker placement steps are interesting with interconnecting mechanisms. Everyone takes turn placing workers then when all workers are placed actions take places in a predetermined order. This is great and makes the game flow quickly for our group. But I can see that playing with an AP-prone player it might really take a lot of time calculating all options. 

Areas are controlled in two ways, the one with most animals on an area gets most points when the area is scored. Of those who are present, the animal most adapted to the area get a special bonus card when the area Is scored. The special bonus cards are not balanced and can take some time to understand and really mess up other players plans. They slow down the game a bit, and if they where clearer easier to see at a glance that would be a great improvement.  

Scoring actions take place last in the round, so there are plenty of actions to take before scoring to get points from other players scoring. It is quite easy to see what area is best for them to score and increase your presence there. But if you increase so much you get majority, then the player will score another area instead. That is a really interesting mechanism that works well. 

Why are there so few games with this theme? It is amazing to be animals spreading across the land, adopting to the environment. They could have made the connection to the theme a lot stronger and the game more intuitive than it is, but the theme is still a great one. 

It is a really mean game with lots of kingmaking moments. You can destroy areas with glaciers or remove food so that animals that eat that starve and die. That is the nature of area majority games that I accept when playing them but really dislike. It is about taking control of areas from other players. When I gain something someone else have to lose it. That is something I do not enjoy and the reason no game like this will ever be my favourite. 

I could imagine a game with new areas that we take control of and that we never remove control. A friendly area majority game where we all grow and get better. The land grow here and our presence grows so there is a bit of that here. But it could be done more. 

During the game you adapt to eating different things, but other than that there is no arch of the game. Your options in the beginning are the same as in the end. 
But instead it is quick to learn with only a few rules (compared to other heavy games). Liked it would like to play again. 8/10
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Needs sleeves (not green/purple FF sleeves). 66x91 I think.

RATING: 9
A great wargame disguised as boardgame. The ecologist in our group says it's too confrontational to be an accurate depiction of real ecosystem (she has high praise for Primordial Soup). =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.2
1) Incredibly long wait time between turns with 5 players.  Allegedly plays 6, but it's bad enough with 5.
2) Again, allegedly plays 5-6, but with 5, you can be locked out of round scoring.  With 6, at least one person definitely would be locked out each round.
3) Mean, I mean really mean.  Specific players can be targeted and destroyed.  Players can be ganged up on as well.
4) So much AP. From every player. OMG.  The playtime for four new players and one teaching was 4 hours but it felt like 8.
5) Player groups are VERY unbalanced. Don't play as mammals; you go last and your player power is useless. 
6) Reward cards are incredibly powerful. Maybe TOO powerful.
7) U-G-L-Y game - very generic pastel hex board.

All this being said the game has deep strategy and interesting choices.  It's more a war game than a worker placement and since it's overly long those two things mean it's not that fun.

RATING: 10
Perfectly brilliant area control game with a theme that well fits the mechanics. Ignore naysayers that say the game is difficult to understand- it's very simple. What unfolds is a war of the species each with their own unique strengths, in desperate & tight competition for ever dwindling resources. Every action counts with tremendous effect. Applying a killer strategy, though, is not that easy- but can be a very enjoyable undertaking if accomplished. The game is brutal and punishes mistakes quickly, which, again, fits the theme perfectly. The 3rd reprint edition has a wonderful map-board and tiles- significantly improved over previous editions. If I could only take a few games to a desert island, this would be one of them.

Incredible fun. 10/10.

RATING: 8
Highly confrontational, AP prone, chaotic game of evolution and dominance.  Theme is nicely incorporated into this two-tiered area majority game.  First tier is pretty simple --most cubes (species) earn points.  Second tier provides powerful actions that can score, help you in the long haul, or seriously mess up one or more of your opponents.  If you can't handle a wild ride, don't even think about playing DS.

RATING: 9
Art & Production - :star::star::halfstar::nostar::nostar:
Theme & Narrative - :star::star::star::star::star:
Mechanic Elegance - :star::star::star::star::star:
Replayability & Fun - :star::star::star::nostar::nostar:
X-Factor/Originality- :star::star::star::star::nostar:

Grand Total - 19.5/25

A crunchy and rich worker placement game which mimics real world ecological shifts and asks player to adapt to the ever changing, player driven, tile-laying landscape. A game which models evolution to a certain degree of fidelity which perhaps leads to too much manual calculation and cleaning but nevertheless becomes the pre-eminent game on speciation and arguably worker placement!

RATING: 9
1 play and I love this game.  The dominance mechanics make sense thematically while still providing challenges in gameplay, the rotating placement of actions and action resolution guarantees minimal downtime per player, and allows you to plan ahead to minimize AP.  All species have interesting special abilities which can be used advantageously.  There are enough different actions available to make it challenging, different, and allow different strategies to win.  Overall a great game I can't wait to play again.

RATING: 9.5
Whenever I play this, I marvel at the genius of this game! Every decision wracks your brain because there are so many consequences to what you pick and the order you do so. The theme works absolutely brilliantly here and represents the changing earth, dwindling supplies, and the encroachment of other species in to new areas. (I have a biological sciences background, so this is something that appeals to me.) 
It DOES take a while to play, and your head might hurt a bit after doing so.
For me, and some of the people I play with, this is what it's all about. Socializing with good friends and staying intellectually engaged and competitive.
