RATING: 9
I really enjoy this game. A lot of direct interaction, brilliant theme, and a constantly changing board. This is a very well made game and contrary to what other people say I think it is quite well balanced. Extremely high replayability with each game having a drastically different feel and result. Chaotic elements provides new challenges in each turn that you cannot anticipate and plan for from the previous turn, which I enjoy. You are never out of this game and the winner almost always comes from behind. A great reward for both strategic foresight and tactical play wrapped in a brutally competitive game.

RATING: 5

Maybe the Ice Age was freezing our brains but the whole table seemed swamped in Analysis Paralysis. Usually I am not one to take a long time on my turn but I was getting mired in choices like everyone else. And the one person who had played before, his first game had also taken 7 hours.  

And the game is very tactical as opposed to strategic. It was hard to plan ahead since you didn't know what crazy things your opponents would do.  While I might enjoy such a chaotic game if it was only 2-3 hours long, I really don't enjoy 7 hours of chaos where I feel I have no control.

If I was to play with 3 others who already knew the game and we could play it in 3 hours or less I might could rate it higher.  But TBH, I don't feel compelled to try it again.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Played on Minnesota Dan's 1st edition copy. I'm not sure what to make of the game. On one hand, it is very involved and I truly think the old chestnut "many paths to victory" apply here. Furthermore, the dynamic of resources being considered both for survival and dominance feel really fresh and interesting. The scoring is almost all tied to the bonus table chart which makes figuring out scores quite easy. On the other hand, the game has moments of being random and quite swingy. For such a long and involved game, I don't know if I can get really excited about a game that relies so heavily on these elements.

PROS
-High player interaction.
-Lots of planning & ways to win.
-Player abilities feel thematic.
-Nearly all scoring follows the bonus points table, which makes this quite easy to grasp.

CONS
-Randomness in resource tiles for Adaptation, Abundance, & Wanderlust. (Also randomness in Wanderlust tiles but this is less of an issue.)
-Randomness in event cards.
-Very swingy. In our first game we had massive lead changes -up to 20 VP - four times. End game scoring can also lead to some crazy scoring.
-Nitpick but I'd like to see the board indicate the three actions that get you VP - glaciation, wanderlust, & domination - plus the tundra scoring.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8.5
Wow! This game is amazing.  Like a fascinating enigma.  There is so much to think about that my wife literally said "My brain just exploded.  I thought I was onto something, but then it went *boom* and I'm done.  I'll just go here and see what happens."

We've played twice...with 10 dominance cards to keep it short.  Keeps the game at about 2 hours.  

A definite keeper, but I don't know anybody other than my wife who is going to want to play it with me.  It's a real brain burner.

UPDATE:  we can't seem to get this to the table.  Our 2 year old takes up a lot of time and energy, so it's a rare occurrence for us to have 3 hours and the energy multiple days in a row to focus on learning this game and playing it well.  We're still fascinated with it and WANT to play it, but it will probably have to happen during summer vacation when my schoolteacher wife is more well-rested.

RATING: 10
My absolute all-time favorite game. Intense worker placement that creates wild variation between games, and one of the few games I know of where being eliminated from the board does not necessarily cripple you - I managed to come in third place in a tournament of this game after being completely wiped off of the board on turn one. Unfortunately the depth of the game and the length of time it takes to play this game means I've taught it to relatively few friends, since a game of this can frazzle everybody's brains for the night.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Marvelous, brilliantly-constructed game.

The best way I can quickly describe Dominant Species is that it's the state-of-the-art hardcore gamer's version of El Grande. The magic of El Grande was not just plopping cubes into regions and scoring 1st, 2nd, and 3rd place whenever a scoring round rolls along. Many games have done that sort of thing. No, the magic was in the jockeying for the special game-breaking actions that put the game state in constant flux, and provided countless ways of screwing up your opponents' plans. Dominant Species has the same kind of fun in the box.

But of course, Dominant Species is more than just Advanced El Grande. It combines the best parts of El Grande with the smooth menu selection / action drafting / worker placement of games like Caylus, Agricola, Age of Empires, and seemingly every other game released over the past five years. That sort of system works best when it creates the feeling that there are three or four or five things you absolutely must do right away, and you might be totally screwed if you don't get to do them. Agricola, for example, gets this right. Most of the other games in the genre get it wrong. Dominant Species gets it right.

And for all its mechanical beauty, Dominant Species also features an organic, compelling theme that meshes amazingly well with the game systems. I really do feel like I'm doing the sort of things I ought to be doing in a game about protean creatures that are adapting, surviving, proliferating, dominating. My role is that of a god-like shepherd and provider for my creatures. I'm not just guiding their actions. I'm also shaping the world itself to create an environment where they can thrive.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
First game took over 4 hours with 5 people. I really enjoyed it and look forward to playing it again. You know you have played a good game when you go home after a 5 hour session and can't get to sleep because you are going over your moves and how you could have improved them!!

RATING: 7
While the concept of a combination of area influence and worker placement isn’t unique as it has been compared to [thing=22545][/thing], the integration between the mechanics is more seamless here. This makes it impressive and coherent experience. The game has some really tough decisions because the game is open-ended and that it can lead to some serious analysis paralysis. 

I found it more interesting in theory for my first game than in practical execution though. There are many things I admire in this design, the choices between spreading out or get more adaptable and dominant, but it was hard for me to wrap my brain around it and too much player driven chaos. That said, I would love to play it some more.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Dominant Species is an excellent worker placement game for 2 to 6 player.  The goal of the game is to adapt you species the most effectively before the Ice Age occurs.
Actions allow you to adapt your species to new element, add or remove element from Earth, add new tile to the Earth, change existing terrain into tundra, kill other species, add your own, etc.
I like this game a lot!

RATING: 7.6

The key point is to find a good balance between Dominance and majorities. The last round is decisive and sadly prone to kingmaking. It takes 3 hrs to play but is not boring if at least you don't play with a/p players as some decisions are made by pure calculation of what cubes to place or push over there... I deducted 0.3 from my rating for typos on the board and cards (German Edition)

RATING: 8

Only the length of play and player count (best with the full compliment) prevents me from getting this to the table as often as I would like.  In saying this, it has become my 6 player strategy game of choice and I'm looking forward to the next game in the hope that my next crazy plan will be more effective than the one I tried this evening.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I'm willing to admit it's a bit longer than I'd like, but for me that's mainly because the length makes it harder to talk people into playing the game. 

First time players can come away with the impression that the cards are too chaotic for such a long game or that too much depends on the final scoring. Now that I've played a few games I think those first impressions are misleading. There aren't very many cards, so after a couple of games you can keep in mind the important ones that haven't hit yet and try to position yourself to grab them or mitigate their damage. 

Secondly, although a large fraction of the points are scored in the final round, the game is really about positioning yourself well to grab those points. Ideally you would stay within sight of the leader, avoiding too much attention from the other players. (There are a lot of opportunities to attack the leader.) Then, start preparing your positions a couple turns before the endgame to be ready to take full advantage of the final scoring opportunities that come your way. 

I think this is a game where skill allows you to make your own luck. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
1st play - 2 players, (Marlee) mammals vs. (me) arachnids.
The mammals dominated 196-169 pts.  This was so much fun!  There were definitely a few errors made during play that might have changed the whole flow of the game, but it was tremendously fun nonetheless.  I can't wait to play this again with new animals and more players.  Serious brain exercise!
---
2nd play - 2 players, (Mar) insects vs. (me) reptiles.
Insects win by a narrow thread, 232-222 pts!  I scored the maximum for domination through ice age at the end, but Marlee's survival bonus and 2 sea tiles wanderlusted at the end gave her the game.  This was all despite a very devastating Blight in the first round that put her in a foul mood the whole game and she accepted her defeat.  Until the final scoring of course.  Seriously fantastic game and we played with only one wrong rule this time!  (Not scoring the bonus for wanderlust).  I think it would have only secured her victory even more.  
Rating boost 9->10
---
4th play (3rd was incomplete) Mammals (Sean) vs. Birds (Me).
This game had some amazing twists and turns, devastating Domination cards, a relentless Glaciation that wiped out the majority of our cubes (mostly equally), and though it wasn't a close finish, it was a close game.  However, I did decide to drop this one to a 9 as a result. This game is just a little long (even having removed the action pawn related Dom cards) for what you get from it.  It's brilliant, but not perfect.

RATING: 5.5
Dominant Species is a wonderful game that's hurt by all the tedious bookkeeping. On iOS it's fantastic, and takes at most 30 minutes. In person it takes at least 3 hours because every time an element on a tile changes you have to do some simple math. But there are a lot of tiles, so that math time adds up. I'm also not a huge fan of games where you have to ruin other people's games to win. You have to do that here. But it's a solid game through and through.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
On the good side:
Has plenty of depth and is a "gamer's game";
Has many alternative actions available to choose;
Is an interesting adaption of the Age of Empires action system;
Seems to be hard for anyone to run away with the lead if other players pay attention.

On the bad side:
The impact of the event cards seems overpowering relative to the rest of actions;
The calculation of dominance, scoring and projecting changes to those as a result of actions gets a bit tedious;
Arguably, too much depth as it feels more convoluted than AoE III for example;
Players can have strategic plans and execute tactical level actions, but the operational level in between is a challenge of managing turbulent processes and events that are hard to predict (which is where this differs from the 1830 family of games);
Need to be willing to commit a significant amount of time with the understanding that a couple event cards will likely determine who actually wins.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Big game in a really nice and sturdy box. The cover artwork looks fine, but once you see the other graphics you may ask yourself: "wtf happened?!"
This doesn't kill the game for me, but the difference is huge. Well, the 2nd edition seems to avoid this. :)

This game works great and is by no means a bad game, BUT there are things I just can't understand. Like the fact that a lucky player may be able to get the "new action pawn" card early in the game, while the other's don't. You can't do much if anything about it and that extra action is HUGE! This card problem reminds me of Railraod Tycoon and I know that many people had a problem with that system. There's even more luck working in this game, that MAY kill a players game.

The other problem is the playing time. This game can take ages and most of the time you will have to wait for your turn, as other players may have changed the whole board until then.

Away from that, it's a great, heavy game with easy to understand rules. Really, this is a monster of a game, but the short rules are very clear and that's very impressive.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
005 Want to play

RATING: N/A
1e
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
gmt by cc 3/18 upgraded counters from 2e
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Have only played it a few times but its great.  The game has a lot of depth, but the rules once learned are fairly simple.  The game has great interaction between players which I love and a lot to consider.

Real fun, real well designed, and looks great.  The time range of 2-4 hours could definitely be shorter as it is largely dependent on how long people take to think while placing their action pawns.  If you play with some slow movers it could surely be 4 hours or longer.  However, if you play with some quick choosers you could probably do a game in 1-1.5 hours.

The only thing that is a bit tiresome about the game is constantly re-calculating dominance, but I suppose you could only do this prior to the dominance phase.  But when doing it this way it would be easy to make an error and miss changes.  Might be a bit hard to get non-gamers to play due to the numerous rules, but if you could get them through a turn it should be fine.

Overall great game and great theme.

Only downside I see is the large learning curve and reluctance you get with it from people (family) not as open to such barriers of entry.

Revision: Do not play this with people who take a long time to make decisions, it will drag into the 5 hour range.  This also makes it quite a bit less enjoyable.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
A game I always want to play. It takes a few plays to really grasp how the game fits together as a whole but after that it is worth all the effort. Reading the board, grasping the significance of the scoring system (knowing that those ahead on the score are not necessarily the ones in the best winning position for instance) as well as the impact of the dominance cards is important to get the best out of it.

The game is far less chaotic than it appears at first sight but that does mean you need to think into the other players board positions rather than simply play your own game. This is really a Wargame with Euro selection mechanics, to play it any other way will probably result in disappointment.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

I need to play this one for fun again, to get that sour taste out of my mouth for this game that tournament left.

RATING: 8

RATING: 9.5

Worker placement game that can be a brain-burner at times and takes 3-4 hours to play, but I love every minute of it!  Lots of player interaction, but not mean.  Variable players powers, but balanced.  Continuous area-control fighting with no random chance.  It may be the euro-gamer's ideal game.

RATING: 7
One of the most brain draining game I played to date !

Players each given a species at random, each with special abilities which will help in the game.

Players take turns selecting action they want to take and resolves one by one. I would say this game involves strategy, math skills (counting domination of an area tile) and sweet talking to other players to play/not to play catastrophie cards! YES there is a card called catastropy which kills everyone!

I rate this game highly because of its cleverly designed APs and involves thinking. However be prepared for lot of brain draining!

RATING: 8
A terrific worker-placement, action selection game, that nicely models the inter-species competition it portrays.

The cubes, cylinders and cones Euro-ize it considerably, so it doesn't seem very animal-specific, but the competition mechanisms and the swings as well as opportunities seem very strong, and fairly varied.

Getting more actions early-on was the biggest swing in my one play; first species to 4 really built out a lead (which was surpassed in play) but which propelled it to the final victory.

This one gets an 8 on a 1st play, and I expect more to follow when I can budget the loooong chunk of time needed to pull it out again.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
(12/17/10): Intriguing "survival of the fittest" type game, where you try to gain dominance in specific terrain in the ever expanding map board. Players alternate and reserve up to four-five (dependent on number of players) specific actions on a flow-chart-like action menu. There are only so many spots available for each action, and each action is resolved from top to bottom, starting with turn-order jockeying, mutation, regression, glaciation, migration, competition, and other steps that mimic the evolutionary process.

There are several other "evolution" type games that play in a much shorter time, as this plays in four-five hours! However, the level of detail in this game that each turn entails is fascinating, as one can watch the rise and fall of a variety of species. Rating: '7'.

Update (02/21/11): It's been two months and it hasn't seen the table since. As several others agree, after a long period to digest our first game, it is simply exhausting to think about playing this again, as it is tedious, complex, and dreadfully long for the payoff. Intriguing as I may have sounded that night, in hindsight, I was hoping the game would accelerate and come to a swift conclusion, but it didn't. It dragged on and on, with one or two hexes being laid out each turn. Every turn was the same monotonous cycle of putting out fires, managing adversity, and mitigating disasters, with little, if any visibility into (or hope for) the future for a long term strategy. I'd watch my herds grow, only to have them decimated either by other players or by random elements of the game, particularly the dominance cards, which seemed realistic, but not enjoyable. Somewhere halfway through the game we began to understand how to use our specie's special powers, but by then we just wanted it to end. Only with one to two turns did it become evident that dominance of the tundra, and earning the right to select the dominance cards, were keys to winning. Until the final turns, we were simply treading water. It will be awhile before we revisit this.

Update (01/24/2015) 4 plays: It has been nearly [i]four[/i] years of begging and pleading by one of the members of my group to bring this to the table. The first game was the same painful exercise in futility, taking 4 hours. We thought it would be another several years before this came back, but the very next day we played it again. This time, being ever vigilant (calling "Time!" if any player started to pause to think, or to start commenting on something), we managed to finish a 3-player game in 2 hrs 5 minutes! This time, concentrating on the dominance cards and Wanderlust, I managed to do well enough to enjoy myself. Also, the game went quicker, because we were doing dominance every turn. Once we accepted that there would be many "take that" moments, and that our herds would get decimated here and there, it became enjoyable. It is not for the faint of heart, as it is a particularly nasty game that awards aggressive play. Over the past four years, I have gained an appreciation for heavier and heavier games. So, this is starting to interest me, enough that I may (gasp) consider buying it. Raising it to an "8".

Update (03/12/2017) 5+ plays: Bought it, love it. The people that love it, love it, and the people that hate it, continue to hate it. I've taught a number of newbies since then, and all agree this is a very good game. In teaching, I've emphasized on getting the dominance cards--this forces players to really examine the dominance cards, thus eliminating surprises, and actually speeds the game at a reasonable rate. Raising it to a "9".

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.1
規則:
1.起始順序照食物鏈，最低的最前面
2.優勢物種為該地形版塊存在對應分數單獨最高的，分數為該版塊各元素乘上生物版塊上對應元素的總合
3.2p:7-55, 3p:6-50, 4p:5-45, 5p:4-40, 6p:3-35,一個物種cube記分
4.除了冰原行動其它移除物種cube的動作都是移出遊戲
5.元素只要移掉就是丟回袋中
6.物種只要沒有配對元素，就會在滅絕階段滅絕
7.行動:
A起始: 往前一格，然後往下擺
B適應: 挑元素一個放在自己圖版上
C衰退: 有放的少掉一個生物圖版上的元素，只算種類
D供給: 放元素在任一角落
E荒原: 可選取意元素拿掉，剩下的有與冰原相連的都要棄掉
F消耗: 選取一個地圖版塊上的元素棄掉，必須這裡面有
G冰原: 放冰原，冰原上生物剩一隻，其它回手，三個冰原連角的元素棄掉，冰原連結記分
H物種形成: 在選取的元素相鄰版塊生物種，全部版塊都生
I探險: 放一個地形版塊，可選一個元素放，相鄰生物看生物鏈順序移動上去，或得版塊相鄰分數
J遷徙: X隻生物移動一格
K競爭: 三個地形中，各有自己生物可各殺一隻對手生物，
L統治: 選一個版塊記分，分數比個數，優勢物種必須選一張卡並執行，有玩家選冰河紀，則此回合後遊戲結束
8.滅絕階段把沒有配對元素的生物移出遊戲，然後倖存者記分，全部冰原上生物最多的可以記分，平手都不記，分數為他總共佔據多少冰原版塊，查表得分
9.在生階段，能向下的元素向下，沒有向下的收回袋子裡重抽補滿有格子的，翻開地形版塊，補牌補滿
10.最後記分:遊戲結束根據各版塊上生物數量每一塊都記分，冰原記分卡根據你擁有的優勢物種個數，記累加分數 
11.無卡牌變體，所有卡牌沒有效果(冰河記分除外)，遊戲最後照拿到卡牌數目算bonus分數。
12.遊戲算bonus分數的時候，拼冰原跟地形版塊，倖存卡記分，冰河卡記分

RATING: 6
Really a worker placement and area majority game, but the dominance cards throw such a lot of chaos and direct attacks into the mix that whether you succeed or not is mostly in the hands of others. I wouldn't want to play this with more than 4 again, as the player going last can't take adaptations, nor advance along the initiative track if the others take these choices first (and it's entirely sensible that they should). The game's length is further extended by a vulnerability to over-analysis, putting this way over a sensible playing time for the chaos factor involved.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Wow. There's a lot going on here.  Each player has a particular power and a particular place in the turn order (which can, however, be changed over the course of the game). Then there's a worker-placement game and, underneath it all, an area control game.  There's also some card drafting involved. So there are many different elements, and taking them all into account in one's strategy over the course of this four (or so) hour game is pretty challenging.  There's enough scope in the game for a lot of back-and-forth--a player can have it all wrapped up only to lose a lot of ground in a single bad turn.  The end result is satisfying and complex and, um, really long.  Fatigue set in after the first few hours, which tempered my satisfaction a little bit. It hangs together really well for what it is, but I couldn't play it very often. (1 play)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Great game. If it takes shorter to play, I may rate it 10
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.7
When I first played it, it blew my mind away to be honest.

So many options to choose from, the mechanics is so different than all those games out there! Oh and the pieces, so colourful, so cute! (Haha, can't think of a better description.)

Every class of animal plays differently, and a 2 player game is different than a 4 player game, and those games are different than a 6 player mayhem!

Some might have complained about the lack of control about the game in high player count, but that's exactly why I love the 6 player games! It's a tough world out there, we cannot control everything, but we can take the best out of what we have.

Some might have complained about the long play time. My girlfriend told me this, which I completely agree upon. "Even the game lasted 2-3 hours, I... don't feel devastated. My brain is not burned like after playing Sid Meier's Civilization." Besides, if it really took TOO long for your taste, you can always take away 5 dominance cards, or even 10. You will still have a quick fun game.

Every person's action has impact on everyone, the high amount of interaction keeps everyone engaged. Cut-throat element is gorgeous. I also love the big swing at the end, it very often comes up with some pleasantly surprising results!

If you love strategic game, you don' want to miss this one! One of the best games I have ever played!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This is my number one favorite game.  Its long but it completely satisfies my Gaming Quotient (GD = Game Enjoyment/Time Playing).  The game has a simple yet complex action selection mechanism that drives the game. There is a nice balance of multiple strategies which are dynamic with the way the events come out and how the players develop the board.  There are player boards that are slightly asymmetric, but none of them dictate your strategy they only enhance your tactical decision to get where the game leads. The margins in score are often large but the game is still close.  One of the nice elements is that you can have all of your early game pieces eliminated and still recover and move to victory with solid play.  The choices in this game are deep and rich.  I have played this game at all players counts, I prefer 4-6 players and I find this game very engaging as there are many meaningful things to think about even while waiting for 5 other players to make their action selections.  I have several friends that prefer the game at 3 players and I wont argue when we can just start playing.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
"El Grande: Versión del director". Un juego de mayorías con muchos más añadidos que obligan al jugador a prestar mucha atención al desarrollo de la partida. Añade la interacción de Die Macher al sistema de puntuación de El Grande, junto con la colocación de trabajadores de Caylus o Agricola y cierto toque de evolución que podemos encontrar en Primordial Soup.

En Dominant Species, (DS), cada jugador toma el rol de uno de los 6 animales del juego: mamíferos, reptiles, pájaros, anfibios, arácnidos o insectos. La tierra está dividida en hexágonos que representan el mar, humedales, la sabana, junglas, bosques, desiertos, montañas y, cuando se acerca la edad de hielo, la tundra. En cada vértice, se sitúan los "elementos", unas piezas de cartón con forma de círculo que representan lo que los animales necesitan para sobrevivir: carne, sol, semillas, agua, larvas y, por último, hierba. Conforme el juego progresa, la tierra conocida va aumentando, se añaden nuevos elementos al tablero y los animales tienen que adaptarse a ello.

Cada animal (cada jugador), tiene un poder especial que no se altera durante toda la duración de la partida, pero los elementos que necesita para sobrevivir si pueden (y deben) evolucionar durante la misma. También hay tres tipos de piezas de madera: los cilindros que son los "puntos de acción".Se usarán para seleccionar las acciones que cada jugador quiera realizar.

Los cubos representan las "especies", digamos la cantidad de población de ese animal en concreto que ocupa un hexágono y los conos de madera representarán la "dominancia", que es un concepto del juego que representa la adaptación de un animal en concreto al terreno que ocupa. Esto se calcula en función de la cantidad de elementos (hierba, sol, larvas...) que haya en los vértices del hexágono que coincidan con los que tenga el animal en cuestión.

Lo importante de esto es lo siguiente: un animal NO domina un terreno por tener la mayor cantidad de especies (cubitos) en él, sino por tener la mayor capacidad de desenvolverse en él, que viene determinada por ser el que tenga mayor cantidad de elementos coincidentes con los del terreno (el mejor adaptado para desarrollarse en él).

El juego, en esencia, es una combinación de dos mecánicas que me encantan: la colocación de trabajadores con la de mayorías. Hay que conseguir la mayor cantidad de PV´s antes de que llegue la edad de hielo (representada por la última carta que entra en juego durante la partida). 

El núcleo del juego es el menú de acciones que hay en el tablero, que es enorme. Hay un límite de puntos de acción que pueden entrar en determinado lugar, así que, al no haber espacio para todos los jugadores, el orden de turno es importante.Sin entrar demasiado en la explicación, algunas de estas acciones son:

Adaptación: (añades un elemento a tu tablero de animales), Abundancia (añades un elemento a una loseta de terreno), Glaciación (transformas un terreno en tundra), Speciation, (añades nuevas especies -cubos- al tablero), Wanderlust (añades una loseta de terreno nuevo al tablero, Migración (mueves especies por el tablero), Competición (las especies pelean entre sí y se eliminan), Dominación (el jugador anota puntos por tener la mayoría de especies en determinada loseta, habiendo PV´s, en general, para el 2º y 3º). Además, la acción de Dominación, entrega al jugador que tenga dominancia en la loseta que se puntúa, una carta que suele dar una ventaja: acciones extra, desgracias que puedes hacer a los demás...

Las mecánicas del juego, como vemos no son complejas. El menú de acciones disponibles es muy claro y cada acción "per sé" no es difícil. Pero entender las implicaciones de una acción es dónde reside lo verdaderamente intrincado del juego. Además hay dos sistemas de mayorías: el control del área (que da PV´s al que más cubitos -especies- tenga en el hexágono) y la "aptitud del área" (que premia al jugador que se encuentra mejor adaptado para desarrollarse en el área, es decir a aquél que tenga mayor coincidencia con los elementos mostrados en los vértices del hexágono).

Por si fuera poco, hay otros métodos de conseguir PV´s, como son colocar nuevos terrenos gracias a la acción de Wanderlust o Glaciación. Por último, tienes una reserva de cubitos que es limitada y que puede agotarse antes de que termine el juego si no lo gestionas bien. Añadir que debes prestar atención al orden de acciones dado que una acción previa puede anular el efecto de una acción posterior. No es que haya sorpresas gracias al azar, sino que hay que seguir muy de cerca las acciones y su orden o te sorprenden (generalmente de forma bastante desagradable).

PROS:  La Glaciación. Una mecánica que me encanta. Si alguien me preguntara: "¿Qué es lo que hace DS que no haga El Grande?", sin duda contestaría con:"La Glaciación". Esta mecánica hace que todo el mundo ande de puntillas con cierta tensión y, con frecuencia, te obliga a tomar decisiones desagradablemente duras (¿Coloco este elemento cerca de la tundra para tener más posibilidades de supervivencia, o por el contrario lo alejo de ella para encontrarme más seguro?). Además, otorga cierto arco argumental al juego (inicio-nudo-desenlace) y genera un mecanismo de buenas oportunidades para remontar la partida.

Combina muy bien aspectos estratégicos en las acciones de Especiación /Wanderlust /Glaciación /Adaptación con aspectos más tácticos de la dominancia y migración. 

Reglamento clarísimo y con ejemplos aclaratorios. Creo que incluso mejor redactado que el de Through the Ages.

CONS: Si esperas un juego con animeeples de 60-90 min. de mecánicas sencillas y comportamiento predecible, no es tu juego. Esto le hace ver muy poca mesa.

Hay mucha variabilidad que puede no gustar: inicio asimétrico gracias a los distintos poderes de cada especie, tablero variable, situación variable de recursos, árbol de decisiones enorme debido a la colocación de los peones de acción en las acciones... Esto genera excesivo Análisis Parálisis (AP), así que recomiendo encarecidamente olvidarle si hay algún jugador que tienda a ello, aunque sea mínimamente. El juego se convierte en una tortura. En un festival del AP

Además, hay mucha agresión e interacción, muy poco habitual en los juegos de este estilo, y pudiera ser que no gustara a todos los jugadores.

En general, para muchos jugadores es un juego que exige mucho más de lo que te da.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: N/A


=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
After finally managing to play Dominant Species in under four hours, I feel comfortable giving it a 10.  There's nothing I don't love about this game.  It's one of the few games that keeps me completely absorbed for the entire run, impressive considering its length.  Others have labeled this "brain burning," but I generally have not felt that way about it - yes, it is heavy, and yes, there are many moving parts, so many that it's almost guaranteed that something obvious (in hindsight) will completely blindside you sometime during the game, but I find the experience exhilarating rather than draining. After playing it a few times, what I've come to appreciate about it most is the constant tension between the short-term tactical game and the long-term strategic game.  This is a common feature of many great games (i.e. Agricola) but Dominant Species really takes it to the next level with the Dominance Cards (and by extension, the constant need to maintain Dominance somewhere on the board); what cards are available on a given turn can completely turn the game on a dime and force everyone to readjust on the fly while still trying to maintain some semblance of the long game. Combine this with the constantly changing board and its tendency to mess up whatever plan you originally had when you placed your Action Pawns, and you have a roller coaster ride of a game that does not let up for a minute.  Perhaps the most amazing thing about Dominant Species is how simple the rules are and how much depth and complexity the game can wring from them; the brain-burning comes from your opponent's actions and their effects on your plans, not from pages and pages of chrome. Not for the fainthearted or conflict-averse, Dominant Species is an absolute beast of a game, and an absolute joy to play.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9

This game plays well with 3-6, and competition is steep regardless of the species chosen. Delicate alliances of convenience must be formed, or your species will be pushed further into its niche - and eventually into extinction.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I LOVE this game!  I almost could assert that Dominant Species is THE perfect board game, however I cannot give it a 10 in good conscience because the game takes a substantially long time to play and there is significant barrier to entry for most new-ish gamers.  Non-gamers have no business playing this monster.  The theme of animals vying for dominance in an interesting, varied and dynamic landscape comprised of numerous terrain types shortly before the dawn of an ice age comes alive through brilliant mechanics.  Players will deploy their animals strategically on different terrain hexes, modify their animals' ability to flourish in diverse environments, alter the environment on the terrain hexes so that they will be more amenable to their own species and less amenable to other players' species, and even kill other players' animals.  Dominant species combines several ideas established in previous games such as the area majority scoring from El Grande and the worker placement action selection from Stone Age into a brain burning masterpiece.  With twelve interesting and strongly thematic different actions to choose from, Analysis Paralysis (AP) struck early and often.   I do not mind AP; it often indicates that players are challenged to make stimulating choices on heir turn, which is a characteristic I want embossed into every game I play.  Dominant Species is a mean and nasty game that affords players several novel and stimulating means of wrecking other players such as: commanding the mighty power of a glacier that road grades unwary animals one hex per round, invoking ecological disaster to strike where your opponent would like it least, benefit from sundry supremely powerful evolutionary adaptations.  I can't gush enough about how well designed this game is, how mentally stimulating it is and how much fun it is to play.  It is so mentally taxing that at times you wonder if you are at work solving important technical problems, yet the game is such a blast.  Dominant Species is a thrill ride that I found so enjoyable, I couldn't feel upset as another player delivered a devastating, crushing blow that wiped me entirely off the face of the Earth on the second round, which wasn't the end of the world or the end of the game for me because I could simply have new species emerge the following turn. If you are a serious tabletop gamer looking for an epic gaming experience, seek this game out.

RATING: 7
A typical area control game. Dominant Species has successfully combined with scientific theme. The game proceeds as following biological evolutionary phenomenon. This game is very logical, educational and provides dynamic interaction among players. However, the game has too many complicate details. Moreover, this game takes very long time. Usually, 4 players needs 4 hours to enjoy one single game. It is certain that Dominant Species give players a lot of fun and strategic varieties. Though, it is very complicated with its rule details which makes game too long. For this reason, I prefer El Grande, Samurai and San Marco, such like classical area contol games. In my opinion, these classical area influence games offers similar fun with Dominant Species in game mechanic and less downtime. If I choose to play area control games, I would rather not to select Dominant Species, but other classical area control games.

RATING: 9
Dominant Species can be mind-meltingly tough, but one cannot help but appreciate how beautifully it's put together. There are a lot of moving parts and a lot of things to keep in your head as the game plays out, but it all goes very smoothly and is really a pleasure to play. But, oh, it can be so nasty.

The only thing keeping it from a 10 for me is the utter strength of the Domination cards.  They're just a bit too strong, and they can cause huge swings in the game, obliviating any and all long-term strategy.

RATING: 9
An excellent game, though it's kind of ugly in its current form.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Dominant Species comes in a sturdy box, which is needed to hold all of that cardboard and timber! The design of the rulebook, board and other components is functional rather than aesthetic. Top marks for the rules, which are straightforward and very well-written. The game itself offers nothing very original in terms of individual mechanics, but is remarkable for its overall complexity - particularly in the sheer number of choices available to players. The many options can lead to a lot of downtime due to analysis and result in the game being rather too long given what it offers (there is barely any narrative development over the course of play and forward planning is difficult). Still, if you are prepared for the long haul then it can be a great gaming experience. One element of Dominant Species that does detract a little from it being a heavyweight gamer's game is the variability of the dominance cards, but this can be offset with some house rules.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Far too long (4+ hours) for the payoff, and we played with the variant that pulled  the action-adding cards.  Dear god, how long would this have been with them?

It seems like its got alot of moving parts, but the end-game scoring is all that really matters...I lost by 2 points at the end.

Chaos reigns.  I'm not looking for euro-chaos in a 4 hour game.  I'm looking for a sound rules-system that allows for solid choices to be rewarded and poor choices to be punished.  This game doesn't provide for either.

Highly, highly disappointed.

Also it can be hard for people to grasp workable strategies until they've played it a couple of times.

People's Choice Top 100 2012 #36
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Splendid.  Totally immersive game - smart, elegant and close to brilliant.  Great ideas in the rules - very thematic and integrated into the game in an excellent way.

Extremely clean rules for such a heavy game.

One of the most vicious games I've ever played.

--

Avoid the 5-player mode.  Too little control and only 4 action pawns to forge your destiny.  In contrast there are 5 action pawns with 4 players and 6 with 3 players.  Not only you feel like you want to do more/more types of actions, but addtionally this scarcity of APs gives you even less control (performing 4/20 of actions in a turn vs 5/20 of actions in 4-player mode vs 6/18 of actions in 3-player mode)…
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Wow what an ambitious and viscious game. Screwage in a way that would even make Kramer blush...lol well, maybe not but it sounded good. Really its a Euro, a themactic one but its one no doubt and laregly a Weuro at the same time, who knew Chad had it in him.

Kind of feels like AOEIII(worker placement similiarity) combined with Kramer's Wildlife (Theme, AC), at least that would be the easiest way to summarize it. Even if not entirely accurate if you like those two games you're in for a treat. 

Definitely some chaos and/or PIC present (not surprising considering the creator) with the large screwage elements, but it sure does make its way around. I was a little perturbed as everytime I setup a nice scoring area it got wiped out by a Tundra but I guess that's the point, Animals fighting over everything and the experienced player I was playing with knew enough to cut down bigger scoring chances. At any rate, I think I'll stick to 3 players for added control and game length though I'd try 4 once anyway, 6 player would be insane.

So if your comfortable with that kind of thing (like the Castillo in El Grande for example) then there is a lot to like in DS. A very thematic game where Area Control and Area Dominance (slightly different and a pain to constantly calculate with the dynamic boardstate) are both important and a very well done worker placement phase determines how the board will change. Very strategic and still largely tactical, you know mostly what things are coming up and the timing of them, the things you don't know though have to be adapted to and thanks to the order these actions take place, adapting is possible mostly IF somewhat anticipated. Even some of the things you do know, you DON'T know HOW they will be implemented, or where etc so count on some of your planning NOT turning out so well. This will make some pretty uncomfortable incl me, more experience will likely help, like in a game of Maharaja where anticipating is a BIG part of the game. 

I have to say it is fun to smash down a big populated territory you're not on. The ever changing board is somewhat of a marvel to watch. The varible powers asymetrical and interesting. Multiple ways to score with Tundra scoring becoming more and more important, this really ramps up the intensity and creates a nice arcing game as the Glacier spreads. Length easily modifed by playing a set number of rounds or removing some cards, though there could be some balance implications with that. I wonder if getting an extra "worker" early on is too powerful, especially compared to someone who doesn't get one at all or really late, almost has to be so probably good cards to remove to shorten the game, 2 birds. Overall very engaging, probably too long, chaotic BUT in a Kramer kind of way I believe, really want/need to play again soon. Rating could go up if strategies can indeed be executed with some amount of control but will likely stay at 8 or close for me. 

Oh, I'd put a picture in my comments too, but, nahh, what a way to clutter up the comments pages (imagine if we all started that, why? its a [i]comments[/i] section), really they belong in the reviews and PICTURES section anyway.  Edit - Ah hell if you can't beat em...

[IMG]http://netdna.copyblogger.com/images/bigbird.jpg[/IMG]

http://www.boardgamegeek.com/article/6427839#6427839
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I should love this: worker placement + area control + theme. But the design is clunky, in that it's a kitchen sink. It could do with 1/2 the mechanics. And those mechanics all come at a significant cognitive cost. It's not clear that that additional cost actually buys me any extra enjoyment, or challenge. Feld can get away with mechanics-mashups because his games don't overstay their time on the table. Doing it in a game of this length (in my experience, anyway) is nearly cruel.

Some people don't like how long it takes to play, and I am someone that normally avoids long games, but I am here to say that this game is WORTH EVERY SECOND.  Love, love love it!

RATING: 4

I think that Dominant Species is intellectually a very good game, and I understand why other people like it, but I would rather get punched in the testicles by Mike Tyson than play it again.

RATING: 4
Bearing in mind that I do not like area control or tactical games, I can cope just about with most of that in this game given that it comes with a lot of mechanichs that I typically enjoy (all the euro style mechanics that govern how the game plays). 

There is just too much going on to even have the slightest hope in anticpating what other players are going to do combined with what chits come out each round, so often you just have to make a good move at the time and hope.

The cards can be brutal/amazing/uninspiring depending on the game state, and unfortunately a little bit swingy.

Other than the cards, it's an excellent game, just not for me.

RATING: 4.5
Evo 2010

Pros: streamlined play, consistent rules, fun theme, nice board and bits (although it would be cool if it had species bits, not just cubes.)

Cons: Chaotic, kingmakery, chit pulls too important, endgame drag with finding best places to max VPs.

Takes a game to get the hang of everything--how things work and interrelate, what's important, knowing the cards. Everything makes "sense" at the very least.

Might play again, but not looking forward to it. Too long for such chaos. I'd certainly play better though.

I'd love to see a computerized version.

RATING: 8
Dominant Species is right at the limit for what I enjoy in a game when it comes to game length, aggressive interactions, and sweeping thematic events disrupting gameplay. I'm glad I'm fine with those qualities here, because Dominant Species is an exciting game full of tense decisions and clever design ideas. I especially enjoy the complexity of dealing with competing to select actions before they are carried out and dealing with the two forms of area control on each board space. It's an excellent choice for gamers itching for an intense and epic battle.

RATING: 6
A game with some nice parts, which initially seemed great.

However, the on-going calculations for dominance are a bit of a pain.  

The final scoring is awful, being largely calculable before the last couple of moves of the game - but those calculations taking so long that for a player to play optimally they should take the 5-10 minutes needed to do the maths, and then choose their move; then the next player should do the same etc...  I don't think I'd want to play the full game again, as I feel (I mostly do maths for a living) that I should be paid to play it.

And being pedantic - it's not a great match between theme and mechanics

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
First impressions after one game.

Some good stuff, but ultimately the game lies *way* over my tolerance threshold for arbitrary "screw you!" abilities, considering how long and analytical it otherwise is.

An uncomfortable hybrid of a dry, Caylus-like eurogame and an old-school AT "take that!" game, it falls between two chairs for me: I think the designer should have either toned down the dryness, making it more of a pure whinefest-style game, OR should have made it a game where your carefully laid plans stand a chance against the arbitrary strikes of the other players.

As it is, spending a lot of effort carefully formulating a plan, only to have to take off most of your action pawns unused, because the other players decided to target you exclusively this turn, is immensely frustrating.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Excellent, excellent game! Super simple rules that lead to some very tough decisions! Very aggressive. Every choice you make can make big, sweeping changes to the board that affect the game for a long time. 

I feel like the play time has been hugely over-reported. No game I've played has taken more than about 2h45. If it's taking your group four or five hours to play, then I think they're just WAY overthinking it. The game is all about getting BIG turns. There is some strategy, and there can be some big swings in endgame scoring, but I think the game is all about maximizing every point you can get this turn because there's honestly no telling what the next turn will bring! Half of your species might be entirely wipred out by then!

RATING: 8
Relatively meaty, but not as much as some people seem to think.  The random factors consist of what cards come out and what people do... but people do so much stuff, you need to just go with the flow of the game and focus on the big picture rather than looking at every single consequence of what you do; because everything else will be different.  Focus on the big ones, play around what the cards may do to you, and try and score points.  Much easier than some people make it out to be.  This is not a 5+ hour game.

RATING: 6
Fairly heavy. All actions are planned in advance and then executed in order and situation can change drastically very quickly, so often your actions you planned for later part of the round may not work anymore. RATING: 7
2011-10-13  

Initial Rating: 9.0 (June 2011)

Brilliant game, with more plays I believe it will crack my top 10 of favorite games.
This gem has the best aspects from 2 great games, Agricola (worker placement) and El Grande (Area control) creating a truly marvelous game.

The good: The game is a little complex (which I love) thus it requires a deep strategy, despite that the game runs smoothly and completely in synch with the theme (which is great). Each species has one key advantage making each game different.  The game is so well designed that everything is interrelated in the game; every choice counts and has a deep impact in in your survival. Totally absorbing.


The bad: The long play time makes hard for this game to hit the table more often. The components serve their purpose but I think they could have been prettier. 

In conclusion a truly gamer´s game and a must have for me.

Current Rating: 9.0

Current Rating: 9.0
[hr]
2015-09-11

After more plays I’m enjoying Dominant Species less and less. I have changed a lot during these years and I no longer enjoy the “take that” mechanism and Dominant Species has it in spades. Most players attack the perceived leader but sometimes they attack the weakest one as well because the retaliation is less dangerous.

With 6 players the game is too slow for me. I think its sweet spot is 4 players.

I still recognize that Dominant Species is a solid game and it is still among my favorite games, but it has fallen a lot for me.

One of 2010 favorites.
Ex game of the Year

Current Rating: 7.0
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Want to play
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I didn't like many of the earlier generations of area control games.  El Grande, for example, I rate highly out of respect than enthusiasm.  I find myself getting too invested in the areas I'm trying to score and annoyed with the extreme focus on positioning and timing.

Both Chaos in the Old World and Dominant Species get past this by adding another dimension of area control.  I'm frankly stunned that the solution to what I dislike about area control games is more area control.

In Dominant Species, the tension is between cube majorities, which affect the scoring, and "dominance," which is based on a set of up to six elements that are represented on one's player card and have matching symbols on the board.  This represents how well an animal is adapted to the resources a particular tile supplies.  Of course these resources can become more abundant or depleted through player actions.

The two-dimensional area control system makes for a much more engaging game than the old one-dimensional models, which tend to get static as players become entrenched.  It's difficult to become entrenched in Dominant Species, and even when one is entrenched on a particular tile the expanding glacier can swallow up the tile, making it near-worthless for scoring purposes.  Even then there is an interesting subgame regarding placement on tundra tiles that can yield big points over repeated turns.

I appreciate games with many paths to victory, and Dominant Species seems to deliver on that score.  In two games I've seen the following strategies pursued to some success:  aggressive glaciation, spreading and dominating low-scoring tiles for a big final domination score, under-speciating early so as to place cubes with impunity and make a big final turn score, survival, and attrition by depleting other players' cube supplies (which is basically a more aggressive variant of under-speciating).  It bodes extremely well that all of these strategies seem viable.

I'm already finding the permutations easier to calculate after two games; by five games in I'm hoping they become second nature.  My real concern is the game length and complexity.  I love heavy and epic games, so a 4-hour game doesn't bother me [i]per se[/i], but Dominant Species is an extremely busy game, with a lot of decisions and calculations to make.  As such it leaves me with a massive headache afterwards.  I can only hope this effect dissapates after a few games.  It will remain difficult, but not impossible, to fit in games of DS given my current life situation.

A strong 8, with room for improvement if it delivers as I expect it to over the next few plays.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7.5
Got this to play 2-player on some recommendations.  I am not sure on this one.  I have had the rule book out 3 times.  Hope to actually play this at some point.  Right now, it is all organized and ready to go, but I just can't get it to the table.  Overwhelming!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Updated rating to a 9 after first 4 player game. I don't think I'll want to play this as a 6 player again.

With 4, you have much more control, more options each turn and less downtime, allowing you to work with the game mechanics rather than just making the best of the few options you have as is the case with 6.

---------------------------------------------------

Two 6 players games in, and a few lessons learned. The first play ran to 3.5 hours and went well as everyone knew what the game was about before signing up for it and had at least skimmed the rules beforehand. 

Second 6p game was a scratch game prior to which only two of us had heard of the game, the others were primarily players of shorter Euros. They liked the gameplay but it ran to 5 hours which they thought was too long (I'd struggle to disagree). To generate a good game experience here I'd match the players to the game carefully, which will limit how often it hits the table.

That said it's a deeply absorbing game with a lot going on. There are a lot of (cohesive and thematic) mechanisms in here, none of which in isolation is complex, but taken together they create a sophisticated whole. 

The board evolves (sorry) rapidly in play, and what seems like a strong position can quickly crumble. I think you need to make a choice when playing this; do you want to consider deeply every single action you take against what the others might do, or go with the flow a little? If everyone takes the former approach it's going to run long.

However, interest is maintained throughout as just about any action taken by the other players has the potential to affect you.

Slight concern over the effect of the chit draws on such a long game. As the arachnid in my last game I only saw one grub chit (the one that favours the arachnid) come out for Abundance while I lost count of the number of water chits (which favour the amphibian player) that came out. Granted he played well, but in the end the amphibian player won at a canter. Not an issue in a 45 minute game, but over 5 hours it was a little frustrating.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

I suspect future plays would run closer to 3 and a half or four.  As a three or four player game you could probably wrap it up in under 3 hours assuming everyone has the rules down.  All things considered the rules themselves weren't that bad.  As a whole I would recommend this game but its not for all groups.  I would say this is a war game at heart with some euro type mechanics.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Has several pluses working in its favor. 1) Worker placement - nothing fancy, but executed well enough. 2) Random card draw - the various cards, of which you only see 5 per round, vary wildly in power. In addition, some cards are much better early in the game while others are better late in the game. Ideally, stay away from targets of the BAD cards, but it's much easier to say than do. The five cards available really set the tone for the upcoming worker placement round... and it's great! 3) Negotiation - the point track tells a small picture of the real score. It's up to the players to understand the true score and beat the appropriate leader. This game has become a staple in our group and will continue to see plenty of playtime.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Excellent hybrid of area control and worker placement, definitely would like to play again. Only reason it's not higher is because of the playtime, this can be managed by removing some of the dominance cards.

Every time I have played, the game play is so intense emotions run high. This is due to the Dominance cards in the game which essentially require you to play a bit rough, but always keep in mind your actions could come full circle the next round. Recommend, but not for the faint of heart.

RATING: 9
1st edition.  A highly interactive area-control/worker-placement game on a familiar theme we all know and love.  DS is a game of balancing inequities with attention to furthering your own agenda while at the same time thwarting those of your opponents. I for one like the overall appearance and understated look of this game that doesn't get confusing when additional tiles and components are placed.  We adjust the 'length' of play by eliminating several given Dominance cards and clearing the unclaimed cards from the board after each round, or....  simply limiting the number of APs.  

Rating is based on 2-player games (and one 3-player), we love this game...  9 for now.

UPDATE:  I'm noticing a subtle but definite tendency in our 2-player games towards competing for the Tundra tiles to score the Survival card as points increase exponentially beyond control of just 4 Tundras.  Not sure this is a good thing... (reminiscent of base-Dominion with gold/Provinces)  :/

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
DS is essentially a worker-placement driven majority game. The object is to collect the most victory points before the Ice Age comes. The heart of the game is the action menu, which takes up about 1/4 of the board. There is a large menu of possible actions on a turn. All actions are limited in number, so turn order is very important.

The game mechanics are not as complex has I feared, the action selection menu is very clear and no action is complicated in and of itself. But understanding the implications of an action is where it gets tricky. There's a split-level majority game - species (points) and elements (dominance cards) - and the element game is a complex one, with a constant shifting of needs and availability. You have a limited number of species for the game, so if you don't manage your stock well, you CAN run out before the game ends. You need to pay attention to the order of actions as well, since a previous action could negate the effect of a following action. It's all visible and above-the-board, so no random gotchas, but you do need to pay close attention or the actions of others WILL surprise you.

The game did not disappoint. There is so much going on in such a smooth mechanical structure that it is hard not to be impressed. 

UPDATE: Revisiting after a few years, I've downgraded this to an 8 due primarily to length. I think the game is really good and super engaging, but without dedicated or regular play, 4-5 hours is just too long. I have to knock this a point.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
reviews lezen, m.n. m.b.t. 2P
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
A solid multi-level area control game and probably my favorite of the genre. Mechanically driven by worker placement (WP), and wrapped in an interesting topic, Dominant Species utilizes the WP to encourage interaction rather than to avoid it. The use of multiple spots for most actions also means that players are less concerned about not being able to do an action but rather which actions to group together with limited pawns. This creates a nice trade-off between shooting for immediate results vs investing for future impact. Overall a good gamer's game. 

WIFE RATING/Comments - 7 
I like how different animals have different strengths although I do wish it was shorter.

RATING: 6
A rating of 6 after one play.  The degree of micromanagement is too much for me.  The worker placement thing is very like Age Of Empires III and Carson City but those games are quicker, more strategic (Dominant Species is generally tactical with less genuine different paths to tread) with much less analysis paralysis and much better integration with the theme.  I don't know why it bugs me, but I would like to know what the players represent in a game, and in Dominant Species there is no answer: at one level the players represent the types of animal, but at another the players represent the forces of nature.  In either case, I just don't think that you can satisfactorily have players representing impersonal, non-intelligent forces - it just does not work thematically.  The worst is the glacier that can somehow decide which way to go!  Dominant Species is a very decent, somewhat overlong game which works just fine with some clever mechanics but the theme questions just nag away at me.

RATING: 10
I love how the game forces you to constantly make choices between short-term gain and long-term investment. Just one example: element placement.  Place an element as far away from the tundra as possible to maximize its safety, or closer to give you more hexes you can live in but the element will be more vulnerable to glaciation?

 Very well-balanced and well-designed.  I like the way the game kind of "teaches itself" to you by starting off small and adding more and more hexes as interactions get more and more complicated.

Not entirely comfortable with the degree of luck in a game this long.  But, the game design is really ingenious, with the double layers of area control, balanced asymmetric powers, etc.

Record: 2 wins 1 loss
Won as:
Birds (5 players)(Sept 2011)(168)(18 point win!)
Reptiles (5 players) (July 2011)(133)(3 point win!)
Lost as:
Mammals (3 players) (Nov 2010)(2nd; 31 points behind winner; first game)

Purchase/trade note: get beautiful new edition!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A

Area Control, Card Drafting, Tile & Worker Placement

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Dominant Species may be the heaviest multiplayer title I've played. 

The game represents the masterful combination and refinement of some of gaming's most central concepts. It really is a thing to behold.  The game also creates an incredible sense of narrative along with an intensely challenging experience. My second play saw three species locked in a dire struggle to hold out against the coming Ice Age - my insects were nearly 80% extinct, and even the warmongering arachnids were spread thin (though triumphant). 

Let me describe DS "from the ground up." Players are building a modular board ("The Earth") made up of several habitat types: Sea, Wetland, Savanna, Jungle, Forest, Desert, and Mountain. Each type features a majority scoring scale as seen in the El Grande school of games. More points are available in richer, more habitable regions (Wetland for example), which can also support more biodiversity and so have more "places" in the scale, whereas a Desert offers fewer points and only two places. Players compete for majorities by piling species into a region (each cube is a species, and players represent a taxonomical class). Scoring, though, comes with a major twist. 

At each vertex on the map, an "element" chit is placed. These represent food sources and environmental conditions, essentially customizing the particular qualities of any given habitat. Each of the six animal classes begins the game adapted to two elements (for example, the mammals are meat eaters, the insects thrive in grassy areas, etc). As the game progresses, animal classes evolve and adapt to new elements, making them more suited to live in particular regions of the board. A species that is best adapted to a region is said to be "Dominant," and this is distinct from a simple numerical majority. Think of it this way: the insects in your house probably outnumber you, but they're not exactly the Dominant Species in your habitat. The game is representing that distinction with the two-fold competition for numbers and adaptability. 

There are five main scoring opportunities per round. A player who claims one of them will pick a region on the map to score (based on majorities), but the [i]Dominant Species[/i] in that region (the best adapted) then gets to select a special card from an available row. These cards are very powerful, so it's often not worth it to score a region you're not Dominant in, even if you have the majority there. This creates fascinating positional play on the board. 

That's the heart of the game. Modular board (six regions at the start, and up to three per turn added in what is usually a 5-6 turn game); two-fold majorities. Player actions are drafted a la Caylus, and these include the ability to evolve your species, to add new elements to the board (and sometimes remove them), to score, to add new regions to the board, to migrate species (move them around between habitats), and to eliminate your opponents' species. Turn order is important, and can also be adjusted in small steps. Since the game is about the onset of an Ice Age, once per turn the Glacier will further encroach upon the various habitats, scattering the species living there and potentially destroying some of that regions elements. Controlling the Glacier can be very powerful, and being the "Survivor Species" (the one with the greatest presence on the tundra) can also be a worthwhile way to score. 

There's a ton going on here; like I said, it may be the heaviest game I've played. Each individual piece is accessible and easy to conceptualize, but effective play is difficult. My one quibble with the game is that, at the far end of the action-drafting, it crosses over into a permutations game not unlike Chess, in which the volume of if-then considerations exceeds any other non-abstract board game I can think of. This does not undermine the rest of the game for me, but it's the one place in the design where I'm withholding my seal of approval. Permutations-gaming is a very specialized branch of the hobby, and one that doesn't mix well with any other variety of tactics and strategy. 

Bottom Line: one of the most inspired, ambitious, and developed designs in years. For many it will be too ambitious for its own good; for some it will be love at first sight.  

[b]Update:[/b] 3 plays in and I continue to find this enjoyable, but the ridiculous forward thinking is "a bridge too far" in my book. Admirable title but it will never be among the best for me.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
This takes an animal development theme, adds worker placement and majority control, and creates a very coherent engaging experience.

Its strength is its weakness.  On the one hand you've got two things going on.  The worker placement phase controls what you can do, and offers strategic play and agonizing decisions.  Then when you execute the actions you picked, you've still got lots of good tactical meat - where do I move my cubes, which elements do I want to promote and where...

The weakness is that with both modules demanding thought, the game takes a long time to get through.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Excellent worker placement / area control hybrid.

Card effects balanced against board position and scoring make for a rewarding game. The game state is never static and care needs to be taken over the cards and how best to combat or nullify the effects against your position.

Highly interactive and strangely thematic in the integration of its mechanics.

Avoid AP prone players, although nowdays we can be done within 2 hours 4 players.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
What. A. Game!  The "10" experience starts when you first pick up the box and feel it's substantial weight.  Then you peal off the plastic and open it up to find an incredible assortment of wooden bits, great quality cardboard markers and a wonderfully designed board.  Then you start to read the rules and are amazed by the subtle mechanics and substantial weight contained within.  
   Right from the beginning you can sense the struggle of these ancient animal species trying to survive primitive earth's encroaching ice age.  As you put yourself in the position of your species trying to survive, you intuitively sense when they need new food sources, or if they should migrate away from a risky location to take advantage elsewhere.  Do you ally with your strengthening/weakening neighbour or do you attack their strongholds?  
   A wonderfully complex yet simple game where player interaction occurs at nearly every step.  I would only suggest that you play this with your more serious gaming friends.  It suffers from a long play time, and if someone is not "Into" it, they will be sure to remind everyone else at the table.
   I. Love. This. Game.

---
It didn't catch my attention when it was on P500 but luckily early reports were very good. Otherwise I would have missed a great game. At its core, it is worker placement coupled with area majorities but as can be expected from GMT and Chad Jensen, it's not your run of the mill eurogame. Far more theme, far longer, far more conflict. This is what I like to play when I have 5 hours to emerge in an epic adventure. Forget about the ameritrash classics or Fantasy Flight coffin games.
From now on, I will watch Chad Jensen's new games closely. Combat Commander already was a pleasant surprise in a genre I usually don't enjoy too much and Dominant Species backs the trend.

RATING: 9
I've only played this with three. Three was a wonderful number for this game. I love the way that your turns are very fast and the difference between point scoring and domination make for a very interesting balance between population building and adaptation/abundance. It is so coated with theme. I really have a hard time believing that GMT are the ones that put out this game. It is definitely made from the same production line as their other games, but it seems so unique in its theme and mechanics. 

All of the actions in the game are useful, and there are interesting ways that players are punished for ignoring parts of the game. The player interaction is high, and both games I've played ended up with a player seeking revenge on another player. Hilarious!

My favorite part of the game are the cards. They are hugely thematic, nuanced, and dictate a lot of the strategy for the specific turn.

RATING: 8
Held out for a long while on this one, but having now played, I think I was mistaken to have done so. only played with 2p (no variant) so far, and expect that the game would be better with 3 or 4 or possibly more. There's a lot going on, and we botched some rules or remembered and then forgot them, but it all should be more manageable with a bit more experience. Typically tight Jensen rulebook--clear, concise, well illustrated, and just the right level of redundancy to clarify and remind without wordiness. The mats/player aids, though probably superfluous for the experienced, are good for newbies. Once the rules are (mostly) down, the focus can be on the gameplay, as it should be. Current (3rd+) edition is attractive and well laid out. If there's one complaint about the presentation, it's the cones, which are difficult to grasp owing to their shape and texture.

RATING: 8
I have thoroughly enjoyed this game, which seems to bypass many of the problems that long and heavy games can often have.  Though it is longer than most of the games we play, the rules are relatively easy to explain and seem more or less intuitive.  There seems to be a lot of variability in the Domination cards that come out, and while there can be big swings, I don't feel that luck (in the Domination cards) plays too big of a role.

I like the theme of the game, though the artwork is fairly bland and uninspired.  Still, as you're playing it doesn't make that big of a difference.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Essentially a worker placement game with two area-controls to manage on the map. Players are juggling their species and their "elements" and trying to expand both to score the most points. Very minimal strategy and planning because everything changes when it gets back to you, so the downtime is pretty bad.

The game itself is fairly straightforward, but definitely too long for what it is.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
I liked the theme because my wife is a biologist specializing in genetics.  I was looking forward to the game until my first (and likely only play).

In the game (a five player game), 3 of the cards that came up were ones that gave you extra actions.  These were hotly contested and pretty much went to player order.  I ended up with my original 4 cylinders while the rest of the players had 5 and one player (the only "experienced" player had 6 cylinders.  I estimated that there were probably 10 rounds or more in the game, so I'll have 40 actions compared to 60 actions for that one other player.

My thinking was that I lost, 10 minutes into a 5 hour game.  The experienced player kept telling me that the extra actions were not that good.  That the 50% more extra actions he got was not that much of an advantage.  This just made me more aggravated.  And he kept picking on my cubes on the board, removing them because I was easy pickings.  I asked to resign from the game, but the experienced player refused--saying that it would totally screw up the game.

So for about 75% of the game, I didn't even have a dominant area so I couldn't pick a card at all.  Any time I had a chance at an area, he came and squashed me with his extra actions.  I pretty much played kingmaker at the end against this "experience" player which I don't normally do, but I was pretty furious over the game.

I kept getting advice and comments which further make me dislike the game.  The winner of the game told me the main strategy was to spread out as much as possible on the last turn.  If that is true, why even bother with playing the 4.5 hours?

The core problem in my mind is are the extra action powerful or not?  If they are powerful, then the extra action cards early in the game will break the game.  If the actions are not powerful, then the game is too chaotic.

Note that my opinion is likely to be colored by playing at BGG.CON and felt like I wasted 5 hours of precious Con time.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Complex. Absorbing. Takes hours longer to think through than it should. Late Fellini? No, Dominant Species.

The array of choices is stifling in this game - there are so many options that it can be quite tough to figure out, but Dominance is almost always the best action, and especially with four, it's going to be the one you want to hop into first place in turn order to take. Beyond that - well, good luck, son. 

DS suffers slightly from the same problem I found with Innovation: it can be a little tough to craft a solid strategy when by the time it's your turn again the situation you face on the board will often be completely different. This is mitigated by the action selection, which allows you to distribute your actions pretty carefully. On the other hand, the choices are so difficult and there's so much mental math re. sequence and who-will-do-what that you end up taking twenty minutes to figure out what to do with a single action sometimes.

I don't think that's necessarily a vice, though, just a sign of a game that's adaptable to a reasonable range of strategies. The cards can prompt wild point swings, but gameplay generally won't. All in all, I think this is a fine entry in the burgeoning series of GMT non-wargames, but it may be more good than fun.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9.5
Heavy area control game where you are balancing two types of area majorities, your number of species in a zone and how well adapted you are for survival in that zone. The worker placement aspect is amazing and makes the game have a logical progression each round as actions are resolved in order from top to bottom, all available actions are on the board so it's actually quite easy to teach. Best at 5 or 6 players, 3-4 hours.

RATING: 6
Okay game.  Very confusing rules relating to regression, wasteland, and depletion makes the gameplay slow, awkward and clumsy.  The player aid that explains the game play steps is written in small type which is difficult to read easily.  The answer is to pick up the aid to read it but this isn't easy because your animal's element tokens are supposed to be kept on this card.

Perhaps multiple plays and familiarity with the game will solve this problem but how often will I sit down to this game with experienced players only?  And besides, the game isn't that compelling or interesting to make me want to spend the time to become familiar with it.  I'd play this again if others truly wanted to but otherwise, I don't need to play this again.  There are plenty of other games of this type which are better.

RATING: 10
