RATING: 7
After a few more plays, my rating has gone down. It's not a bad game, there's just a lot going on and I'm not convinced it's entirely necessary. The main function of a lot of the choices seems to be to make the game go forever if you get stuck with a player who thinks through every option on their turn. I can get the same experience out of Age of Empires III, which has quite a few similarities to Dominant Species, in a much quicker time.

------------------------------------
It's a lot of fun to play, but my gut feeling is that the elements that turn up for the various options affect who wins more than player actions. That's only after a couple of plays though, and I may be wrong.

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
(Rating after many plays)

If I were a fan of worker placement euros I'd rate this game 11/10. Since I'm more into wargames I give Dominant Species 7.5/10. The game is engaging and entertaining, but it is also very dry. It seems thematic at first but during game you realize that you're just optimizing cube placement, not commanding animals. So far I played only 2 and 3 player games and I wouldn't play with more than 4 players. I guess the game would be too random with too long downtime.

One thing I dislike a bit (aside from being dry) are the dominance cards. These are very strong and for inexperienced players like myself can completely change the outcome of the game. I am certain though that experienced players can learn the cards and play as to mitigate their effects.

UPDATE: Rating goes up after some more plays. A really good game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 4

I want to really like this game.  Hoping to give it another shot with more time dedicated.  We shall see...

UPDATE:
One more time through and I think I may have to let this one go.  What I initially thought was an elegant game has become a fiddly mess.  Constantly needing to assess Dominance is no fun at all... especially when you have to factor it in for many tiles when elements are removed and such.  Leads to long down time. 

It never got to be as fun as I hoped it would be.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Dominant Species combines so many elements that I love into a game that almost defies description. It has variable player powers, a variable hex map that's created as you play the game, variable resource placement, a strong area control dynamic, dynamic event cards, and an incredible decision tree for worker placement. The big downside to DS is the three hour playing time, and that's if everyone already knows how to play. If if played more quickly, this could easily be a 9 or a 10, but the truth is that the long playing time keeps this game from hitting the table very often.

RATING: 8.5
What’s not to like. Area control (al la El Grande), action selection (al la Age of Empires III) and variable player powers all blended together for a very good (if not great) game. Although I like it quite a bit, there are a few concerns: end of game scoring can be huge. Inexperienced players will focus on the player(s) ahead on the score track during most of the game, but they are not necessarily the ones to be concerned with. The cards can certainly have a big impact on the game, but the bigger factor (IMHO) is the random element draws which can be a big factor that is hard to plan or prepare for.  Sweet spot appears to be with 3-4 players.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
For me, this is very close to a perfect game.  I couldn't wait to play after reading the rules ... partly because I'm interested in the science of behavior and adaptation.  The way the game mechanics and the theme support each other is outstanding.  Our "game day" group of four played it twice yesterday and even though I got crushed the first game (every one else lapped me on the VP track), I am still loving the game.  Only after playing it twice am I starting to understand how much the game is about adaptation.  The randomness provided by the drawing of the elements, tiles, and cards are what give the game its strength and what reinforce its theme.  The earth is ever-changing and one must adapt or die.  We used the random set up for the 2nd game and two players had no species on the board to start the game, yet one of them found a path to victory.  Can't wait to play again.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
The kingmaking is the only real downside to an otherwise almost perfect game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8

RATING: 8
Oh man this sounds so interesting.
Probably will have a hard time getting it to the table however

Comment from geekbuddy John Bandettini

I think if you want to play Dominant Species in a shorter time you (well everyone really, not picking on you Charles ) need to have a mind set adjustment. Don't play it like a Euro, play it like a war game.

What I mean is don't fret about the small stuff. In a typical euro, you get a limited number of actions, waste a couple of them with bad plays and you will probably lose the game. With a war game your overall strategy is more important than any individual move.

If you think of it that way, you can get through turns a lot quicker, you are not looking for a perfect move every turn just trying to advance your strategy. With this mind set my group are playing the game in around two and a half hours and still enjoying the game a lot.

edit
finally played it. It took us over four hours which was too long.

I played the mammals which probably means you have to stage a comeback ( i didn't score the first two rounds)
I was succesful profiting from steve's insects and beating him on the tiebreak.

edit 2 :second game

amphibians but very little water appeared (abundance or wanderlust)  and the glaciation was over the water at the start.
Infact I think they are a pretty weak species if there is little to no water around. (I addedd water when I had the chance..

Mammals won again 168 points. BIrds second 153 points , amphibians 151 points. Spiders 125 points.

RATING: N/A
Dominant Species is a game that abstractly recreates a tiny portion of ancient history: the ponderous encroachment of an ice age and what that entails for the living creatures trying to adapt to the slowly-changing earth. 

Each player will assume the role of one of six major animal classes -- mammal, reptile, bird, amphibian, arachnid or insect. Each begins the game more or less in a state of natural balance in relation to one another. But that won’t last: It is indeed "survival of the fittest."

RATING: 7
This game is probably more complex than it needs to be while including cards with effects so devastating that they seriously reduce long term player agency.  There's a fair amount of bashing the leader and too much chaos for serious planning.  The core is very interesting and if feels like there is a spectacular game somewhere in there, but it's drowned in tedium, cruft and overlong play.  There's a lot of room for human error (forgetting phases, miscalculating domination, etc.) with easily game breaking consequences.  State of mind plays a large role I suppose.  You have to be in a mood for some chaos, having to constantly adapt and scrap your plans, roll with punches, take what you get and make the best of it.  I can see how this game gathered a lot of momentum and following, but it doesn't really do it for me.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
I don't know what is the fuss about this game, but it seem people like awkward and inconvenient games. That are thing I generally want to solve in my game design rather than proposing them as features.

First, if you are color blind, avoid this game at all cost. Because you have 3 color level of analysis: first the terrain color, second the resources color, and third the players color.

All these levels of information made it impossible for me to analyze the board. It's just too complex, and if you are partially color blind, you cannot see relations in a glance like some other players could probably do. So you are constantly re-evaluating every hex without being able to find what is your best move.

Then considering that there are dozens of actions + special power cards, the choices are so overwhelming, that it was impossible for me to plan anything. 

So I simply played the bad guy, took control of glaciation and resources depletion all of the time.

Oh! and by the way, the game's artwork sucks badly. I mean, I am not an artist and I can do better. So please, it does not take a lot of effort to have something acceptable.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
If it not for the fiddliness and time-consuming tasks of keeping track of dominance for every tile and so forth, I would rate it a 7.  Also, since thematically Dominant Species has similarities to Ursuppe (Primordial Soup), but I would much rather play the latter.  Ursuppe seems more streamlined and more fun.  Dominant Species has some fun chaos elements but it is low in strategy and high in tactics.  Ursuppe has higher strategy and slightly lower tactics.  Plus, in Ursuppe, I can let my ameobas take a dump and tell my friends to go eat my $H!T... :)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
LIKES:

* I like that each animal brings a special ability to the game.
* While the majority vs domination concepts can be confusing the first play, this really brings a fascinating parallel competition/game to the game.  One is almost playing two different games at the same time although there is some relation between the two.  
* The 12 or so different actions really bring out the flavor of the game and can really swing rounds like crazy both in regard to domination and majorities.  
* When one scores a tile using the domination action, not only does the tile score points, but the person who has domination must choose and play a card that often can effect future scorings in the same round.  Finding combinations that work well here are just fun and interesting.  Another fascinating twist is that the majorities leader may not be the domination leader and either person could select to score the hex!  I love incentive based games.
* When your species cubes are removed from the tiles for any reason other than glaciation, they are actually removed from the game.  This can lead to a cube shortage for majorities!
 
DISLIKES:
* It is confusing to many people the concept that each cube is a species.  Just make sure to hammer the concept home that when one reads/hears species, it refers to ONE cube.
* While this isn't a negative per se, this game will take 4-5 hours the first time you play.  While it is straightforward to play, there is a lot to take in and think through while playing and choosing your actions.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: N/A
https://www.rebel.pl/product.php/1,302/19597/Dominant-Species-4th-printing.html
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
VERY TENTATIVE initial impressions. Also, I love the theme, and so I am probably pretty biased. I love the combination of euro mechanics with a war game area control that gives it plenty of meaningful interaction. Obviously there is spatial strategy in area control of having majority where you're scoring while being parasitic to get residual points when your opponent scores regions you are in. However, there is also planning out how other people's actions will affect the board by the time you can resolve one of your own actions, giving a strategic feel similar to turn order manipulation.

Despite the many actions you can take this game's flow is still fairly smooth, as long as you don't have anyone too AP-prone. The basic concepts of the game are actually quite simple, it's just playing optimally that makes it a brain burner. Also, I like that despite the huge variety of spots the worker placement still feels fairly tight, as in you can meaningfully block someone off from a spot they want, or snipe an element token they were gunning for.

Despite my normal dislike of cubes to represent units the theme is really evoked in this game. Each animal class feels very different due to their ability to expand onto regions with different elements. I really like the customization of evolving your species, while it makes sense that you would have to spend energy (or actions) to have your gene pool retain adaptations, as for example growing webbed feet or something to be further adapted to the water should expend more energy from a biological standpoint. The actions that terraform the land gives an environmental theme to the game. While I'm not sure why the elements that were previously abundant suddenly disappear from the Earth (maybe they were too fertile and led to a crash in the ecosystem?), tundra only being able to encroach on adjacent territory adds theme both in the growing dread of the encroaching ice age and also that areas adjacent to previous tundra should be more likely to turn into tundra, especially if they are surrounded by tundra. It's thematic that it would harder to speciate in harsher biomes, and that biomes with more resources could support more diversity (more animal classes can score) and more life in general (more points). Wanderlust I am not so sure thematically because it would seem more beneficial to be in a corner away from other animal classes so that you can have no competition, but I think it is better mechanically. That you can't split up your movement points anyway you like may seem odd compared to most games, but again it makes sense that each species can only migrate so far in a given time. The scoring of having a lot of species in a region while having a leg up if you're best adapted to a region to me doesn't make perfect sense thematically (I feel like dominance should score more points than just the ice age but shouldn't be able to perform random catastrophes), but I do like how you become endangered if you're not adapted to a region at all, and that you get bonus points for roughing it out by living in the tundra.

The cons are it seems like you need the corresponding counterparts to each species to balance the game and I think it would be thematic if the different biomes started with elements relevant themselves (for example, the desert starting with sun), although that would probably really affect the game's balance.

EDIT: This game can cause AP pretty badly, and in that case drags the game out a bit too much. However, my sentiments that otherwise this is a tense (in that you constantly have to work to avoid your species from getting eliminated from specific regions), interactive, thematic Euro with a theme that is terribly underutilized remain. It can be rather tactical depending on how you play, but I like just how a predator you must opportunistically pounce on weak points in your opponents or zones you foresee your opponents being weak in, while still rewarding some long term planning in the genes and what can regress, etc.

EDIT 2: After my 4th game of this which took 5 hours the AP aspect is really starting to wear me out. This is a great 3 hour game, not so much when it is longer. I'm still keeping it at an 8 because I think it could shine with the right group, but my willingness to play with my current group is about a 5 right now. Since there are usually only 6 rounds in the game even over these 4-5 hours, even if you don't fall behind until the last round that is still 45ish minutes where you have to sit through. Also, the swinginess of a lot of actions in this game (dominance cards, preventing wasteland, etc.) really seems to rely on players to value things correctly or correctly identify who is a threat when, which can make the game quite frustrating (whether or not either player is valuing things correctly or not is besides the point, more that people can screw each other over without even realizing it).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
LOVE IT!!  But too long and difficult to bring out to casual gamers.  Need to be gamers to enjoy :
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
One of my favorite heavier games, and an area control game like no other.  There are so many factors to consider, so many way to tweak things into your favor.  2 distinct phases of the game: all of the planning and jockeying for position, and then the resolution where you change your mind on the fly to do with what you prepared because the situation has inevitably changed.    Perhaps best of all, the mechanics/actions all perfectly match the theme, rare for such a game, IMO.  Specialization? adding more species to the board.  Regression? losing adaptations to the environment on the board. Etc, etc.

NOT a game for people with AP, and having to keep recounting strength on regions can be a bit mathsy.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.75
Dominant Species is a fun game. Easy to learn and hours of fun. Personally I have only played 2 player which, from what I have gathered, is not the best way to play. Still the game is fun. You must set tokens down to determine the way the turn unfolds. Your species has to survive being eaten, frozen and essentially adapt to the constantly changing game board. With six species to pick from, each with their own special ability, you must struggle to survive against people and the environment.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Really the game is about area majority, set collection that results in majorities in adjacent "elements" for bonuses, and of course the main mechanism is worker placement. There is quite a bit of information, almost overwhelmingly so at first. You soon realize that you only need to focus on what you need and what will affect you. That boils each round down to a hand full of actions and a much more manageable amount of information.

Tentative 7 after we called the game 2/3 of the way through our first play. We want to play again. We played with 3 and I think the game will be better with more, while 3 might be best played with experienced players or the latter and all players using 2 animals.

I've read quite a bit about the end game scoring and given the volume of points that you gain, not to mention the game seems to be about gearing up for the end, we obviously missed a huge part of the game. We learned quite a bit, so it wasn't for naught. Perhaps another play will prove this a great game, or as it stands just an ok game that I had high hopes for.

Update:

Another play with 5 eliminated all my doubts and frustrations with DS. The game is brutal, requires detailed and abstract planning, and is almost completely unforgiving. Skilled players actually do have a chance to catch up and the game provides avenues to do so. 

It's a shame that Mr. Jensen's games require several plays to simply understand the actual goals and the important aspects of the game. Some people might view that as part of the discovery but it certainly makes players feel lost and somewhat helpless in initial plays. 

It's quite a game, easily in the top three heaviest games I've ever played, and with subsequent plays threatens to push into my top ten of all time.

One of our meatier games. Good but it burns most of the evening so it does not come out that often.

RATING: 9
[microbadge=7][microbadge=5]

This game is like a cross between Caylus and Die Macher, and as much of a brain-burner as the two of them multiplied.  The different animals are clever and unique, and the action display design is ingenious. Teaching the game is also relatively simple for a game of this nature. However, with the full six players, tactics are confined and chaos is ramped. Four is probably a better sweet spot for this game. Overall, brilliant.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This is a heavy worker-placement area-control game.  Some label it a war-game disguised as a euro because there is plenty of "take that".  Brilliantly designed; can be quite chaotic and dynamic, which a good player will manage.  

It has the feel of "El Grande" and "Tammany Hall", but even more nasty, and with a well-integrated worker-placement mechanism.  Deep as well as complex, highly interactive and engagingly tense.  Surprisingly well balanced given the asymmetric animal abilities.

[q]Chad Jensen suggests removing the following cards for a quicker game:  Intelligence, Parasitism, Omnivore and Immigrants. [/q]

Even taking out these cards, a recent 4-player game took two sessions and about 6 hours, including about 1 hr for teaching.  But two of our players were quite slow in taking their turns--if everyone would have played at my average speed, game length would probably been have cut down to 2-3 hours after teaching.  Plan well for board position at game-end scoring, where VP swings of 50-100VP are possible.

Not terribly difficult to grasp, and it is even intuitive once one gets the hang of this.  It can flow quite nicely when people keep their head in the game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.7
The winner of the game can be completely determined by luck, and you are sometimes forced to beat down on players who are in last place, which risks making the game un-fun for them.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.7
Feels like it rewards just wailing on one player.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Perhaps the single most mentally demanding game I've played.  Definitely hangs out at the deep end of the pool.  But it's very impressive as a model of evolution and population growth, the player interaction is very strong and the number of choices and factors to consider is dizzying.  If the rating is low, it's because I can't see playing it all that often; it's just heavier than I'd like.  And I wish the design was a little more polished and fleshed out.  But it's an impressive game, no doubt.

RATING: 8.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This is one of the most conceptually interesting games I've ever played. Mechanically it's just a  super-involved worker placement game, but what's neat is that the actions the player has to chose from are designed so that they mimic the actual laws of natural selection that were in operation just before the last great ice age. If there's another game that's a more faithful attempt to model the world as described by high-level scientific generalizations, I've certainly never come across it. 

The extremely complex interaction of selective forces that take place as the game progresses makes it very difficult to tell at any particular stage of play who's got the edge, but the best response to this is to just watch the whole thing unfold and never mind about who wins.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 5
A long game that just became too repetitive for me. I also agree with many who call it chaotic.  While not wildly out control, things so rapidly change you are forever recalculating areas to determine dominance. It just ends up being too much fiddling around.
Seems like it's about 1/3 too long.
Plus, for me, there are better games out there that fill this nitch for me and play faster with less chaos and  that reward good planning and execution. Lastly, the cards can throw the balance way off- maybe not every game, but they serve to add more chaos in my opinion.
As for removing cards to shorten the game I would be concerned as to how it may unbalance the game even more and make it harder for certian players to be competitive.

Glad I tried it out, not sure I'd run back to the table to play again though.

RATING: 8.5
La glaciacion esta cerca y la cadena alimenticia se prepara para adaptarse o morir. Seria un buen resumen para explicar a grosso modo en que consiste este juego.

Cada jugador toma el rol de una especie, que luchará por prevalecer sobre las demás en el mayor número de zonas del tablero. Para ello, deberá adaptarse a los diferentes tipos de terreno, a los ataques del entorno y de los demás jugadores.

Es un juego que comienza a disfrutarse cuanto más se juega (de primeras puede resultar criminal).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Great theme, great execution, but I’m loath to judge a game as rich and complex as this after just two runs. What can be said is that everything flows very nicely and intuitively, that drab appearance does not preclude a game from being thematically satisfying and that any chaos due to overly strong action cards is strongly damped down by the public knowledge of what’s available in a given round.

The strategic possibilities revolving around the adaptation of your flock to the current world map on the one hand and the changes of the world on the other hand are absolutely engrossing and might turn out to be my favorite part of the game. Incidentally, the potential for devastating moves on this front is bigger than for the action cards, especially if someone has put all of his eggs into one element type basket.

Griping about take-that cards would be appropriate if they were arbitrarily dropped into your enemy’s hands, but this ain’t the case here - if you see a card coming up that’s particularly harmful you, preventing it is usually possible, if pricey.

Hopefully, I’ll get to play this a couple more times during the coming weeks, since I’m optimistic that it could be great and not merely good.

RATING: 8
This has probably replaced Power Grid for me as my go-to heavy Euro game. It seamlessly mixes area control with worker placement, and the asymmetrical player abilities tend to encourage each player to employ different strategies (without any ability seeming particularly overpowered). 

My main complaint with this is the leader runaway. It's not a huge deal, but when a game lasts 3-4 hours long and you realize you have no chance of winning halfway through, it can be really annoying and unpleasant to have to play out the next 2 hours.

RATING: 4
It is not always good for a game to provide many choices. In this game, there is just too many choices, too many things going on - every action makes significant changes so planning ahead is almost impossible.

First I was attracted by the theme, but actually, this game was thematically poor. What does "Dominance" represent? And how does it enables species to use special power(dominant card)? How the competition occurs? A spider eats a snake? Then what does the food chain represent? Why is it irrelevant to competition and relevant to scoring?

In short, this games was unsatisfying both strategically and thematically.

RATING: 6.5
I've had an opportunity to play this a few times to the end, which given the lengthy play time is not an easy task.  The game is not as complex as it may appear at first glance, and there is definitely a lot of strategy involved.  The main drawback is the constant counting and calculating that is involved with keeping track of 'domination'...I feel the game could have been streamlined a bit more and an alternative (quicker/simpler) mechanic for domination should have been studied.  Semantics also tended to throw us off as the word dominance and domination were used frequently in the rules to explain totally separate mechanics.  Overall I felt it slightly overrated and don't know how often it will get played.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Dominant Species requires players to bring their subgroup of animals, whether they be mammals, insects, reptiles, etc., into pre-eminence on the board/earth.

This involves making lots of choices as to what types of food your group can eat, what kinds of environments they can live in, how many cubes to place and where to place them, and many others.  By the way, cubes represent various species within your animal group, but not animals themselves, confusing right?  While trying to think all this through players also have to be wary of other animal groups moving in on their territory, ice formations making certain areas practically uninhabitable, and various other disasters.

Dominant Species is a very very thinky game.  This makes it also a long game.  I like the idea of it.  I appreciate the mechanics of the game.  It was interesting to play, and I'm glad I did...once.  I say once, because I never felt like I was having fun while playing.  I felt like I was doing work.  So, as much as I appreciate the thought that went into creating Dominant Species, it's just not for me.  I play games to have fun, and hopefully in a shortish amount of time.  This one isn't short, or fun for me.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Very smart design. I would rank it even 10 but stupid cards spoil the game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.3718
Excellent, engrossing, extremely entertaining.  Lots going on.  The rules are simple, but the game is not. Seems more tactical than strategic.  The rule book is excellent, fine tuned and with laser precision in describing the game.  Lots of nice touches in design (starting tiles, chits and player markers, for example) shows an attention to detail to which more games should strive.  

On the down side, analysis paralysis is a definite possibility, particularly with new players.  There are opportunities for a player to score huge points that may not be immediately evident to new players, which can give the experienced player a distinct advantage.  But even then, the game is just so damn good and fun.

After a few more plays, bumped up the rating a smidge.  I hate this game -- some of the choices you're forced to make are agonizing.  But that's a good thing.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I left more details on some review threads but can sum it up here:
Beautiful artwork, board, and components
	Note: highly split on editions – many love 1st ed, others hate it (and vv for new edition). I love the original. 

Best manual to date – concise, great use of pictures and examples, pretty. 

The theme is well done and it’s a good thinking game. 

The bad:
Holy crap is it long. And it feels long. Some variant talk about removing the cards (or using them as points only) to speed things up. I’m still toying with the idea of removing Wasteland and Depletion as well – it’s that long. 

Bash the leader. Just don’t like that in games. Variant suggestion would be to use hidden pt chips instead of public track. 

Was so hoping for this to be great, and it could be with a few tweaks.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
[b]2015-04-23 9.7[/b] After 3 Plays
[b]2016-04-02 8[/b] After 5 Plays:
Very strategic games but takes a very long time to play. Really enjoy how strategic it is as players have the power to improve their own adaptability and control the environment. The dominance calculation is a bit fiddly and changes a few times during a round. The game play is very cutthroat but it is all open information and there is no backstabbing. Definitely a game that requires many more times to make less mistakes. Adjusting score to normalize against new scale and also to lower for the long play time.

Since everything is open info, players have a tendency to evaluate for others what the best moves might be in both scoring and use of dominance cards. Happened in almost all of the games so far, much more frequently than any other games I played with the same players.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Your 'state' will swing, and you will need to tactically respond to that, but there are still some underlying strategies to be employed. Its not perfect, its a bit dry and abstract and LONG, but you will be engaged the entire time.

RATING: 9.5
This game is simply amazing. Perfect blend of chaos, confrontation, area control, worker placement, and strategy, in a beautifully stunning game. It is long, but absorbing. Every move changes the environment and the other species. You must plan but be willing to change plans at a moment's notice. I think I really like that this super deep game does not require counting every point and can be played very intuitively instead. One of my favorite games for design, theme, conflict, and mechanics. It is just too long to get out often and most casual gamers would be overwhelmed. Do not play with AP prone players.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
nice game of establishing control on a playing board of hexes.  Fight for scoring control (most cubes on a hex), and dominance (most matching ecosystems and adaptations) on the board.  Manipulate many aspects of the game via the various phases of the game turn.  Each player has only a limited number of actions they can take each turn, and figuring out which is the best is not easy.

I like it, but could see a problem of downtime if playing with some real AP prone players.  

Note that the complaints of graphic design are off in my opinion - the different shapes make evaluating the board very easy.  I find it looks very nice, and I dont think plastic spiders would make it any better.

RATING: 4
I'm starting to develop a list of games that would probably be great if you played a lot with the same group of people, and Dominant Species is one of those games. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
07/26/14 Played 6/7's of a four-player game (fourth printing, I think) in 4.75 hours. 
Dominant Species was even longer than I'd anticipated. The phases of the turns were logical, but there were just too darn many of them. That's what caused all the analysis paralysis and turned what could have been a 2 hour game into a 5 hour affair. I've played several "evolutionary" themed games (Evo, Wildlife, Urland, Primordial Soup, to name a few). None of them took half this long, yet they retained a great amount of theme and strategy. Dominant Species might be a good game if about half the 15 steps in a turn were eliminated/combined. These "extra" steps are what turned Dominant Species from a possibly fun game into a math exercise punctuated by heavy doses of chaos (almost anything one did could be undone by someone later in the turn sequence). If I ever play it again I hope its not for at least a year. And there's no way in hell I'd play with more than four. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Deep and rich euro game that combines worker placement mechanics with direct player interaction. Slightly fiddly rules with plenty of things to consider and different hierarchies and point scales to use correctly  when playing makes for a slightly daunting initial threshold including home-brewed and somewhat counter-intuitive terminology regarding keywords like "dominance", "elements" etc. Relatively low player downtime but extensive play times - hours in the plural, expect three. Anticlimactic ending with sudden point tallying. Highly thematically consistent, highly inelegant, not particularily fun, but recommended for people who enjoy solid mechanics that demands keeping several orthogonal aspects in mind at once over fun or pleasure. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Its 3 times longer than acceptable for a pure area dominance game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Dominant Species indeed. This game is a chaotic ride where you try to survive the churn. Once-rich areas are laid waste by glaciers or stripped bare of the things you need to survive, leaving only the fittest. You try to build your own uninvadvable niches on the board, or you adapt to survive everywhere and leech of the more dominant species.

This is a game of area majorities but with added texture. Both the players themselves and the board collects (or loses) element chits - matching your elements to those on the board means that you are more dominant there, have no matching elements and you better get adapt, or run away lest you go extinct. For most of your points all you need are the majorities, but domination lets you access powerful cards that can severely upset a player's position. This enables players to leech of each other, driving players to chose between points or cards. 

The brutality of the cards and the way players can shape the board means that this is not a game of indirect interaction and optimisation. You focus heavily on beating down your opponents, while trying to incidentally align it with build a superior position for yourself. Reading and assessing a player’s overall position is difficult, as much of the game is not simply tactical manoeuvring to maximise your points for each turn, but instead setting yourself up for the important final scoring in a very chaotic environment. Baking in contingencies and defensive plays into your strategy is required to not be at the mercy of the random element draws or the cards that come up each round. 

The game takes a while, but it has an arc to it that very much fits the theme, and each game can take a different shape, from a blossoming paradise where species thrive, to a barren wasteland where everyone is happy to not go completely extinct. I really like this game as a very interactive game that doesn’t boil down to overt negotiation. The elements and the minor unique player powers each species has results in different incentives for each player, and you can manipulate these to create conflict “elsewhere”. So while I’m not sure you can guarantee yourself victory through good play you can very much ensure your demise by playing badly - and that works for me!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
I can see the allure of this game, and I do see that it is fantastic in many ways.  Unfortunately, this game isn't my cup of tea.

The issue is a combination of length, largely tactical (as opposed to strategic) gameplay, and a high screw-age factor.

Area Control games are generally mean, which is fine; the problem here is that this game is very complex and long, so the antagonism is exacerbated.  It's a real struggle, which while thematic, tends to wear me down over the length of play.

Granted, I haven't played the game extensively, but it does feel that one needs to play for short term goals.  However, so much can change so quickly that you're constantly reassessing the game-state and that leads to longer turns, AP, and a lack of overall strategy.

The theme is definitely there for a Euro, but in the end, it feels abstract.  The theme was a huge draw for me, but the only things that remained feeling thematic are the player powers.

I'd definitely play it in the future, but it would have to be under the right circumstances.  So I'm giving it a 6+.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Excellent eurogame.  

Complex (for a euro), long playing time (3+ hrs for your first game), somewhat fiddly, but also a good mix of short term optimization and long term planning.  A fair number of options to consider each turn.

Good tie-in between thematic elements and game mechanics, and room for aggressive plays.  Elements of a complex version of area control and action selection games with many varied ways to score vps that rewards both tactical and strategic planning (leaning more towards sharp tactical plays).

Production quality is very good imo (decent cards, wooden bits and mounted board)... nothing flashy about the game graphics, but they are very effective in communicating the state of the gameboard (i.e. it is easy to read the board quickly).  I much prefer utilitarian graphics (which still look ok) over flashy, but harder to read graphics (especially in a game like DS where alot of stuff is happening on the gameboard).  Thought the rules book was well organized and easy to read.

Recommended for eurogamers who enjoy longer, deeper and more intricate games.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Heavy worker placement. Possibly too much luck with cards that can swing the course of the game widely. Probably too lengthy for a game that feels so tactical rather than strategic, since the game board can change drastically from turn to turn. There are some simple variants to shorten the length of the game that I would probably use if I played in person - currently all my plays are on iPad… I would definitely avoid with players prone to analysis paralysis.

Kingdom Builder (another area majority game I just started playing) feels way more strategic and is a great example of the benefit of elegance in game design. There aren't as many bells and whistles, but there is still plenty to contemplate and the strategy feels more meaningful. It's also MUCH easier to teach and has plenty of variety with variable board setup, "kingdom builder" cards, and all the different "location" spaces with variable abilities.

Also, while the idea of Dominant Species theme-wise is cool, you actually control not just a species but the environment, too, which feels weird. Am I supposed to be a dominant species or am I supposed to be the earth? Am I God? If so, why do I only care about one specific species… eh, the theme kind of falls apart there.

RATING: 7.5
Worker placement game based on animal groups competing for resources on a hex-based map of the world. RATING: 8
I could care less about the worker placement mechanics - what makes this game amazing is the perfect marraige of theme and mechanics which create a massive butterfly effect inherent in each choice. It almost (but not quite) makes planning impossible, as one tries to parse the exponentially expanding web of if-then scenarios a beautiful kind of brain burn sets in. So, players have to play tactically rather than strategically, quite literally evolving their approach over the course of the game. This plus the actual direct conflict makes this game a work of art.
----------------------
Ratings downgrade to 8. After several plays of this I am starting to see a couple of things that dulls the sheen quite a bit - sometimes a player can have such terrible luck with token draws that they spend their entire game trying to prevent Wasteland and Desolation, while their opponents stomp them across the map. Adding to this is the card draws - if a player isn't high enough on the turn order track, and doesn't have the time or opportunity to increase his position, there is a significant penalty of being repeated victim of the negative cards without any real strategic recourse to mitigate these negative effects. Furthermore, the game seems to be increasingly group dependent - if a player is left alone, for whatever reason, he will tend to do far better than he might otherwise be expected to do. All of these negatives make the game somewhat less fun when any one (or god forbid all) of these issues occur.

RATING: 9
I just love this heavy "worker placement" game. It creates a tense experience.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Some context first.....I'm a eurogame/card game/abstract game player. I almost exclusively play games that take less than 90 minutes and have modest rule sets. The absolute limit of my complexity tolerance is Le Havre which I thoroughly enjoy. When I first read about Dominant Species I was worried about both the length and complexity.

However my professional field is environmental studies. I have yet to play an ecology/evolution game that incorporates population dynamics, changing habitats and climate, adaptation, and migration. Only the now out of print Extinction (invented by the great biodiversity theorist Steven Hubbell) came close, but it mainly emphasized population dynamics. So I was intrigued by Dominant Species and decided to get a hold of a copy.

One more caveat: I mainly have the opportunity to participate in two player games. It was crucial for me that Dominant Species would work with two.

In my view, this is an utterly brilliant game. There are multiple plans to victory, it inspires improvisational excellence, it is no harder to learn than Le Havre, it is fluid and dynamic, it has endless replayability, and it incorporates randomness and unpredictability as well as any strategy game I have ever played. 

In learning the game using the impeccable rules, we had a few false starts, mainly because we forgot to do something. There is alot to remember. But the play aids cover everything. It does take some effort to learn the game, but the rules and player aids do as good a job as I've seen in helping you along.

As a two player game this is absolutely magnificent. You have a great deal of strategic choice, and each time you play you learn something new about the remarkable chain of possibilities. We recently played Arachnids against Amphibians twice on consecutive evenings. The games uniquely unfolded. We could easily play these two animals multiple times before having the urge to try the other creatures. Our two player games take two and a half hours. I can't imagine playing with two or three animals each as that would insure brain melt. However, the replayability with the various creatures is still extraordinary. I'm looking forward to playing Dominant Species with more players.

I'd like to compliment the lovely, understated artwork as well. This is a beautiful game to play and look at. The pastel colors, the font on the cards, the feel of the board and pieces all reflect high quality. This is the closest a cardboard game can some to being heirloom.

Finally, Dominant Species brilliantly crosses the boundary between abstract and theme. My view is that an ecology/evolution game must have abstract qualities as the dynamics of adaptation are representational at this scale. It's all about the patterns that connect. Yet the creative richness of ecology and evolution demand thematic metaphor. Dominant Species matches great gameplay with wonderful aesthetics. 

One of the primary difficulties in constructing a game about ecology and evolution i finding the appropriate spatial and temporal scale. It has to be conceivable and tangbile enough so that you can manipulate the variables so as to play with them without being overwhelmed by the otherwise daunting complexity of the ecosystem. Indeed, that is why it is so hard for us to perceive global environmental change. I write about this subject at great length in my book Bringing the Biosphere Home (MIT Press, 2001).

I'll leave my environmental studies pedigree for now.

As a gamer, I recommend Dominant Species as a brilliantly conceived, wonderfully variable, and deeply rich game. It is totally absorbing, highly compelling, and just plain great fun. It is pleasantly hard. I just love the magnificent flow of the game play. Thanks to all involved for inventing and producing such a landmark game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
I can never figure out what is happening in this game.  I like a lot of the gameplay mechanics, but a game board really ought to give you information on who is winning.  To understand that in DS, you have to refer to every player's food cards - way too much work and a severe headache.  This game could have been a lot better with a different map interface...it would probably rock on computer.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Heavy weight worker placement.
Very solid game, good mechanic for the theme and I love the fact that there is a final scoring to look out for. But at the same time you have to be aware that about 1/3 of the total points are due to that final scoring.
Main downside is: If you play it with people who are unfamiliar with the game or think too long it takes 3-4 hours.

RATING: 8
I respect the design of Dominant Species tremendously and have gotten a lot of enjoyment from this game. I disagree with detractors who dismiss the game outright due to its chaos, but I have to admit there is an upward bound to how much you can mitigate it. After thirty plays, I feel like I've seen all there is to see here, barring the development of online play, which would allow for testing and propagating new strategies I haven't come across around here. (The iOS implementation works, but the AI is terrible, even with its recent improvements.)

For those looking for a shorter 2-player variant, we settled on a couple quick changes that worked well for us. Each player plays one Animal and gets 30 (not 55) cubes. In addition, use only the following fifteen cards: Aquatic, Biodiversity, Biomass, Cold Snap, Ecodiversity, Fecundity, Fertile, Hibernation, Ice Age, Instinct, Mass Exodus, Niche Biomes, Nocturnal, Omnivore, Predator. If you want to ensure the game lasts just three rounds (as we did), discard any cards that aren't activated at the end of the round. However, even with these changes, I disagree heartily with the sentiment that the 2-player game is "pure skill." You remove the multiplayer chaos, and the above card selection yields a little bit more predictability about what cards you'll see and when, but the Elements become a much bigger factor. If those come out in a certain way, you will have a hard time winning (or losing), no matter how skillful your play.

Although my interest in playing this is currently pretty low, I cannot deny the dozens of hours of enjoyment this game brought me, so I'm keeping this fairly lofty rating.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
After 1 play.  I need to give this another try but honestly, it's just not my kind of game.  It's very heavy and too long.  Every decision relies on 10 other decisions which all depend on what someone else may or may not do.  I just don't enjoy this level of thinking.  Can I see it is a good game and do I understand why a lot of people like it?  Yes. But it encourages way too much AP which really drags the game.  I think the components really need an overhaul as well.  And I think it is a little overrated here on the Geek.  Just because it's heavy, doesn't mean it's brilliant.  I prefer an overall more elegant design. And lest anyone think I just didn't like it because I played poorly, I did come in 2nd in a game of 5.  It's just not to my tastes.

RATING: 6.5
Only one play so far, which was agonizingly long (about 4 hours for 4 players, 2 newbies and 2 already familiar with it) but on the other hand, it was not an unpleasant experience: the extreme swinginess of the game and the ample opportunities to make life difficult for other players meant that you never felt like just tuning out even if you were trailing abysmally. My main problem is just the difficulty of reading the board: it takes such an amount of effort to constantly calculate the dominance of other players (and the possible shifts in dominant triggered by a given action) that it's genuinely difficult to tell if you're in a strong or weak position, and your actual position on the scoring track is not a reliable guide either. More experience with the game would obviously help in this department, but with such absurdly long runtimes that's just not going to happen.

RATING: N/A
Acquired on April 15th, 2011 - new
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Dominant Species is a brilliantly designed game that adds several layers to the area control mechanism. Not only do you strive for area majority but you must also adapt your species to the area (by adding elements to your species) and adapt the area to your species (by adding elements to the area). In addition, you must take into account that elements not chosen by the players "flow through" the game machinery and may eventually harm the species and/or their habitats. All actions are chosen through a programming mechanism, where they are available on a first-come first-serve basis, thus requiring both planning and prioritization.

Most of the gameplay can be predicted, with the random element draw adding a healthy dose of uncertainty for the players to adapt to (pun intended). The cards may be a bit too swingy but there are not more of them than the players can memorize and prepare for. They remind a bit about the calamities in Civilization, that add regular chaos to the gameplay.

All in all, this creates a highly tense and interactive gameplay, where the players constantly must be on their toes to defend where they are weakest and attack where they are strongest to maintain their comparative advantages. In the end, it's all about the survival of the fittest.

Reviewed at http://boardgamegeek.com/article/27896642
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Only played this once, so thoughts and ratings could change in the future.  The main problem that I have with the game is one of expectations.  I expected a game in which evolutionary / ecological themes were pronounced.  I did not find this to be the case.  It's a fun enough game.  I like the "worker placement" aspect, and the "more you'd like to do than you can do" aspect.  The unfolding of a turn after placing "workers" (i.e., action points) is very clever and tightly designed.  ...But I don't know.  I just feel like other games provide these sorts of mechanics in a way that I find more entertaining: Chaos in the Old World (area control), Alien Frontiers (placement), Twilight Struggles (choice stress).  And I feel other games do a better job of capturing the ebb and flow of "species" in a more thematically accurate way (Brittania).  Good game, one that I'd always be willing to play.  But you won't learn anything much about ecological systems / evolutionary processes.

Edit: +1 after more plays.  Putting aside the simulation aspect of the game, this is such a tightly designed game.  The "choice map" and how it interacts with the animal types is fantastic.

Edit: A few more plays, and this game continues to rise in my esteem.  Such a tense game, and the spooling out of player choices is brilliant.  Hovering on bumping this up to a 10.  Still don't consider it very informative about natural selection in general, but so what.  The game is fun.

Edit: Final choice is an 8. Terminology of the board really gets in the way of playing, and the domination mechanic is always clunky. Also not a huge fan of the final scoring of all tiles.  Somehow doesn't fit the v. careful planning that is associated with the rest of the game.  Still, has a high fun quotient, and the worker placement "programming" is v. cool.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
In this worker placement game, themed after six species fighting for survival, players play to improve the durability of their species, cause glaciation, add new tiles, migrate and reproduce. It's also an area control game, and there are cards that give you a wide range of bonuses. It's a game that clocks in around 4 hours. There are some interesting twists, in that you can use a worker to reserve a future action on the glaciation action.

I have played once with 5 players. I'm happy to try again, to understand the nuances of this game, but the time could be a factor. I also have some concerns about the wide swings caused by the dominance cards, and the targetting of the leader. The game does keep you engaged throughout. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
[floatleft][IMG]https://cf.geekdo-static.com/mbs/mb_834_1.png[/IMG][/floatleft]
[b]Dominant Species[/b] by [person=6331][/person]
2-6 players

Worker-placement, area control, variable player power, modular game.

Players choose to play one of the following: Mammals, Birds, Reptiles, Amphibeans, Spiders, or Insects. Each has its own special ability. Each will struggle to dominate the other across the various shifting environs of planet Earth.

[i]Natural selection[/i] is a fantastic, even phenomenal game subject, however, the game is a far cry from a simulation (not saying that the designer was going for that). Its theme is pasted on as with many eurogames. This is something that I´m not so enthused about. For me, DS doesn't ruin the gaming experience, but I sure would like to find something that is a tad closer to the real thing.

Perhaps one of Phil Eklund´s titles will appeal more, such as Bios:Megafauna. Must try it out first.

All that said, I´ve enjoyed the game.

Have played with 2, 3, and 4 players. All numbers are okay, however as the number of players increases, I find a greater need to utilize a game timer. It also becomes more chaotic and questionable whether good play is properly rewarded. 

Actually, it is here that we stumble across one of Life´s most fundamental questions: [i]Do we pull our own strings, or not?[/i] 

Perhaps in this the design remains most true to its subject matter.

Game Tips:
#1
Some complain that there's a lot of counting in this game. A timer would limit that, as well as use of double-sized cubes to denote 5 species, such as the 5 VP cubes in Tigris&Euphrates. If you own T&E, borrow its big cubes. They should have been included in DS from the get-go!
#2
If you don´t like bash-the-leader play, victory points could be tracked by placing VP counters into pouches, thus keeping player score totals hidden akin to T&E.
#3
If possible, purchase the first or second printings of the 1st edition. They have very clean art with pastel colors. The game state is easier to read than in later printings.

Official cardless variant:
https://boardgamegeek.com/article/7823126#7823126

Player aid:
https://boardgamegeek.com/filepage/60309/dominant-species-player-aid

Number of Cards: 27
Game sleeves:
Fantasy Flight Sleeve Size: Standard Card Game (FFS05) 2 1/2" x 3 1/2" (63.5 x 88 MM)
Mayday Sleeve Size: Card Game 63.5 x 88 mm

Useful Geeklist:
[Geeklist=102880][/Geeklist]

A good game, but boy, the theme is simply no there, and it's just madness level number crunching at the end of the day.

RATING: 6.5
On first play, I enjoyed it until I lost! And it didn't feel like four hours were passing, although it did feel a bit familiar...
On second play, I realised I just couldn't keep a handle on the game in the last two or three rounds. I just lost track of what the hell was going on!

Problems for me: I think a lot depends on what other players do rather than necessarily what you do; it's difficult to get an overview of the game just by looking at the board - I don't know if that's the design or what; there are a few Dominance cards that seem to cancel each-other out; it also feels overly long, and for no particular reason.

Maybe I've just played too many "Who's got the most cubes in this bit?" games, or maybe I just don't like them. I can't help admiring the mechanical design of the game, but I feel like I should enjoy it more than I actually did.

RATING: 7
Dominant Species is long and complicated, but for all of it's many moving parts, they are all intuitive and easy to learn, and it manages to stay very engaging throughout it's entire duration, resulting in one of the best area-control strategy games ever made. Perhaps its most amazing achievement, however, is that all of its various deterministic mechanics interact in incredibly complex and even unpredictable ways that perfectly evoke its ecological theme. 

Approved.

My son's Brithday gift - Played it once so far great game 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Beautiful and original game. 

It could have some small disadvantages for my taste: it is less predictable than I usually like (a bit of luck, e.g. when drawing the elements, and a bit too much depending on which opponent players choose to "punish"). 

BUT... 

The game is really different each time it is played and it develops in ways difficult to foresee: this is somehow part of the disadvantage I was mentioning above, but it is also its strength at the same time, because very thematically it represents the struggle to become dominant in a dramatically changing environment. 

The games are beautifully tense and fun. It is also nice to see how a single game develops, almost like reading a story that we are writing while playing it.

The length that could have been a problem is solved easily using the official variant of discarding 4 event cards (you can find it here on BGG).

The rules are beautiful and logical, without exceptions, intuitive because very well matched with the theme. My eight year old daughter manages to play DS, and to play well! No doubt about any rule (she can count dominance at a glance, surely better than me :) ).

All considered, if you like boardgaming it would be a mistake to miss this top game, IMHO. Very recommended.

UPDATE
What a pity I can't give this game more than 10: wonderful. All disadvantages I mentioned above disappeared after really getting into the game. I suggest playing with the variant mentioned above: besides being a faster game, it becomes more balanced. And what a game! Every single step is a tense and beautiful choice. Every game so different from the other. It is thematic. Rules are crystal clear and logical. After playing more games you, like me, may come to regret that 10 is the maximum you can give to a game here on BGG :P

RATING: 9.2

Players must strike a delicate balance between adapting their animals, tailoring the board state, and populating select tiles. The domination cards initially appear too swingy, but their power is gradually revealed to be a necessary check to a range of possible strategies. The physical enormity of the game matches its complexity and depth.

RATING: 6.5
A good game overall, but sometimes it feels like even the most watertight strategy can't even hold together for more than 1/8th of a turn.  

Some may view this as a strength and others as a weakness. Personally, I view it a a bit of a weakness as it presents only the illusion of strategy to the players. It's almost as if the game is playing itself at times.

On the other hand, it is a neat system, and so I do appreciate the game from a "game experiment" point of view.

UPDATE: Having played it several times, I think its "more fun than fair".  The reason for this are the cards, which are overpowered.  Not exceptionally so, but enough to swing the game too sharply in favour of a player who doesn't deserve it.  Sadly, my rating has dropped slightly on this game, though I will still play it and consider it to be fun.

RATING: 8
[i]Dominant Species[/i] is at heart an area majority game with worker placement, variable turn order, and some brutal direct conflict. It is NOT your average Euro- it is highly complex, requires constant attention and is absolutely cutthroat.

DS has fierce direct conflict both on the map and during action selection: this starts immediately and does not let up. There is no obvious way to ally with others, either. It suffers a little from "six-player chaos", but plays very well with four or even five.

Good game, but very heavy and has a long duration. Thus it will not see frequent play with my group. More's the pity...  :-(
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Game is very interesting and at the same time complex and easy to learn. The setting is very well bound with the rules and you really have the impression of a fight among species/classes.
However, there are some major drawbacks, according to my tastes, here:
- game is ONLY tactical. Probably there is some strategy towards the final scoring, but honestly any card can dramatically change the entire board
- components are cubes! Small animal meeples would have improved my game experience dramatically
- it is somehow boring to continuously check who is dominant in each region

RATING: 8
Holy crap, what a brain burner. Heavy, little randomness. After 1 play (finished half an hour ago after 3.5 hours), I feel pretty exhausted. There are a lot of rules to distiguish, and as a consequence of the permutation, I found it hard to keep the overview and understand the consequences of my moves. 

Although there are a couple of funny "take that!"-actions, it's first and foremost a game where player sit quietly contemplating. While I can appreciate the neat implementation of the theme (some rules really make sense from the ecological point of view), the excellent mechanics and even the artwork and the quality of components, there is just not enough [i]emotion[/i] in the game, although I imagine that may change with experienced players. Anyway, so far it's one of the best games with worker placement mechanic I know. 

Judging alone by my desire to play the game again, I rate it a 7.

Concerning purchase: The game is relatively expensive, minumum 55 EUR. Big minus. German edition goes for the same price.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
[b]Dominant Species[/b] 

[COLOR=#FF0000]Initial thoughts and rating (8/10):[/COLOR]

[i]I really didn't know much about Dominant Species other than it was known for being notoriously long and nasty. I played a 3p game and there was plenty of conflict, but it made sense in the context of the theme. And while the game was long, it took 3 hours including teaching, time flew by as turns moved quickly. I could see the game grinding to halt if you had AP players; there are some folks I probably wouldn't play this with. I would definitely recommend learning this from someone who already knows the game, it would be a beast to learn from the rule book.

As far as game play goes there are so many moving parts in Dominant Species that I'd recommend watching some videos if you're interested in learning the specifics of game play. What makes Dominant Species stand out is how all of the interconnected actions make sense both in terms of game play and thematically. The rise and fall of a species is definitely a turbulent event and Dominant Species does an amazing job capturing that theme. 

While the presentation may not be the best [i](it looks like an abstract game, minus the terrain tiles)[/i] the graphic design and layout is excellent and definitely aids game play. The action spaces on the board are placed in sequence making it easy to see how each action you take will effect later actions. The combination of building the terrain in conjunction with area control is difficult to balance, making for some really nasty surprises if you don't plan well or if potentially catastrophic events take place.   

Dominant Species is by far the deepest area control game I've played and has a steep learning curve, but still provided an enjoyable first play experience. The game is not overly complex, it just takes time to understand all the nuances between the different actions and plan accordingly. I really appreciate that this game rewards repeated play and strategies and synergies between actions will continue to unfold as you gain more experience. Dominant Species is one of those games I would recommend to anyone, at least for one play, and hopefully a game I get to play more.[/i]
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Excellent area influence/worker placement game. Love the theme. Very heavy and can last 4+ hours but so strategic. Will play this anytime. Higher player count is better. Lots of interaction.

RATING: N/A
Number one: do not play this game with 1 species each in a 2-player game. Maybe do not play it as a 2-player game at all. Best to play with 3 or more players, so everything isn't taken so personally. In a 2-player game you are constantly targeted by the other player...never makes for a good game. The game is unbalanced in a 2-player game and doesn't work perfectly. But I suspect it is way more fun and interesting with more players and a much tighter game play as well.

I want to play this game. I really enjoy this game and crave playing it, but it is lengthy and strategic. I am discovering about myself that if I am going to play a game by Chad Jensen, I will need time to play and I will need to take breaks. This game and Urban Sprawl are so great to play and so immersive that I get exhausted. Take a break, go get lunch, come back play for awhile, take another break...get the idea! We are talking about the evolution of species after all...this game takes time to make it to fruition. Another words, if you are feeling like you are way behind and probsbly going to loose...you might pull out a victory 5 rounds later...but if you don't take a break you will exhaust yourself and miss out on a great game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7

I like worker placement.  I would play this again at a game night, but the long play time would make this virtually impossible to play at home.  Plus it's more harsh than El Grande or AOE III in terms of removing others' pieces which doesn't fly as well at home. I've already got 2 or 3 long games sitting unplayed, so I won't be buying this.

RATING: 8

However, it is a fun and rewarding game, watching your species thrive (or die) on an expanding geomorpholic board.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
心得:
互動相當多的區域控制
可控可算性在人多會變少
但是大局觀依舊有用
還不錯玩，不過至少要三小時吧
規則:
1.起始順序照食物鏈，最低的最前面
2.優勢物種為該地形版塊存在對應分數單獨最高的，分數為該版塊各元素乘上生物版塊上對應元素的總合
3.2p:7-55, 3p:6-50, 4p:5-45, 5p:4-40, 6p:3-35,一個物種cube記分
4.除了冰原行動其它移除物種cube的動作都是移出遊戲
5.元素只要移掉就是丟回袋中
6.物種只要沒有配對元素(0分)，就會在滅絕階段滅絕
7.行動:
A起始: 往前一格，然後往下擺
B適應: 挑元素一個放在自己圖版上
C衰退: 有放的少掉一個生物圖版上的元素，只算種類
D供給: 放元素在任一角落
E荒原: 可選取意元素拿掉，剩下的有與冰原相連的都要棄掉
F消耗: 選取一個地圖版塊上的元素棄掉，必須這裡面有
G冰原: 放冰原，冰原上生物剩一隻，其它回手，三個冰原連角的元素棄掉，冰原連結記分
H物種形成: 在選取的元素相鄰版塊生物種，全部版塊都生
I探險: 放一個地形版塊，可選一個元素放，相鄰生物看生物鏈順序移動上去，或得版塊相鄰分數
J遷徙: X隻生物移動一格
K競爭: 三個地形中，各有自己生物可各殺一隻對手生物，
L統治: 選一個版塊記分，分數比個數，優勢物種必須選一張卡並執行，有玩家選冰河紀，則此回合後遊戲結束
8.滅絕階段把沒有配對元素的生物移出遊戲，然後倖存者記分，全部冰原上生物最多的可以記分，平手都不記，分數為他總共佔據多少冰原版塊，查表得分
9.在生階段，能向下的元素向下，沒有向下的收回袋子裡重抽補滿有格子的，翻開地形版塊，補牌補滿
10.最後記分:遊戲結束根據各版塊上生物數量每一塊都記分，冰原記分卡根據你擁有的優勢物種個數，記累加分數 
*遊戲算bonus分數的時候，拼冰原跟地形版塊，倖存卡記分，冰河卡記分
***無卡牌變體***
*所有卡牌沒有效果(冰河記分除外)，遊戲最後照拿到卡牌數目算bonus分數。

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Worker placement (Disclaimer, I don't like WP games). A bit long  for what it is (and expensive with below average components compared to similar games, though you do get a lot of wood in the box). The random event cards are slightly too powerful and important IMO, and there are other random factors such as element draws and terrain draws for "wanderlust."

The mechanics feel gamey - it's very much an abstract bag of mechanics dressed up as a 'game about evolution'. In particular the way you get points is mostly unrelated to the theme.

However there are some interesting mechanics and a lot of depth to the game, it's just not my cup of tea.

RATING: N/A
優勢物種
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A strategic rich game of cube pushing via worker placement actions in order to score points via area majorities. Your animal can only exist on tiles that have a food chit next to it that matches the food types you've collected for your animal. So there's your first mission for your workers ... place on the spots that get you food types added to your animal and then on spots which put out food types that your animal likes. Then you can place workers to add cubes (ie species of your animal) out onto the tiles next to a food type you've chosen and place workers to allow you to kill off competition and then also to migrate between tiles. You can also allocate workers to score a tile, hopefully one that's high scoring (wetland is worth more than desert), one that your animal is best adapted to (more food type matches than others, because then you'll earn a bonus card) and lastly have more cubes (species) on than the others for the actual VPs themselves. So there's lots of ways to get on the board and lots of ways to be removed from the board. It's fluid and hard to assess how a turn is going to pan out (and whether you'll still be able to score well in the region/s you were hoping to, as that happens last). There's also points of offer for placing new tiles to the board, expanding the tundra (ie reducing a tile's score power) and having the most cubes on tundra. Lots of strategies towards scoring, lots of ways to go about things, and only 5 stinking workers to do it all with. Which provides a rich decision making process each turn. It can be hard to assess the best way to go about things, and following the implications of what each player is planning to do as they place their workers, and that's what introduces the downtime. The trick to enjoyment is to play with players who'll play by feel and don't need to work out all the implications (too many times anyway) which will keep the game moving. The worker decision process hides that it's just a cube pusher to a degree, but it can get a bit same-y by the end stages. Well worth playing however, if just to explore the different way the game can evolve. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 5
Finally had the opportunity to play this game with other humans (not on the I-pad), and thus got the sense of how the game play flows.

Better than I expected.  The theme seemed to work to me, and I thought that the flow of the game had certain nuances that created opportunities to succeed.  This is not a casual game where you can do well unintentionally... rather it is a game where you are fighting both the other animals and the general forces of extniction and evolution.

The flaw of the game is its length.  This is not a short game, but seems to be guaged at an hour per player.  This means it is a game that should stay on the shelf.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This amazingly deep game surprisingly has a lot of similarities to Age of Empires III--Caylus-style worker placement with top-to-bottom execution, fueling an area-control game on a map board.  However, in addition to the usual "most-cubes" majorities, the game adds the concept of "domination", which is based on your race's attributes compared to the terrain's.  Majorities give you points, while domination lets you use game-altering cards.  Players elect which regions score, but choices become difficult if you don't dominate a high-scoring region.  Overall, I did enjoy it, but it's a LONG game, and quite the brain-burner, so it's not something I would seek to play often (I find it comparable to Die Macher on that level).  Also, domination is constantly in flux and not trivial to compute--makes me wish there was a computer to do it.

(1 play)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8.5
I've played maybe half a dozen games of Dominant species so far (all to conclusion) and I must say I'm impressed.

With any less than 3 players the game can drag on a bit, especially if people don't bid regularly on the domination area. In fact I don't think any of our games have been played in under 3 hours

I would say that the game is balanced since I've played as most of the 6 creature types and not won as any of them so far and still I enjoyed every game - they always seem to end up nail bitingly close!

The game itself does remind me a bit of diplomacy in a wierd way when 4 or more players are involved. There seems to be a lot of double dealing and secret agreements between the various animal groups that I find entertaining especially when they all stab each other in the back. Although I feel this maybe down to the cutthroats I play with as opposed to any game mechanics...Although it must be said the day the arachnids and the birds work together is a day I don't want to live to see!!

Update 1/16
Still a favourite, we now play a version where all cards are wiped at the end of each turn so if you didn't bid domination that turn you won't get a chance to play those specific cards later-this has halved playtime and has allowed me to introduce far more players who if keen can opt for the 'proper' game later

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Really enjoy this. It reminds me a lot of El Grande.

Two levels of majorities working together: most cubes is important to score points while most elements in common with the terrain will allow players to choose the all mighty Domination cards. The timing considerations usually present in worker placement games are also at play here, but are not the focus of the game. 

Dominant Species is about adapting to the ever changing environment, recognizing the most significant threats and taking actions to minimize them, while trying to make your competitors' life as hard as possible.

It's a fairly heavy game, with a level of complexity that sometimes is hard to distinguish from just plain chaos but I think that's a conscient design decision. For the game to work, it's important that apparently unpredictable things keep happening, forcing players to constantly adapt their plans.

Great game!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A conflict oriented worker placement area control game. Simple to learn, difficult to master. A long, but enjoyable experience that fits it's theme extremely well.

It plays surprisingly well with just 2 as it does with 6. Lots of decisions to be made through out the game. Be warned, people prone to Analysis Paralysis might curl up into a ball and die from decision overload.

The visual appeal of the game could be better as it is a bit minimalistic, though it's for functional purposes of game play. 


One of the best games I've played this year.

edit: after some time now I find this is still a very good game, but not as compelling as others. I need to be in the right mood to play this over some other available choices at game night. Because of this I've lowered the score to a 8.5. An exceptional design, just not a really compelling one that gives me the itch to play it often. The 4hr+ game length also hurts how often it gets played.

Don't get me wrong, this is still an exceptional game I'm just not sure it's a 10.

edit: sold due to many other friends owning it and that it doesn't get played often in my home. Might purchase 3rd + edition at some future time.

RATING: 8
Mixed feelings on this one. Amazing design, super super deep. Both plays I've experienced with live humans have been longer than I would prefer for a gaming experience. Update (9/13): Played again last night. Great game. Hard sell. Still really long. Definitely worth keeping even if rarely played.

Update (6/14): This game definitely has flaws. Probably the largest of which is the relentless bash the leader phenomenon. I still like it quite a bit, but I'm not pursuing plays with quite the same vigor. Also, still really long.

RATING: 6

Maybe my patience needs to evolve but if I'm sending my breed just to get eaten up and destroyed by the landscape, I get a sense of dissapointment. The calculations that go in to the game are as intense as any good Euro game, however the pay off isn't as satisfying. RATING: 7
Interesting game with some unique features and mechanics that can be a fun and enjoyable experience (if you are thick-skinned,) but a game that you can't take the results seriously.

Extremely chaotic and from the very first move your fate is at the whim of other players. Most of the event cards (Domination cards) are so powerful that leave little room for any meaningful long term strategy. Also, there are bound to be lots of player influencing attempts in the game, and leader bashing, "See, I'm in the second to last place, destroy that other player's species".
