=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Fantastic worker placement game where hexes are scored using area majority and points defined by type of terrain. When a player chooses to score an area, the person with the most cubes gets the points, BUT the player who's animals can eat the most effectively gets the opportunity to play a powerful and sometimes harsh action card.

One of the charms of this game is that even in a turn where you get wiped from the board, you can bounce right back on the next turn, so long as players know to not kick you when you are down.

The severity of these effects can be off-putting for new players, and bad or inexperienced players can choose to victimize the same player over and over again with the powerful card effects, ruining everyone's good time.

:star: Art, Iconography and components functional
:star: Clever or interesting mechanisms
:nostar: Reasonably low downtime between turns with mildly AP players
:star: Multiple plays stay interesting
:star: Low or mitigatable luck elements
:star::star::star::star::star: Raw enjoyment
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
The first turn is daunting (and would probably be a nightmare if you were going to try to walk through the rules), but the pieces fall into place quickly with someone familiar with the rules.  A combination of a number of genres: worker placement, area control, tile placement, bit of resource management...it works well.  The theme is fun; one or two of the species seem to be at a slight disadvantage, but I'm sure there is some undiscovered strategy that could capitalize on their abilities. Not sure I'd recommend it to a Catan fan, who might be fooled by the mere appearance of hexes...Dominant Species is a good deal meatier, to the point of being a bit of a brain burner. Game time is longish, but totally manageable.  

Update: Played again.  Hasn't aged well.  Not great for larger groups as it absolutely drags.  Can think of many other games that last 2+ hours I'd rather play.   
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
A nearly perfect game.

Worker placement meshed seamlessly with territory control, with a lot of flexibility and player interaction.

Dominance scoring isn't exactly difficult, but it's the one part of the game that doesn't feel streamlined.

Two other complaints: 1) the victory points feel a bit too weighted towards the last turn 2) regression impacts adaption strategy a bit too much when not all species are being played

RATING: 5
Not a bad game but, like Agricola, it gives me more stress than pleasure. There are just too many subsystems to integrate into a functioning plan. Experience really matters and, like Agricola and Puerto Rico, I'm unlikely ever to gain that requisite experience.

As I wargamer I'm not intimidated by the volume of rules, rather these rules feel like the player is fighting the system more so than the other players. All these wheels-within-wheels subsystem do not, in my opinion, make for an elegant design.

Personal desire to play: 3.

RATING: 6
A lot going on here, a real brain burner. It is a deep game with lots of small decisions to make. Beside the area control, (majority scores bonus), there is domination which is the cross reference of your race's attributes to the terrain, as long as you have one piece. It is domination that let's you take the bonus cards. Domination changes with each placement and become tedious to calculate. You select the scoring region which can be come difficult as the games progresses.

Ultimately a game that I have little desire to own, and would only play occasionally.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.75
The game is not as complex at people have you think, at least the rules are not. The most complex issue with this game is the fact that all actions are available from the very beginning. Of course, some of them do not make a whole of sense at first and chosing them as your action might be quite foolish, but it is a long and winding road until you figure that out for yourself. The game is quite abstract and so are the 'depictions' of the species, dominance and so forth (cubes, cones), but the flow of the game and the dynamic of conflicting species is very on theme and has been a surprisingly involving experience even if compared with games which are actually trying to be thematic (and are not). The final scoring is kind of overpowered in my opinion but that is not too bad. The game takes a long time and really melts your brain, I wonder if you could play it with less cards (12 and the Ice Age card) ? Anyhow, a good game and if it was not for the time and effort it takes to play this, I would have rated it much higher.

EDIT: Played again and the same thing happened AGAIN. Rush for empty tiles at the end and too much chaos that really unbalanced the game. Rating slipped down. For a game that takes this long and feels so intricate, there are too many things and special abilities that throw the balance. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
A top game for me. I wasn't expecting to like this based on what other people have told me about it. But, played as a six-player game, it was one of the most amazing experiences. From the start, it's a slugfest, and you're messing with each other. Allies don't emerge and grudges don't really form because you're opportunistically impacting the map and messing with the leader. Well-balanced, hard choices. The game is intimidating at first, but a good tutorial really can make the difference.

RATING: 9.25

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Dominant species is all about survival of the fittest. You control a group of animals there tries to adapt and survive just before the ice age sets in. It’s a Euro style game but a very aggressive one, so if you aren’t into cutthroat games this is definitely not a game for you.  If you on the other hand like games where you try to survive under harsh conditions and fierce competition, then you should give this game a try. It’s fairly easy to learn but hard to master, there is a lot to keep track of and at times can become pretty fiddly.

RATING: 8
Love this game, but I have some issues.  I played once so far.  5 players.  2 had severe AP.  Game took 6 hours to play.  I had alot of fun, but the last two hours were a bit daunting.  I need to play with faster players.  Calculating dominance also becomes a bit of a chore after a while.  One of the guys in the group suggested placing a dice on the spot with the number of the current highest dominance on there, so when you place, you can see if you beat it or not, without having to recheck dominance.  It may help a little, but when elements change, you still need to recalculate dominance for each player.

RATING: 9
I admit that I wouldn't even look over this game because I was so turned off by the title and theme, but once I got over that...

A fantastic worker-placement game with a bit of a war game feel.  I am a big fan!  At this point I only rated it a nine because I've only played it once; however, I expect my rating will be going up.

Each species has a slight difference to each other which should increase replay ability a ton.  The down side is that a good chunk of time is going to need to be committed to getting it on the table.  Our first game ran about five hours, but I hadn't even finished reading the rule book by the time we started playing our first game - and I needed to teach the other two players.  If you can tolerate a longer game or two in your collection and you don't mind aggressive worker-placement games get it before it's out of print!  You'll be happy you did.

RATING: 10
Amazing euro-styled game with much more player interaction than what most euro's offer. The sheer amount of choices and interactions that players can make to benefit themselves and hinder others is designed nicely. In addition, a very cleverly placed clock in the form of chosen card-events makes the game go as quickly or as slowly as the players choose. 

If you like euro-games but want more direct confrontation and interaction, Dominant Species is for you.

RATING: 9.5
Epic area control game with so much to track and so many ways to win. Tile placement, pawn distribution, action selection, movement, decay, opponent blocking, turn order, varying powers (advantages), and game changing cards (I wish there was more variety here). Amazing production quality. Will take multiple plays to appreciate, but surprisingly easy to learn and teach. Requires thinking a few rounds in advance. Many ways to play and win. Phenomenal theme integration. This game resets the bar for excellence in area control

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
TRULY EXCELLENT GAME OF ICEAGE SURVIVAL
I purchased this on a GMT sale based on the notion that I would get it to the table much faster than yet another 2-P wargame.  The reviews I read led me to expect a deep and lengthy game - which for the most part it is.  What the reviews in no way led me to expect that Dominant Species is an OUTSTANDING FAMILY GAME!  My first play was a learning game with my 9 and 12 YO sons.  They both quickly grasped the mechanics and at the end of play declared the game to be a GREAT game (of course they did join forces to pound Dad).  My 14 YO daughter watched the first game and insisted on joining us the next morning.  It was a school holiday an no-one asked for the TV/XBox/DS/PC/etc - we finished breakfast and there they were at the gaming table, ready to go!  How's THAT for GAMING GOODNESS!  Dominant Species is definitely a GMT HOME RUN.
[GMT 50-% off sale 11-2010]
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I like everything about this game. For me the graphics are just right, not overwhelming and yet aesthetically pleasing. The rule book id one of the best that I have ever read.

Some complain about the length, but with practice 3 to 4 hour games are possible.

The game itself has very high re-playability. There are many strategies. One tip is to not beat the leader down too hard as yesterdays enemy is todays ally. You never really want to be too far ahead or behind in victory points, so there is a bit of tight to walk.

The game experience is better with experienced players.

RATING: 5.6
This is a crazy insane analytical game.  There is tons going on but it is really hard to keep track of where your place is compared to your opponents.  This is truly as euro-y a game as you can get and a very good design.  however, for me, it just isn't that fun.  It's a epic type game that just really doesn't feel all that epic.   The dynamics of the board are way to fluid.  Thus, it really hard to plan a strategy on others turn because the board is so different by the time it's your turn to do something.  In turn, this creates long down time and heavy analysis paralysis.  On top of all this, it was way way to long.  Our three player game took 9 hours which is way to long for what it is. If the game could be refined to a real 90-120 minute then this could be a fine game but as it is, I would rather play 3 or 4 shorter Euros in the time I could play this, save the constant frustration and happily scratch the same itch.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Rating after one play. 

This is one of those games where you spend most of the first session just pulling the levers to see the myriad of cause and effect. Reminds me a lot of Age of Empires III, but about 30 per cent more complex and 30 per cent longer. Whether it's 30 per cent deeper remains to be seen.

It's transparent enough once you see a couple rounds of scoring. And there are many trade-offs in efficiency, long-term potential, and scoring. 

It is quite swingy. Dominance cards can open enormous opportunities, depending on the timing. And scoring is heavily weighted to the final turn, which feels a bit wonky in such a long game. However, it does seem that with experience, the swinginess would be mitigated. So my rating may rise.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
I've only played this game 5 or 6 times, despite having owned it since August 2012 (the most recent play in March 2015). I think it's a very good game, bordering on excellent - yet I feel no desparation to play it, and no "that was great, I should play it again soon" feeling after the game is over. For me it's a once-or-twice-a-year sort of game - it's very intense, and always seems to go very slowly even when there doesn't seem to be excessive AP (my most recent game, with 4, took around 4 hours, and yes we were using 4 or 5 domination actions each turn, although I was struggling early on and deliberately chose tiles no-one was dominant on a few times). It's a great design - worker placement and area control with an awful lot of "take that" - and a very intense play experience, and I can well see why many people love this game. Yet I don't personally, even though I do admire it and am glad to have it in my collection.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
I really wanted to love this game but can't. There is clearly a lot to it - great theme, interesting mechanics, lots of choices, probably too many choices. Even that's fine, the problem is tension. You don't really feel the tension of doing one choice over the other because whatever choice you make, you still feel like you are just "shooting in the dark" - at least that's how it felt to me. It's just very hard to tell how any combination of decisions are better than another combination of decisions. I mean you can head in a general direction but can't really tell most times how much more or less one set of choices versus another is getting you. 

I know games that give you fewer choices but you feel much more tension in those choices and you really "feel" the effect of one choice over the long run versus another.

Moreover, games takes a long time, to me there are games that scratch the similar itch of this one but in a shorter time frame - Automobile, for example.

UPDATE
Based on second play, I am going to bump to 6.9 rating but contradictorily say it has an appeal that's higher than that rating. I would love to be able to play this more and would play this almost any time [maybe not 3 in a row]. 

If this could be played in under 2 hours with 3, I'd give it a 9 plus. If it could be done in 1.5 hours, it would be my first perfect score.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
A rather easy to learn game with endless amounts of strategies that will constantly change throughout the game. One of the frustrating aspects to this game happens after the planning phase: players place their action pawns amongst 12 or so possible actions with a strategy in mind. By the time the actions toward the end of the execution phase are taken, the game board has completely changed. Regardless, Dominant Species is a fantastic game with infinite replayability. The game mechanics, in my opinion, are perfectly designed and flawless. This game is complete from beginning to end and provides everyone a great experience. Probably my favorite board game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.66
Great game, way way to long
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3.9
I feel like I should rank this game higher than what I do, because I think this is a genuinely good, clever and well designed game *system*. However, after two games a few major issues have surfaced. For the positives: I absolutely love the basic game mechanics and the way they implement and complement the theme. The dual area control mechanisms, worker placement, the conflict, the glaciation, etc... all work in a fluid and intuitive system with layers of strategy and tactics, with plenty of randomness to keep you on your toes.

That said, the game is just too chaotic and fiddly. That isn't so bad, but it's compounded by having a lot of downtime. It's an AP players nightmare, which makes a long game drag even more. I have two major issues that smite my rating even further: a few of the special cards and the balance of the different racial powers.

For the special cards... the same issue popped up in both games I played. How often this will pop up is probably rare, but the fact that it's happened in both of my games left a sour taste in my mouth. In worker placement games, one of the keys is getting an advantage over the other players in the number of workers you have to place. How that is done in this game is through the special cards. That's fine, except for the fact that there are very few cards that actually do this. I'm guessing that to counter this, when a card is triggered it can give multiple players an extra worker. In both games (one lasting 6 hours and the second 4 hrs) only ONE player was excluded from the extra action card in the very first first turn. Also in both games: another card that would reward an extra action didn't get revealed until the last and then second-to-last turn. This meant that one player was basically playing the entire 5ish hours with fewer actions than everyone else. Both players in this situation finished dead last. That is a substantial issue, and at least in one of those situations there was nothing that player could have done to prevent it (In the other case, the player hadn't played before and didn't realize it was such an issue to look out for).  

As for the special powers on the races- in my limited exposure to the game, it's felt as if a few of the races have decidedly more useful/powerful abilities. I know this is a source of debate, but the amphibian's special powers have the ability to be extremely powerful in ways that a few of the other races can. When you compare the insect's and Spider's powers which influence one hex at a time to the amphibians, whose power helps in every hex there is water (and the birds power, which can affect nearly the entire board). On top of the range of usefulness you also have random elements that can supercharge the amphibians. While it doesn't happen every game, if the random filling on adaption, abundance and wanderlust makes it so that plenty of water is able to hit the board the amphibians become superpowered, easily winning dominance throughout the game. That is compounded when water isn't available in adaption. In a long game, having a random draw determine if a race is superpowered or just average seems unacceptable. 

Overall, I'd say that I like the ideas in this game. But I will probably turn down playing it again. I really dislike that a random drawing of a special card can give one player a huge disadvantage for nearly the entire game, and random drawing of chits can give one race a substantial advantage. Will those situations come up every game? No. But they have come up in both games I played. I'm sure in games where a random element doesn't cause an decided advantage or disadvantage for one player, it is a game that belongs in the top 20 (though probably not my personal top 20). I've seen the other side if it, though, and I'd rather play a game where everyone competes on even ground.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
Mostly because of the playtime.  it's a great game, just takes forever.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
 Only one play with four players. Wonderful and original theme, nice mechanics, but just too many of them. So many choices leads to a weird first game with a steep learning curve.
 Some dominance cards seem completely broken (and others completely mediocre), especially in six player games, where you start with only 3 actions and getting an additional one early is crucial. In a 4 player game every player gets five from the beginning so thats not so a big deal.
 But my biggest grip is the length. It took us about 3 and half hours to complete the game. It adds up with the fact that some players will probably get out of the competition barely passed the first half of the game.
 Waiting for a second game, because i really liked worker placement mechanics and elements influence along the game.
 ----------
 Update after another play, this time with six players. I really wanted to like this game, but unfortunately its way too long for me. I have no problem with a 4+ hours game, but this one gets repetitive after the first half. With six players there is a bit too much downtime and, given the length is easy that one or two players will get out of victory race with an hour or so remaining to the end. Some factors will influence the length to a great extent, specially the sorting of the dominance cards. If some of the worst cards came out early, they are probably going to be hanging a lot of time waiting to be picked, which results in a longer game, specially in a six player game, when you do not have actions "to spare".
 The game definitely plays very different with 4 or 6 players. But i think the biggest issues arouse with six players. The unbalance between the dominance cards is a joke. Really. As i thought, the additional actions cards change the game when shown early. When you have 3 actions per turn, gain another in the first turn (not very rare) gives you a boost to do 33% more every turn, or a 66% more if you get a second in the next few turns, much more difficult but still posible (it happened to us...). Some of the cards are good, but only in a very specific situation. Others are simply broken in some scenarios. And a bunch are really worthless to pick if you cant get a pack of VPs when scoring before choosing the card.
 Still i think the base game is very thematic, has some wonderful mechanics (abundance, adaption, regression,...) which require to plan in advance and a deeper strategic play than most of similar euros. Unfortunately the length and balance issues kill the game for me.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9

Can be prone to AP, but seems to flow well once everyone is up to play on the rules.  

My first game was a wash, kind of left me feeling meh.

So to potential buyers, don't give up on the game just after one go, to get the feel you must give it at least 4 games to really understand the mechanics.

This game in my book is an excellent game, well done Chad Jenson!

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.25
23-04-2015. Rated after 1 play. Dominant Species is a 'heavy' euro. It's like El Grande x2, with worker placement to get your influence on the board. In the game you try to gain VPs, 'obviously' for controlling areas.  There are two types of 'control', one based on the amount of cubes you have (scores you VPs, depending on area number 2 and 3 in influence can also get VPs), and one based on the 'adaptedness' of your animal to the area you are trying to score. If you match most resource types in the hex you are trying to score you are 'dominant', resulting in you getting a special 'dominance' card.

You get more influence, move influence and score areas based on a worker placement mechanism. In addition, you can use a glacier to basically 'ruin' areas. 

I like it quite a bit. It's complicated, but fun.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Hilariously swingy cards are a no no for me.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.2
Choose a type of animal (Mammal, reptile, amphibian, insect, arachnid or bird) and then try to evolve and adapt better than the other players to your constantly changing environment. 

This is a heavy, brutal worker placement game with a ton of choices for you to make each turn. You will need to perform many calculations over the course of the game which might wear players out who are not used to heavy board games. Also, there is a lot of take that between players. Now if those two points don't discourage you, please give this game a try. It is simply excellent. No two plays will ever be the same.

RATING: 10
----------

Deep, nuanced, interactive, strategic, immersive.  

What a wonderful game.  I'm not a huge worker placement fan, so DS is a bit of an aberration for me, perhaps because the worker placement mechanism supports a dynamic, interactive area control core rather than a creation of a standard VP-engine.  

I love the story arc that is created as I watch the world and its creatures change.  Deeply thematic and engrossing. Brain melting. Challenging. Rich.

This is my #2 game.

RATING: 7.3
--Sept2010-- Liable to improve on additional play.  There's a lot of recalculating relative scores (if you've played it:  think of the recalculating that goes on in [i]La Città[/i]; this is more pronounced.)  But, to be fair, we were calculating dominance when it didn't really matter - and so our game dragged on a bit: 5.5h with 5p.  If I could play this in 3-4 hours it'd be enjoyable (so I'm very interested in trying a reduced deck of dominance cards on a future outing.)
--Sept2010-- Second play was ~3h with 3p.  But had a runaway leader.  Not sure if the runaway leader is an inherent problem with the 3p configuration, or whether it was just a symptom of the fact that we're not very good yet with the game system.  Still very glad to have ordered the game.
--Oct2010-- Third game was 6.3 hours with 4p.  Yeah, one of the players consumed the majority (yes: more than the other three summed together!) of that time - but, still, that's too long for comfort.  I like the game in the 3-4h range.  By 5h, I'm beginning to care very little who wins.
--Jan2017-- Sold.  Not missed yet.  (Though I expect I could play a friend's copy if I really wanted to reprise it.)

RATING: 4
[color=#CC0000]

I don't think I'll play this again.  As the game progressed it became apparent to me again why I dislike worker placement so much -- there were so many selections (6 players/four tokens each) that there was a lot of garbage that needed to be selected and that part of the game just became interminable.  Actions on the board weren't any better.  There is just too much to count and calculate before taking your actions.  If you and your buddies give a damn about winning this game is going to take hours and hours to play with six players.

I did well in my final game, but frankly not through my efforts.  As in real evolution my species were largely at the whims of fate and got breaks due to pretty arbitrary reasons that I had no control over.  Given their entire primary food source was wiped off the board it made no sense I was even in the hunt.  The guy that had never played before ran away with it and admitted he had no idea why.

Crazy chaotic board by the end of the game.  Very difficult to assess game state.

I wanted to like this one but it just didn't turn out.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
This game feels like a masterful design from the moment you begin to learn to play.  Consistently, players learning the game feel the weight of the game, and yet have few or no questions to ask for clarification, due to the unambiguousness and concise rules.

Here again we have one of the mechanics I enjoy: area control in which you coexist, most of the time, in the same areas as your opponents.  But in addition to that, we have two types of area control going on.  The typical competition to have the most units in an area earns points for the winners in that regard, but simultaneously there is the competition for dominance by being the species most suited to the environmental elements present, for the prize of being able to execute a powerful action card.  The latter system, in which you compete by manipulating both the elements your species prefers and the elements present on the board, is immensely satisfying.

It should be noted that this is a long game, and extremely long when analysis paralysis comes into play; there is much to consider, from very early in the game and only increasing.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I have a bit of mixed feelings toward this one, but with a definitely positive result overall. It's extremely susceptible to analysis paralysis with a huge amount of options and requires constant weighing of available choices, and yet all our plans can be easily thwarted by enemy action. Has very high - maybe too high - interaction and dynamics, and ultimately not being attacked too much is as important as good play. If you manage not too look like a threat, in consequence gaining points from other people's domination, and pull a strong ending, you are likely to win. It's a bit too long for me, with 4 player games in experienced (but somewhat thinking oriented) gamers lasting just over 4 hours.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A very solid game, with the somewhat admirable yet curious feature of being almost dangerously long for modern board gaming. I like the aesthetic and the cover art, on the whole in this category (of sneaky/combative area majority scoring games) I think I prefer Age of Empires III (more fun) and Confucious (more interesting). Does kind of surprise me how highly rated it is here on BGG, which I would choose to take as a positive sign that long, serious games are by no means out of fashion. Stiff competition, I would have thought though, from faster playing weighty games, such as Hansa Teutonica. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Great game, takes a little too long to play too often but is great when time isn't an issue.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Rated if I've got the time to invest in a long game. It's an engrossing ride that keeps you engaged throughout.  That said, I'm probably inflating the rating somewhat due to the lovely production, how well developed the game is and because of how simply it plays. At it's heart it's an area majority game driven by a worker placement mechanism. So... worker placement cube pushing. Nothing really new here apart maybe for the scoring - which is... involved and will have you counting cubes on tundra tiles like crazy as the game nears its end. With domination rewarded throughout the game by powerful cards the game sometimes develops into a crazy unpredictable almost mess. Keep your eye on the theme and you'll be okay with it. Don't covet your cubes... sorry... species too much, because at the whim of another player they could very well be gone in the blink of an eye. In fact, players will be performing a great deal of hitting or scoring other players based on the perceived leader. If you're thinking about your move for more than a few seconds then you're thinking you've got more control than you really do.

One thing I really like about this one is the excellent rulebook and really easy rules that make this easy to pick up after a long break between plays.

On the downside it's long - about an hour long to make it to the table regularly. I wonder if removing five dominance cards and 20% of the species cubes would just bring it down to comfortably under three hours. Another option is to remove one card and clear the dominance cards not taken at the end of each turn (plus remove 20% of the cubes) - turning the game into a five turn game. All this might be unnecessary for me if reports prove correct that the game time can drop to under two hours with experienced players.

Additionally there's an awful lot of counting and bookkeeping throughout. These are moderate distractions in what is otherwise a fine game. Players need to balance each other out, but beware of the table talk - it slows down a slow game even more. Players will hopefully balance out players dominating - there's plenty of scope for communal whacking. Which is why the game can't be taken very seriously. There's big points swings in the cards and the placement of a cube here or there.

The closest game I can come up with that's similar is El Grande. You push cubes around and score areas. Cards influence stuff. Except El Grande takes about half the time and involves much less counting. Dominant Species has this double counting aspect - the number of species is easy, and then there's the dominance determined by multiplying the number of counters around a hex by the number of counters of that type on a player's board. It's constantly changing. It works, but it works like an old Citroen 2CV works as a car. It's clunky and after a while it becomes annoying.

Dominant Species could almost be a civilization game in a way and I am looking forward to exploring further. Speaking of civilization games - Sid Meir's new civ game came out the same year as this, is about as fiddly and runs about the same length. It's tricky to decide which I'd rather play. In fact, with all the choices I have for a long game - Struggle for Empires, Through the Ages, etc, Dominant Species has a lot of competition. The easy rulebook and ease of picking it up after a long break might be what ends up making it the game of choice to bring off the shelf.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Core Game
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Worker placement with area control, as in [i][url=http://www.juegosdemesacr.com/cms/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=105&Itemid=1]Age of Empires III[/url][/i], but different in feel and in almost everything else. Formally this is a good game: It works properly, the mechanics integrate very good with the theme, and there are a lot of meaty decisions for the players to take. Besides, its rulebook is easily the best written one that I've ever seen: Concise, clear, well presented and explained and full of examples. What a pleasure was to read it! All these elements would normally be enough for me to give it a high rating, maybe an eight. That's right, if the game is good, it wouldn't matter for me that there is nothing really new in the design, with the exception, perhaps, of the the double majority aspect (species and dominance) that gives so much to think to the players. Nevertheless, the playing time exceeds by a mile the limit in which I would never turn down a game, at least for one of this kind. Maybe it is just that our gaming group meets on working days after work, when attitude for long games is not at its best, but a time comes when you start to feel like that the game should have ended a while ago. So even when the game is very good and engaging, it is probably the one among my favorites that I rate the lowest, cause I like it and enjoy playing it, but just not for that long . That having been said, I'm sure that trying a variant that reduces the playing time will catapult this game for me to a  very high rating. Perhaps even experience alone would be enough to solve this problem, but in the meantime I probably establish a time limit or remove randomly ten cards in my next games to shorten them. This would not only consume less playing time, but also would introduce an element of incertainty, since not all the cards would come into play, giving the game more replayability, expectation and tactical feel.

RATING: N/A
Scholars Oct. 2010
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Dominant Species is actually a highly tactical game which doesn't easily forgive stupid mistakes. There are so many approaches to the game – be it actively killing your rivals through competition, undermining them to extinction by desolating their natural resources or just continually displacing them through glaciation – and a range of different species with different perks that the resulting game is a great experience. My friends have commented on the lack of 'active screwing-over' in the game despite half of everything you do resulting in your opponents' species being displaced/killed. I also love the feeling of the box - 2kg in such a compact box screams quality to me!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7.5
FUN ★★★★✰
A lot of decisions to make at each turn. Also, a lot of changes in the situation. It's sort of a big mess full of coloured pawns. Time goes very fast and all players had fun.

RULES ★★★✰✰
The rules are well writeen without any issue to understand. The choices make the game a bit tricky, but not the rules. One or two rounds are needed to have a grasp on each possible action.

IMMERSION ★★✰✰✰
I understand it's a Euro-type game. Howevers, moving cubes and cones is not really immersive. Nor are the choice of animals. The theme is almost not present in my taste. I prefer some kind of minis that at least reminds you that you are playing a game taking place 90000 years ago!

DEPTH ★★★★✰
I played only one time and I am sure there are lots of possibilities and strategies. We'll see over time though. After the second play, I find the game a bit random in the sense that it's a huge chaos where it's quite hard to plan anything. I decrese the overall score by 0.5, but it's still for sure a very solid game.

RATING: 4
Rating after just one play, the game is clearly very well designed, but I don't find the decision making and accounting to be enjoyable, at least in a game that takes this long to play. Hence, I rate it fairly low not as an indication of whether it's a "good game," but rather on how interested I am in playing again.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Nothing particularly innovative, but the cornucopia of mechanisms is blended together beautifully, creating a stirring narrative of rise and fall. Species arise organically, migrate away from glaciation, explore for better opportunities, and struggle to adapt to the elements and avoid extinction. Half the game is watching your animal, adapting appropriately, plus getting the majorities and dominance cones, and half of it is placing the tiles, glaciating and seeding/maintaining the board with resources appropriately to make it more hospitable for you.

People like to compare this to [i]El Grande[/i], and that is there with the 5-card display and the importance of managing and timing your cube reserve. But the biggest analogue is [i]Age of Empires[/i], which just comes off as a wannabe filler next to this tour de force. AoE has half the action choices (turn order = initiative, token draft = Abundant + Adaptation, shipping = Speciation, discovery = Wanderlust, merchant ship = Glaciation, warfare = Competition) with little interaction between them, whereas in DS, every single thing messes with the board and the other actions in a complex and subtle manner. Shades of [i]Mammoth Hunters[/i] too with the glaciation action and take-that cards.

I normally wouldn't bother with such a complex inter-mingling and relentless layering of mechanisms, but there is purpose and an evocative dynamism behind them, instead of only dryness in others (Caylus, anything from Chvatil). I enjoy seeing the board morph and develop (in 3 ways: tiles, resources and glaciation), animals rise and fall, and every thing in the game thoughtfully furthers the theme and gives your actions meaning. The components might be Euro-austere, but such rich meaning is infused into the game that they do not need to be figurines or animeeples.

What also impressed me was how 1 single point of difference between the animals creates meaningful asymmetry throughout the game by changing how players value different action spaces, and enabling subtle combos, which I still haven't completely figured out yet (Birds = Initiative + Migration; Mammals = Glaciation, then tie-break majority). Again, so much more meaning than games that slap 1-5 "variable player powers" rules that give little payoff for tacked-on rules complexity (AoE expansion).

Worth at least one play to check out the subdued but tight marriage between theme and mechanisms, feeling almost like a history lesson. Wouldn't play this on a dime as I do with nearly any other game due to the sheer decision complexity, but I can get warmed up every once in a while.

Update: more of an experience game, because as a leader-bashing game, the stakes can get too complicated. Hence, would remove the AP-gaining cards to shorten the experience.

4+4
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I almost want to give this a 9 considering how much I enjoyed it, despite area control being one of my least favorite mechanics.  You can't have thin skin to play it as there is some meanness, but with the right people, you don't even notice the time melting away.  It says something to the game's design that even a bad early blow - such as being knocked down to 1 cube on the board - doesn't doom you to a game-long torture session with no chance to win.  Love the mechanics for dominance as well as the scoring, especially the end-game scoring for dominance, which you are building towards all game.  The production values of the later printing are an improvement over the original ones.  The board and cards aren't going to blow you away, but they're pleasant to look at.  Really good stuff.

RATING: 6

RATING: 2
3 plays: 

1 play:
I liked the theme implementation and the slow pace of the game, which nevertheless is not so big on downtime. I liked that not every decision is crucial, it can be, but... you mostly can do something about it with the overall butterfly effect feel of the game. I liked graphic design in live much more than I though I would. Clean and bright. Also, the rules are so clearly written this doesn't feel like such a heavy game (FFG this is your obligatory reading assignment).

What I'm not sure about:
It's an area control with added stuff hence - it's both interactive, highly tactical, but also opaque. 
Maybe one reason I enjoyed the game is because with winning strategies so blurry, your position opaque and really no real clue except what happens this and next turn, I could relax and just take it as a ride. So I hope it will stay as a ride with further plays and not some VP tweaks engine. 

3 games in: 
I've explained the game on the 2nd and 3rd game and my head hurt. Too fricking demanding. Won't teach again. The rules are so well written, one should be able to learn from reading and they will. 

EDIT: Lowered game for 0.5. On repeated play the theme hid itself in the background, also 5 player game was a bit too stressful (less actions, more screwage). There's a funny thing with the cards - some are made to better in the start game and some in the end game, if you get theme in opposite parts of the game, they are less of an impact on the game, which feels like they weren't played. 

EDIT 2: played once more after a while. Lowered rating by 1.0. We tried some table talk and you can't do it in this game - too much overhead, too much thinky stuff that buries the game (probably group's fault). Anyhow, while I like it better than El Grande and is an euro with actual interaction I'm unlikely to play this in near or intermediate future. 

EDIT 3: new graphic design is hideous and so so so average and common. This game has a ton of stuff going on so functionality of visual design is a necessity - game state must be easy to read. Original art had this.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
[2011-12-02]
Talán megtaláltam azt a játékot, amit eddig kerestem. A legjobb és legélvezetesebb eurogame-t. A játékkal játszva ugyanolyan érzés fogott el, mint a Battlestar Galacticával töltött idő alatt. Fantasztikus játék a Dominant Species. A játékosok hat állatosztály közül választhatnak és azok fajait próbálják dominánssá tenni a játék közben többfajta területből épülő térképen. Akcióválasztó a játék. A sokfajta akció nagyon jól ki van dolgozva, mind nagyon hasznos és nagyon fontos. A hatszögletű területekből felépülő térképen egy ötletes megoldás adja, hogy ki a domináns az adott részen. De közel sem egy egyszerű többségi játék. A játék tökéletesen működött ketten is és a játékidő sem volt túl hosszú. A játék legnagyobb erénye a dinamikája. Hihetetlen érdekesen alakul a fajok jelenléte a területen. A dominanciák fázisonként is nagyon változhatnak. Nem érzek visszahozhatatlan hátrányt. Hihetetlen izgalmas, fantasztikusan jó játék a Dominant Species. Több játékossal szerintem még érdekesebben alakulhat a sokszínűség és ha sikerül kipróbálnom és jól gondolom nagyon érik az első 10 pontos eurogame.

[2011-12-29]
Négyen kipróbálva is nagyon jó, ugyanolyan hihetetlenül dinamikus és tényleg nincs reménytelen helyzet, ez szuper benne. Egyedül a hossza durvulhat el sok személynél. Megadom neki a 10-est, mert megérdemli.

[2017-08-28]
A véletlenszerű föld változatot nem ajánlom, mert kevés egyeddel kezdve nem érzem elég kompenzációnak azt a pár győzelmi pontot.

RATING: 6
I'm not convinced (yet) that this is a game of skill. The elements outside of the individual's control seem to overwhelm those that aren't.

If you play this game in a fairly regular group, and keep records of the game results, I'd be interested to look at it. Are there players who are simply better at it, and finish high consistently? Or are the results all over the place, with the same individual finishing 1st/2nd half the time and 5th/6th in the rest?

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
[i]Game of Games, for Euro Gamers[/i]

Challenging, deep, and well designed.

[b]Length[/b]: Justified. To shorten this game would probably be to cheapen the experience.

[b]Flavor[/b]: Fitting. Adapt or die.

[b]Strategy[/b]: It seems you must respect both strategy and tactics in this game. Go in with a strategy but be prepared to change it as you adapt or die.

[b]Components:[/b] 2nd edition is minimal but stylistic. I like the "art project" look and the cartoony artwork on the domination cards.

3rd edition appears to take itself a little more seriously. The styles of the cards etc seem more like a hodgepodge in the 3rd edition rather than stylized around a certain theme, so not sure I prefer them, but the terrains etc definitely "pop" more and are pleasing to look at. Overall 3rd edition looks more polished despite (IMO) sacrificing a bit of style

But either way this game is about the gameplay first. The components do their job and then step back and let the gameplay shine.

[hr]Still a great game, but it isn't getting played that much for one reason: Chaos in the Old World Horned Rat expansion. Everytime I'm taking a game to game night and look at my shelf and consider Dominant Species, I see the faster, sexier area domination game that is also less taxing on the brain and body and grab that instead. That's a shame, because Dominant Species is more than satisfying.

(5 Design + 3 Enjoyment)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
Overly long and repetitive with huge swings based more on what chits, tiles, and cards get flipped up over most of anything else you do.  The worker placement section is nice, but there are too many better games that do this kind of thing.  The main board is a more complicated less fulfilling El Grande.  The cards can be ridiculous.  Thematically, it has all the language, but ultimately it is pretty abstract, so if I want a random sim I'd rather play American Megafauna and if I want an abstract representation I'll play Trias.  As for any kind of growth of your species it doesn't have anything on Evo, and if you just want an awesome dinosaur game play Tyranno Ex.

It is long, and slow, with mostly tactical, reactive decisions.  There is no middle or end game, you just do the same thing over and over again.

RATING: 8
Played on iPad with AI only. AI is quite dumb, looking forward to 2018 q1 reprint and play with human. Will adjust rating after playing with human intelligence.

The Good:
- Indirect player interaction (by worker placement and area influence, my favourite mechanics)
- Direct player interaction and conflict
- Easily understood theme and doesn't feel pasted on.
- Can play up to 6 players
- Asymmetric player power that feels well balanced.
- Kingmaking usually doesn't happen in this game (Compare to say El Grande, which you can see happen from time to time) because the scoring track is not a good representation of the final standing.
- Low luck.
- Meaning decisions to be made every pawn.

The Bad:
- Will find out when I get a chance to play with human.

RATING: 7
This is a beautiful game. And the rulebook is excellent, one of the best I've seen. I only have two problems with the game:

(1) Trying to figure out how all the different phases of the game interact, and what you should actually be trying to achieve, is very complicated. I expect a person would have to play the game half a dozen times to get a good feel for this. Helpful would be a one-pager discussing basic strategy for newbies: half of it pointing out important interactions, and half of it suggesting 2 or 3 basic strategies that a player might want to adopt.

(2) Tracking Domination is a big pain, especially once players get 4 or 5 elements on their displays. It made my head spin as I have to glance at the board, and at every player's player sheet and then do the math. And this calculation can change many, many times during a single turn. Yikes.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.3
This game seems to be one where repeated plays will reveal its depth.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Dominant Species is a fantastic worker placement and area control game. The area control aspect consists of two layers: the first layer is just a numerical majority and will score you some VP's. The second layer consists of dominance: the species who is best adapted to a certain area is dominant and doesn't score VP's but gets to pick a card with mostly very strong effects that affect the board state. A great aspect of the game is that scoring an area costs an action: you might score an area where you're both dominant and have the majority but that will not always be the case. The worker placement aspect consists of about twelve different actions that affect the board state: as all placements are made before any actions resolve there is a lot of ambiguity about what the board state will be when you get to resolve your actions. This gives the game a very thematic feel of adaptability and flexibility. This is often perceived as chaotic, but I think that's overstated; there is definitely room for planning. Although, someone with AP and who has to be in control, will have a really bad time as the gameplay isn't really suited to their play style.
The game can be very cutthroath, there is an abundunce of both indirect and direct interaction. Especially the card effects can be brutal, to a point where some players are no longer in contention, although there is no player elimination.
The rulebook is one of the best I've ever come across. While not the most rules-heavy game, it's certainly a deep game with a lot of moving parts. The rules are very clear and consise which is quite the feat. A single read-through was enough to get started and we barely had to reference them whilst playing.
The components are wonderful and truly functional. I think it's great how the information that the game board has to convey is always clear, no matter how complex the board state. The 3rd edition might look a bit better, but I think will not be as clear whilst playing.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Really interesting area-control game, so much so that my buddy said it was three-dimensional.  The interplay among elements and area control with the animals is interesting as is the cascading effects of the actions, but I don't know if the cards cause too much randomness.  I played this with 6 and it dragged; I would like to play this again at some point with just 3  or 4 to see if it would be better, but I don't know if I'll ever get the opportunity.

UPDATE: Finally got to play this again... I think that 4 is where it really shines, and unfortunately I've now played it with 5 and 3. Still, over the full game, the cards are not random, the cascading of the actions is brillant, and the game is just solid. Also, a game with 6 is a little slow and more chaotic, but still fun once you know what you are doing.

RATING: 10
Revised rating from 8 (2010) to 9 (2011) to 10 (2013).

Yup, this game certainly has continued to live long and prosper in my gaming circles. It is a deep thinking game with many tough decisions to be made along the way. I continue to thoroughly enjoy it after all this time.

New players will often feel miserable as they appear to lose but there are always outs and ways to claw back in and even move into pole position. Definitely not a game to judge on a first play basis.

----------------------------------------

This game has only gotten better with more plays. I enjoy the deep strategy and the heart wrenching decisions. The mechanics marry well with the theme. Prospective buyers/players should be warned that this is a long game, and it is a cruel one.

RATING: 8
전략
◆◆◆◇
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
1 play, 2er, 2 animals each.

Wow! I FINALLY got to play this, and it is pure awesome! Looking forward to trying it in other configurations:
- 2er, 1 animal each (2 each worked, but it's hard! I'm glad we didn't try 3 animals each!)
- 3er, 1 and 2 animals each
- 4er
I doubt, though, that I'll want to play it with 5 or 6 any time soon -- seems like that would last too long and have too much time between turns to be as much fun!

This is a deep worker placement (action selection), area control game with an evolutionary theme and a bunch of very tightly integrated mechanisms. It's sort of like Die Macher: long play time, a LOT going on at the same time, and all that stuff interacts with everything else in interesting ways that actually make sense!

Players represent families of animals, and each starts the game with the same number of cubes -- each cube representing a different species -- in a "gene pool", really the potential for your type of animal. Your goal is to have been the most dominant family of animal (not species) prior to the end of the world (the Ice Age). It's as if we, the dominant survivors of the Ice Age, are looking back to see what was most important prior to the Ice Age. Importance is, of course, measured by victory points (VP). You earn VP, from the start of the world (game) through the Ice Age, by having more species in more important landscapes. There's also a nice reward, slow to earn but steady, for being able to adapt to the ice itself. At the end of the Ice Age, every terrain scores (thematically, I guess, we the survivors are looking back at all of history) but prior to that, only specific terrain hexes chosen by the players will score (thematically: umm ... yeah, I can't come up with a thematic justification for this one!).

From a mechanism viewpoint:
- Players are unique animals, adapted to different environments. The game has 6 elements (represented by discs for sun, water, grub, meat, grass, seed) which are placed on the corners of terrain hexes, defining the environment in that terrain. Animals start with different mixes of elements to which they are adapted, and can further adapt during the game.
- Each player has a number of cylinders (AP's) used to select actions
- The actions are chosen first, in any order of the players' choosing, but resolve in order on the board -- top to bottom, left to right
- Actions do a variety of things such as: gain adaptation, modify the environment (add element to a hex corner on the board), place species (cubes) on the board, move cubes, kill other players' cubes, score a hex, advance the ice (place tundra), etc.
- Players compete in each hex in 2 ways: 
... Presence: based on the number of species (cubes); earn VP according to rank and area type
... Dominance: based on how well you're adapted to that environment (match elements on the hex with those to which you are adapted); leader chooses and plays a Dominance Card, which can have huge impacts on the game
- The evolutionary theme is represented (quite well!) by the constantly changing environment; the ability of animals to adapt over time; the rise, movement and fall of populations over time; and the constant advance of tundra as the Ice Age approaches
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 5
This is a very good, very well-designed game.  The worker placement, area control, and other mechanics all fit together nicely and it makes for a very deep and interesting strategic experience.  For me though the game is just missing that spark that makes it fun for me.

Perhaps it is the themeless coating the game has.  Placing different wooden shapes hardly feels like maneuvering an animal species to thrive and survive (this certainly does make it feel more like an abstract strategy game, something I'm not typically a fan of).  Perhaps it is that even if it were more thematic it isn't very interesting of a theme (to me).  Perhaps it's that all the games feel very same-y without much diversity in the actions and game events except for the domination cards.  Or perhaps it is that the domination cards themselves aren't very interesting and feel a little too easy to use when they are the most interesting and impactful elements of the game.

More than likely it is a combination of all of the above.  It is just such a well-made game that I can't hate on it too much, but not going to be one I'm that excited about playing.

RATING: 7


I think this might be the best 'gamer's game' since Le Havre.  I absolutely loved it; there are so many layers to this game and so many areas that knit  together seamlessly. The rules, for 20 pages, are quite straightforward, the way to play is not. There seems to be the perfect blend of strategy and tactics as neither can be ignored and putting one above the other punishes a player. The first game was one of complete joy as interactions between the action choices revealed themselves.

I'd be delighted is anything at Essen 10 is as good as this let alone better.

Props to wargame designer Chad Jensen - its as if a Classical musician had decided to make a rock album and it was the best of the year. Trad and boring Euro designers beware - this is the new standard

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
iOS
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I have been eagerly awaiting this game for a while now.  As an enthusiast in evolution this game had obvious appeal.  

Let me say just a few words about it.  It is easier to pick up, learn and teach than you would think, but it can be overwhelming and daunting in the choices available and the repercussions of those actions.  The choices are savory, delicious, and frustrating all at the same time.  The placement of each action pawn can leave your palms sweating and you second guessing.  But is it is also engaging, enlightening, and immersive.  I look forward to many future plays.

And now for a rant:  Many have said the theme is "pasted on" I wholly disagree.  Sure, if you change the terms it could have been about colonizing Mars; but the theme fits, the idea of adapting regressing, colonizing, and competing all work together.  Because the game is you being an animal, it may be said that actions like abundance and depletion don’t really fit as those are just manipulating the board and have little to do with actions that animals actually do.  However, animals DO change their environment, and not just by accident.  Animals have forever adjusted their environment to suit their needs.  Humans are the best example, (if you are cold; build a house, you want food plant a garden), but many other species do that same thing to a lesser extent.  Birds eat berries and as the seeds pass through the birds, the seeds not only get dispersed, they get dropped in a nice little pile of fertilizer, increasing the amount of that type of berry in existence.    Beavers dam rivers, massively changing ecosystems to better suit them. There are thousands of similar instances where animals alter the environment.

RATING: 8

RATING: 9.5
:thumbsup: LIKE
- Awesome theme and mechanic integration.  Everything makes sense and has a counter balance.
-  6 different "races" that don't alter you play style but add a little flavor and variety.
- Great rulebook that teaches you the game from the get go.

:thumbsdown: DISLIKE
- The usual GMT production value: ugly art (less so in third edition but still could use some work), cards, design, typos, high price, etc.

:star: VERDICT
One of the best workers placement game.  Might redeem the genre for me.
Even if the game is abstracted and the art is ugly (and I mean real ugly, WTF GMT!), you can feel a narrative build up as you play.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Who knew? It turns out that all you need to do to make a light area majority game I really like is to make it a small component of a heavy worker placement engine. :D

I do have some serious reservations, so let's get those over with first: most importantly, while I've grown to appreciate the typeface on the cover even though it looks like it was ripped from the opening titles of Buffy the Vampire Slayer, was that really Comic Sans on the player aids? For shame.

There are issues with the design that less vicious players might care about, but things like potential player elimination and the "bash the leader" problem shouldn't trouble the target audience.

The only real problem is that the random effects are so significant, and even that is only a problem because the game is so long. It's particularly pronounced with the Dominance cards, which are very unbalanced, and reward the player(s) lucky enough to have the correct turn order position to take advantage. But it is also true of the other game elements: the luck of the element draw has a significant impact.

I'm having trouble articulating this right, but I want to stress that I think appreciating the strategy in this game means adopting more of a wargamer's mindset -- because the designer, Chad Jensen, has a background in wargames. They rarely involve perfect information and almost always include random elements, so "strategy" is more than just increasing the ply depth on your tactical minimax. Strategy is about creating situations with favourable probabilities -- and part of the fun is in dealing with unexpected windfalls and unexpected disasters.

The thing is, it's just tremendously fun, and feels much lighter to me than it actually is -- in part, I think, because it's not just calculating how much money you will need for your action in eight turns time. It's very fluid and your strategy has to be the same. 

At three hours, is it worth it? I think so, because it felt like half that time.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.5
An interesting area-majority sort of game that gets a bit bogged down in its own mechanisms.  I think that having my first game be 6-player kind of skews my view of the game, but while I like the combination of Caylus-esque worker placement with a sort of El Grande type of area majority, the constant need to recalculate who is dominant, and the poor choice in vocabulary (dominant vs. dominance, the choice of the word "species" to mean a single cube, which is awfully counter-intuitive) cause some problems that bog the game down.  Games have to be [b]awfully[/b] interesting and strong to keep me engaged for 3+ hours, and I wasn't feeling that here.  I think with the correct group of people and a smaller size--4 seems about right for this--I could enjoy DS, but I don't really feel the need to try it again.

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
At first this game seems to be chaotic, but after dozens of plays it intricacy reveals a masterpiece. I have played this game about 50 times with the same two other players. This is the first board game I can say brings me back to the focus and planning I needed in chess. I found myself thinking 10 moves ahead and planning counters for every move my two opponents could make. Its like a 3 player chess game for us. Many of our games end with the point spread extremely close. Many people in my gaming circle could not handle all that was going on, it was too much for them. Others felt the game was too confrontational. I recommend finding players who can think ahead multiples moves, are extremely strategic, and can take a hit and come right back. If you find players like that you will have battles of wit that can rarely be achieved in other games.

RATING: 9
Rare combo design that can be enjoyed by both wargamers and eurogamers alike. Takes an extra effort to wrap your mind around at first. Play time can be a bit long if brain-drain sets in.

Tremendous depth of decision-making that is nicely integrated into play. The theme is very strong, and the game is thoroughly engaging.

I'm a fan of the 1st edition art, which is colorful, clean, and crisp.

Great fun, this an impressive design achievement - easily one of the top euros ever, IMHO.

RATING: 6
I wish I liked this game better.  I love the concept and the mechanics are well thought out.  What I don't like is the huge downtime between turns, and the game is way too long for what it is.  Part of my problem may have been the number of players; we had six, at least half of them the type to analyze every possible outcome before making their move.  This may be better with fewer players and/or more familiarity with the rules.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Very heavy and in-depth hybridization of a Euro and War game. There are so many factors and variables to consider that it is almost impossible to determine the best viable move in any situation -- something a lot of players complained about -- but I find that as a strength of the game.

The only major problem I have with the game, besides the heavy weight of the game, is some of the Dominance Cards.

Some cards are horribly imbalanced compared to others, and if you're in a good Dominance position when they come up it can really turn the game into a run away leader. Additionally, there is a problem with the whole "King Maker" problem -- one player can really give another player a huge lead -- especially if not all the players are on the same skill level.

I suggest some house variant that gives bonus VP for taking a subpar card, like between 2 and 4 VP to make the choice more interesting (similar to how the game rewards conflict by giving bonus VP for placing tiles near other tiles).

Despite its flaws, the game is very good and fills a very unique and different niche. A must play for any Euro fan who enjoys conflict!

EDIT: I decreased my rating from a 7.75 to a 7.5 because of the sheer analysis paralysis that can occur. If you get slow players the game to crawl to a stand still. Plus, the game feels a little too abstract for my changing tastes. Still a great game though!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Brilliant area-control/worker-placement game. The theme, which has you controlling a specific class of animal such as mammals, birds, reptiles etc, in an attempt to attain dominance across a variety of habitats is exceptionally well done. It feels a bit like playing a wargame although you have to consider elements such as having to be able to feed your species in order to 'migrate' and then 'dominate' a particular habitat and this ensures that the game also feels truly original. Each class of animal has their own unique skill, which means that players will adopt different strategies and will play quite differently depending on who they control. There are so many options to choose from on each turn and this means that a great deal of thought has to go into planning your moves but the gameplay is also simple and easy to understand. The result of this is that 'Dominant Species' is one of the deepest, strategic and most original games ever created. I can't fault it. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Need to see more about this
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
It's an animals' struggle in the ice age, modelled using board game rules. The final effect is extremely interesting: we can say it's a euro (very well written simple rules), but with some strong negative interaction and variable player powers (animal special abilities). I'm really amazed how the phenomena and evolution mechanisms were put into the game actions: the animals can reproduce, adapt to new kinds of food, migrate and fight with each other. Moreover, the environment is also changing: new areas are being discovered by animals, food is (dis)appearing and finally the ice is coming...
At the same time, it is a very meaty game for real gamers. It's mainly tactical, as the players should adapt and change their plans according to the situation on the board that is constantly changing. Still, some general strategy is also appreciated, especially taking into account the animal special abilities, the order of crucial special cards, tundra occupancy and possibility of acquiring final points. The game cons are: (a) it is AP prone, (b) it's really long (4-5 hours) (c) with 6 players you'll probably have too little influence on the game (similarly like in Imperial 2030) and (d) there is a significant random factor as the elements (food) are appearing randomly. However, the weaknesses fade comparing with the game taste. An outstanding design. 
Chad, kiitos! 

Number of plays: 30.
Last plays: LLWLWWLLWWWL (all 3p, except the 27th game)

RATING: 4.5
If migration wasn't part of the game, this would probably be 0.5 higher. It makes sense and is probably necessary, but just adds an hour to the game which IMO just isn't needed.

Update: The time this game takes vs. the pleasure I derive from it has destroyed my rating for this game. TBF, it's probably not a bad game, just completely not my type of thing.

For a 4 hour game, there is far too much chaos and unpredictability, making it basically impossible to plan more than a few minutes ahead. It is also far too easy to have one player (or more) all but wiped out with no chance of winning and still having three hours to go.

In summary, it is a clever game (though heavily influenced by Age of Empires), but just completely not my kind of thing.

RATING: 7
Reminds me heavily of Age of Empires III, with the 'action placement' mechanic.  Since I already own AoE3, I can't picture picking this one up.

That aside, it's an enjoyable game. I think it's a little more fun that AoE3, but at the same time, it feels more obtuse.  It's not terribly clear what the best strategy is.  I played the Insects in the one game of this that I've played, and ended up in 2nd place. (Or as Hunter J. refers to it: 1st loser.  Heh.)

The production quality is fairly high, at least by GMT standards.  I was surprised by the mounted board, but visually the game still looks a little bland.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
You see the cover and think Evo, but for gamers. You see the board and think El Grande. But Dominant Species is neither Evo than El Grande.

In this game you have 2 levels of area control and worker placement. One level is the same like in all area control games - you have the most cubes on a tile, so you will score the most points. But the`re also the dominantion. Every animal needs some food. There`re several food tokens adjecent to a tile of a board. You multiple the number of this tiles with the number of the food tile of your animal. The animal who has the most point dominate on this tile. You need only one cube, to have domination. 

When a tile is scored (when a player goes to an action field domination), the player with the most cubes scores the most points, than the second etc. The player who has domination scores no aditional points, but takes a card. The cards are very strong (but not too strong), and can change much. Soyou have to decide, is it good for you, to score a field, where you become much points, but another player a card.

In every game every card comes into play. You see the cards, that can influence the game in this round, so you have time to minimalize their bad effect, when another player will take them, or decide, to catch the card. 

To place a tundra tile is another powerfull action. The tile loses his funcion and is now a tundra. In tundra you have not much food, and can earn not many points, but someone who have the most cubes in a tundra will score (the more points, there more cubes on diferent tundra tiles).

Each animal has a diferent ability. When there is a tie, the food change shows who will be better. The better your ability, the lower you are in the food change. But i don`t like the food change.

The`re different ways to score - put a tundra tile on the board, put a new tile on the board, score a tile where you you have majority (on the most tiles not only one player will score), the most cubes on all tundra tiles.

The game is very long, but you have many choices. The domination really changes the standard area control. It`s not two area control in one game, it`s two levels of area control in one game. Great game, want to play more!

EDIT: Great game, my rating would be 10, but the games is too long. 1st 3 players game (easy mode - 1 animal/player) - 4,5h, 2nd game (easy mode, for 2 of 3 players played for the 2nd time) - 6h.

Sleeved.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.9
I want to LOVE this game. It looks great and the theme is right up my alley. Everything is as it should be - except:

COMPLEXITY thy name is death - or should that be the other way round... :)

We have played it twice with 2 players. It is chaotic to say the least. You try to plan ahead. You try to see what possible advantages you could gain. You try to mitigate those as best you can.

Yet, often it feels like I am being played. You can predict to a certain degree what the other will do, but there are so many different variables that you cannot see them all and I just feel lost.

I want to feel in control. I want to feel like the master plan I have is working because of what I do - not because someone missed a step - or because it all fell down around you, because you could not oversee everything.

Is the game at fault because I cannot comprehend it? Or because I have expectations it cannot live up to? Perhaps not, but that said, if the game removed a few levels of complexity - like the dominance cards - perhaps it would all be easier.

Well, I am not going to tinker with it... on the trade pile it goes. :)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Played once at 5P and once at 4P. Too many options to evaluate at a reasonable pace without practice; even players of several games can take quite a long time to place or execute an action. Thematically: not much evolving; unthematic direct, specific interaction; and too much terraforming. Initiative is far too strong. The initiative leader only really needs to worry about his closest competition, while the player at the bottom needs to worry about everyone; this makes things simpler for the person in the easy position, and harder for the person in the hard position.

A bit fiddly, and while the cones are a pleasing shape abstractly, they are difficult to handle and have no redeeming value (for instance, helices would be thematic). They get easier to handle as they get older (and dirtier?)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8.5
Slightly long, but super engaging. Really an interesting playing experience. The sides are asymmetrical enough to make a unique experience for the player while not being so radically different that the player has to understand that animal's strategies. The bonus points and cards make this a game of position and timing.

I think I prefer the game without the 4 cards that affect the action pawns. It speeds up the game and keeps that imbalance out.

RATING: 10

RATING: 9
An excellent disguised war game. It keeps your eyes in tears throughout the entire game as your species are killed one by one. The only tears of joy are when you kill other species. You don't even realize when 3-4 hours have passed. 
It's not a game for everyone, but a darn good one

RATING: 9
Wow, I have been wanting to play this for yonks, bu slightly put off by it's length. However when I did play it, those 5 hours (4 newbies) went very quickly, as althugh it's a big game, it is not prone to AP except for the most ardent of sufferers!
Some very nice mechanisms that have that good feeling of "aargh I wish I had just one more action", coupled no unaway leader syndrome as the game can flip in a couple of turns with th eright play, and because there is varied scoring that can really ramp up in the 2nd half of the game. Overall a delight, and one to purchase as I can see this coimng out 2 or 3 times a year.
Thanks Si :)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
On the plus side, players have a ton of options for each action, which is nice. On the negative side of the ledger, the game is pure tactics, with the board and situations changing so frequently that long-term strategy is difficult if not impossible. The real downside here is game length. Three hours is probably optimistic in terms of game length, and while this is a solid worker-placement and area-control game there's just nothing that's innovative or interesting enough to justify that kind of time investment. The theme is paper-thin, which left me feeling like I was playing an abstract game for endless hours rather than building a world and guiding a species in its quest for survival. I was a bit bored and ready for the game to end about an hour before it did (despite playing a strong final two turns and locking up the win). Dominant Species is not awful, but I'm puzzled by all the praise and high ratings ...

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
Take El Grande, add a bunch of new game mechanics, and put 4-5 times as many regions on the board. That's Dominant Species. 

The game sucks because it has lots of down time. The game board changes frequently, so it's difficult to form a long-term strategy. As a result, players will AP (analysis paralysis) as they adapt their plans to changes on the board. Because the game is so overloaded with game mechanics, there are long waits between turns. 

Because you have to adapt your strategy at every turn, the game is more about reacting than planning. So not only are there long waits, but there is little to think about during the down time. There aren't any battles, or anything that would make the wait more interesting. 

This is what happens when game designers overload a game with game mechanics. Don't buy this game. It is tedious. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.6
I've played a 4 player game and half a 2 player game with my wife.  The 4 player game was fun, but we picked up all the extra Action Pawn cards on the first turn which made the game last very long. This game is not for the feint of heart.  You WILL be combative with your fellow players, and you need to take i with a grain of salt.  My wife liked it okay, but I don't know that she would ever play it again.  When I play it again I will play it with fewer cards, to speed the game length up.

Played with fewer cards, which did speed it up considerably.  We removed all the extra Action Pawn cards (3) and two other cards, resulting in a game that is at least 1, and possibly two turns shorter.  Also fewer Action Pawns leads to shorter turns on top of that.  Might make it to the table more due to this.

Nonstop competition plus long-term strategy. It's amazing how everything was wrapped into a single box.

RATING: 8

It is a bit too long to get to the table often, but it is a good one for to scratch that deep game itch.  Personally if I am going to spend 3-4+ hrs playing a game I would rather it be a wargame.  That said, when my regular gaming group wants a heavy one, we will probably swing for this from now on.
