RATING: 10
An excellent game.  Very tense all the way through.  The time flies by when you play.  I'm very much looking forward to getting it to the table again.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This is a great game that I'd like to get some more experience with.  It might be the mind-meltingest game I've ever played.  The consequences of decisions can be profound and unpredictable, especially with a high player count.  And the game can be extremely unforgiving to mistakes.

Both the worker placement and area control aspects are expertly designed.

My biggest complaint is related to constantly re-assessing dominance, which can be difficult to do without frequent "I have 2 + 2 + 1 to your 2 + 1 + 1 and he has 2 + ..." conversations.  So that's a bit awkward and can be an easy source for honest mistakes.

The asymmetrical sides seem well balanced.  The differentiation between animals, though fitting, could have perhaps been pushed a little bit further to better accentuate the theme.  Playing as insects isn't really that appreciably different than playing as mammals, for example.  Then again, greater differentiation could mess up the balance, so maybe I shouldn't look at this gift horse in the mouth too closely.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Preliminary rating. High player interaction, prone to AP, which effectively isn't that bad since lots of mechanics are intertwined and actions taken(especially those of your opponents) do affect your play vastly more than they do in tons of other games. 

I think this game ranks high on a tactical scale. Sure, regression, wasteland and depletion are things than can be be planned ahead but overall I think to pursue a long-term-strategy won't get you far or as far as short-term tactical decisions adapting to specific game situations will get you.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Highly confrontational direct competition with a variety of actions for creating and maintaining numerical superiority on the board. Multiple ways to score points mean there are important decisions to make every time you take a turn.

The iOS app is a great, portable way to play the game. It keeps track of dominance and other background numbers easily, so you can focus on tactical and strategic considerations. The AI is pretty bad as of July 2015.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Very strategic and player competitive boardgame themed around an amazing icy cold prehistoric theme.

The game mechanic encourages rivalry and competition but is relentless on 'friendlier' players.

A very good game if you can look passed the high amount of book keeping involved.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Agricola introduces additional tension to the worker placement genre by letting you slowly starve to death unless you take measures to prevent this. Dominant Species introduces additional tension to the worker placement genre by allowing you to tear each others throats out. 

Trying to build a planet, adapt your class of animals to that planet and put them in a position to score points is a lot to juggle when fighting over actions. Add in direct combats, the swing of the cards, losing ground both in the form of regression and wasteland and you've got quite a puzzle. Oh yeah, and there's the entire glaciation sub-game which doubles as both a devastating, if slow moving, weapon of mass destruction and a clever way to introduce a second major source of points. 

This game is intense, due to the length, the depth and the level of aggression. That is why you will love it. It's why I do.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Gonna give this a few more plays, but it's gunning for a 10 rating.  Really fantastic work.  After one play I couldn't stop thinking about it for the next few days.  I had to own it, and now I do.  Good work, me!
Edit: This gets a ten from me.  I just adore everything about this game and wish I could play it more.  It is not a game that is gentle to one's brain, as you're 100% on for the entire multi-hour length.  But oh, what a ride.  And also, best rulebook ever, possibly.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Now, don't get me wrong, the mechanics to this game are pretty sound and straight forward (as much as a 5 hour game can be), but I think it's more an exercise in diplomacy over strategy.  Especially during the end-game, I really felt like there was nothing to do but give the seemingly 1st place player the middle finger since I was so trampled and weak.

Andy explained it pretty well when we started by saying that the board changes so much per round that it's hard to have a strategy that lasts for more than two turns at most.  Plus, there are spite cards to acquire and players can gang up pretty easily on another player.  

But, the worst thing about this game is that I feel it's relegated to "heavy gamers" alone.  I had fun, but the arguing in-game left a sour taste in my mouth.  I really can't imagine how a game can be completed without at least one shouting match going down.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This game is brilliant, but completely brutal. I don't think I could play it more than once a month or so. Finishing a game of this, all I am capable of is sitting on the couch and staring off into space for a little while.

I'm not sure whether or not I really enjoy the "each player takes two animals" variant for three players. I'd like to try this game with four.

EDIT: Yup, better with four. Now I'm mostly concerned about the swinginess of the endgame.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
I LOVE this game. It's everything that makes a game great for me. I can't wait to own the second printing with the thicker tiles.

I now own the second printing with the thicker tiles. In all honesty, there is very minimal difference between the two versions. So if you can get the first printing for cheaper, go for it.

Even though I only have a few games under my belt, this game is getting better and better with each play. I'm starting to wrap my head around the complexity of the whole system and I'm loving the way a small change from a seemingly insignificant action can result in large-scale, game-changing affects. 

The game is looooong. But I've had no problem removing certain cards that lengthen the game (i.e., all cards that add APs) and it still comes out nicely. If the game played a bit more quickly, and if it wasn't such a beast to teach, it would be a 10. For now it will sit at a 9.

It's just so dang hard to get to the table that for lack of its replayability, I'm lowering its rating to an 8.
[COLOR=#FFFFFF]TAGS: euro, worker placement, area majority, long, complex, heavy-weight, conflict, skill advancement, exploration[/COLOR]

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.3
I've given this game maybe 4 or 5 plays, and while it's a fine game I'm not a huge fan. For starters, it plays a bit too long, even with 5 games experience under our belts our group struggled to finish a game in less than 2.5 hours, with the first plays dragging out to 4 hours or so. There are just too many opportunities to AP in this game, and so few of your decisions can be made until the previous decisions resolve. Turns really start to drag.
Second, for a euro game with very minimum theme (all cubes and cones here) this game is especially pvp oriented. Not only that though, but the pvp feels exceptionally mean spirited. Single actions can essentially take players out of the game (which generally leads to king making later in the game). I think the problem with the pvp in this game (and I'm not talking about the competition action) is that it takes so long to set things up that when someone goes after your elements, or glaciers your dense population center off the board it just feels horribly demoralizing. More than one play of this game ended with people having ruffled feathers by the end. 

The game is not so bad I wouldn't play it, but there are many other games I'd rather play for the same time commitment, like Eclipse, or Dungeon Lords.

RATING: 10
Brendan's
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I have read the comparisons to El Grande and I see that, but I compare this to San Marco, a game that I love.

I make the comparison because it has helped me to better figure out why I don't love DS. (Note:  I have played DS 3 times and SM over 20 times.)

Both games are area control and both have huge decision trees and both games have thin margins so that the scoring is very swingy.  

My main problem with DS is that the decision tree is so much larger than San Marco that it feels overwhelming.  

My second problem is that the play time for DS is 3 hours while SM clocks in at about an hour.  

Finally, the cut-the-pie mechanic in SM is more unique - and I find it be more fun - than the action drafting mechanic in DS.

So what I get with DS is a 3-hour, tactical brain-burner that feels like winning has as much to do with accidentally being in the right place at the right time.

What I get with SM is a 1-hour, tactical brain-burner that feels somewhat like winning has as much to do with accidentally being in the right place at the right time and has a very fun mechanic that I have seen in only one other game (Piece O' Cake).

I actually love DS's theme and the theme shines in the gameplay.  This is the chief reason that I am willing to give this another couple of plays.  I am actually going to try and play this one without the cards (just track whenever the "Domination" action is taken by flipping a card as a method for counting down game end and still doing the dominance bonuses of Ice Age).

I feel this may cut a half-an-hour off of the time and keep the swingy-ness of scoring from adding chaos to the game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This game didn't impress me as much as I thought it would. I found the theme (if you can call it that) almost entirely non existent. In fact, I struggle to map the actions with anything thematic at all. That cubes are supposed to represent individual species is just plain terrible design. They really should have pasted a different theme on it.

Mechanically the game is actually well designed. It is sufficiently complex to challenge deep strategy players with very little randomness. It can seem chaotic because of the effects of choices made by other players, but when the game is well understood most of this can be controlled to some extent and it is definately possible to establish strategic lines to carry through most of the game.

I wouldn't turn down a game of this, but I'd prefer to play a few others if given the choice.

RATING: 9
My pick for top worker-placement game.

It's area control driven by the hot mechanic of the day. Vastly more enjoyable to me than another economic engine game.

It helps this is a fairly unique topic that's interesting, it is mechanically rock solid, has virtually limitless variation due to the draw of the elements/tiles/cards but remains at all times a perfect information game. The game will never screw you, and it will never hold your hand. You're rewarded for strong play and punished for foolish or weak plays.

Damned excellent and I want to play this more!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
First Impression:

ULTRA heavy eurogame. The are many options and though they're manageable after you get used to them (unlike late game in Le Havre), they are all available from the start and that makes the game quite intimidating. The game is prone to analysis paralysis but I think it was designed this way - downtime is not an issue as you have A LOT to think about while your opponents play, and their moves force you to constantly adapt. 

The theme is very well intergrated (even though uninteresting imo) and the subtle species differences work well. Cards range from broken to average and their appearence order significantly diversifies games. Luck is not a factor, this is a classic euro. Interaction is on the extreme level, you never feel alone on the planet.

It's an open information game, but the information available is just too much for me. It's also too easy to lose track of something (f.e. dominance) and make a scoring mistake. Both of these "problems" are actually design decisions: This game is a dedicated heavy gamers game, and will appeal to those who like to exhaust themselves in one multihour (~3-4h) eurogame. For this category of gamers, this game is paradise and they will never lose track of anything or find any amount of information intimidating. The game also has strong "take that" and "kingmaking" elements that I never like in multiplayer games, but good players can plan to avoid them so it's not a gamebreaking element for most, just really bad for me. Finally, Dominant Species has both in game scoring and late game scoring which are roughly equally important, with the late game scoring however being almost impossible to calculate in game in normal play times. This creates the problem that whenever you have to bash someone (every round many times) you can't really know who is really leading, and even worse the game gives a false impression with the in game scoring which can easily guide your hand very wrongly.

I prefer eurogames that last up to two hours. I can enjoy a really good game if it lasts an hour more (say, 5p agricola or terra mystica), but really these are my eurolimits. If I'm to play ONE game for 3-4h hours, then it will be a wargame, preferably a global domination/diplomacy one. So Dominant Species is just too much for me.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This is unlikely to ever ascend to a spot among my very favorite games, but I do both appreciate the design and enjoy the gameplay. And I say this as someone who came to the game with a fair amount of trepidation -- not because of the length or complexity (I play enough 18xx and wargames that are at least a match for this), but because I often have problems with games that are tactical bash-the-leader affairs (El Grande being the poster child for games of this style that I strongly dislike). This, combined with mixed-to-negative opinions from others in my game group (which were though counterbalanced by rave reviews by others on BGG with similar tastes to mine), meant that it took a long time for me to even get this ame played. And I liked it. Didn't fall instantly in love as others have, but genuinely liked it. I'm not sure I can fully explain why the tactical nature and bash the leader mentality of this game didn't bother me as much as I thought they might (or as the same characteristics of other games do), but I will put forth a few thoughts. First, DS has an epic feel and strong story arc. This can't fully explain my positive reaction as I usually dislike and therefore avoid purely "experience"/narrative games, but it does help that the theme of DS comes through so strongly. Second, there are enough dimensions on which there is a leader (current score, dominance markers, board position for final majorities) that it is not always apparent who to bash -- or different players will have different incentives on who to bash depending on where and how they are competing. Third, there is just so much chaos anyway that leadership in general or on any tile in particular is very transitory.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Best game of 2010. The diversity of options and depth of game play cannot be found easily in other games. Some people may talk about chaos, but this is exactly the opposite of what this game offers. Another important feature that makes this game really interesting, is that players adapt to new strategies each time they play the game again. Not only you have to manage how your species adapt, but the player as well adapts his overall strategy and understanding of the game each time he will play this game again. Do not play with players of "analysis-paralysis". You will spend 4 intensive hours with 5 players! It is time well spend!

RATING: 8
I like the theme of the game. The actions are very thematic and add to the flavor of the game. This is a heavy Euro game that seemed to play well with fewer players. There are many issues to think about before making decision on the moves. This is suitable for one who enjoy more strategic gameplay instead of a more luck based game play.

The cards can have huge impact on the game and it is important that players always take note of the cards available. Some can have very devastating effect that can cripple a player badly if one is not careful.

RATING: 5
Is this game brilliant? Maybe. I don't know, and I frankly don't give a shit. Clearly you have to fight for turn order, but you can't keep first player for two turns in a row if others players are competent. the cards come out randomly, so you never know when a game changing card will come out. You spend 4 hours playing a game, and, at some point in the game a card will come out that blows up the whole map. Assuming you're competent, maybe you're in a position to take advantage of it or just survive it. Maybe you're not. If you're not competent, maybe you're in a position to take advantage of it or survive it. Maybe you're not. Sure the factions feel very different and require very different strategy. But it feels like the beautiful strategy was layered on top of mind-fucking chaos, instead of a bit of chaos being layered on top of beautiful strategy. I give it a 5, because I see why others might like it, but I didn't enjoy it. I don't need to invest my time into this madness.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Update June 2014. Bumped back to an 8. Such a crazy & unique game, and beautiful too. Somehow the thee & its crazy permutations save it from dull WP constraints. 

Update Jan 2013
My tastes have shifted toward less overhead related to programming churn & a growing worker placement distaste. I need another play from my new point of view to find out if the thinking is so much about the other players as it's about tracking what the game kicks at you. My reduction to a '7' is provisional, I'll re-evaluate with the next time it comes around for play.

Even if it remains a '7,' it is an expression of my personal gaming desires. The theme & design ambition remain very worthy, and if it's context appeals to you, it's an exceptional game.

- - - - -

Play ripples across the board, the butterfly effect. So you get screwed by butterflies repeatedly in this game. That can't be bad, right? They're pretty little things.
...

Strong recommendation to play without the cards associated with extra workers, a variant approved by the designer.

[b]On perceived chaos in some threads:[/b] My thought here is that the unpredictableness in this game is due to the way the game systems do not protect you from other players. And given that there are many choices in this game, it's challenge is managing three or more other player's many unexpected stunts & machinations.

The overturn of cards and elements is predictable... these things become static once they occur, and can be taken into account with your worker placement programming. But since you place all your action pawns first in turn order and then execute them all, you can't churn through all those iterations layered with some 20 human choices. It's those [i]people[/i] getting into your face.
...

Multi-layered area control, totally absorbing as the earth grows, elements differentiate the various environments (tiles), and your animal speciates, competes, ebbs, adapts, thrives again. Glaciation provides pressures to population, but is also something to be controlled and scored in multiple ways. The game state changes constantly, and it is a pleasure to plan each turn with your worker placement & then have so many tactical opportunities when you do execute your action. Especially with up to 5 others messing with your species & your environs.

Theme & mechanics are indivisible; in their efforts, both cooperative & aggressive, a "great chain of being" is in constant motion rather than a static built thing. The asymetrical "powers" for each animal and card effects aren't so much balanced as feeding a dynamic you must survive.

The rules & gameplay are exceptionally clear & the game runs smoothly. So the how to do things doesn't dominate, but there is a permutation cliff one can fall off.

The bits & board are very pleasing too. This game looks good on the table, but has just the right understatement to support ease of reading the board & doing things like scanning/calculating for dominance. 

Brain fart warning. Maintaining a strategy in such a dense, changing & opportunistic environ rewards tactical oppertunism with a bit of loose, sneaky strategy. The first couple of plays this will feel like permutation churn, or foggy, but it settles out with familiarity.

Brilliant game narrative.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
I ignored all the warnings from people who said this game was heavy and boy did I pay for it. The experience was utterly amazing but left me with a headache afterwards. 

It probably doesn't help when you've been doing a ton of math to then follow it up with a game of this caliber but not to worry, I'll do better next time. 

This is a great game though, don't let my comments dissuade you, you need to play this! And I can't wait to get this back to the table.

Updated comment: Looking back, this game isn't that particularly heavy. The first play is definitely overwhelming, but each subsequent play becomes far simpler and easier. People have called this a war game disguised in Euro clothing and that's definitely the case. Playing face-to-face is the best way to play even though I quite enjoy the IOS app. 

This game ended up firing Caylus for me. The play is just a lot more tense.

RATING: 9
Damn. This game is phenomenal. After one two-player game my mind is blown. Four tension-packed, engaging, brain burning hours passed in what seemed like 90 minutes. I love games that let you plan out your moves in advance, but require flexibility as well. I am a huge fan of area control, as long as players can plan to defend against attacks and to conquer regions, as opposed to having to rely on luck. I love games with a combination of strategy, tactics, and tense decisions, and Dominant Species delivers. Outstanding game.

[q="Tsaar"]Great game, great session. The scores were pretty close during the whole game, except for the two last rounds when James first got away with three Wanderlusts and a fistfull of bonuspoints, and Audrey who went on a killing spree in the last round which made up for some points she was lagging behind. The cards work in a way that reminds me of [thing=12333][/thing]. You know things are bound to happen and you know that they cannot be stopped, so you have to keep controlling the imminent damage but you can only win the game by taking some risks and expanding your species over the board.

A typical 'if I had done that' and 'I should have noticed' discussion was held afterwards, and if it weren't for the long time to play I would have liked to start a new game immediately.[/q]
http://www.boardgamegeek.com/listitem/1454248?commentid=1767966#comment1767966

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A largely abstract Euro game with the theme of surviving an Ice Age with a broad "class" of animals, such as birds, insects, or mammals. Gameplay is a mixture of worker placement to choose your action and area control to help your species become dominant. As you desperately search for new terrain to expand to, snowy tundra spreads over once verdant land.

RATING: 9.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
2 plays.  Really enjoy this game  There's a lot to take in, and each action taken will have an effect on how most things after it happen, so you really have to pay attention to what everyone else is doing just as much as what you are doing.  The special species abilities make each player start out with a different approach going in and would seem to have a decent balance at first look.  The learning curve and time it takes to play could restrict its appeal depending on the group, and it could be prone to AP, but our group doesn't have that problem.  

My second play I didn't pay enough attention to what others could do to harm me and after being in fairly good position one turn, I was nearly removed from the board the next turn (late in the game).  It's still a fairly long game, but I think it's worth it.

A true gem of a game! The variable powers of the different species are subtle, and there are immense amounts of strategy involved. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
I'm definitely not sold after one play. However I can see how the game rewards multiple plays (simply going in from the start understanding how all the various mechanisms will interact would be a very large boon).

On the other hand, I don't like the fact that you're often at the mercy of collateral damage from other people's decisions. This is randomness just as much as rolling dice is (perhaps a skilled enough player could anticipate everyone's optimal plays...). Some of the cards are quite powerful (although having majority control and scoring points is really where the game is won, so I'm not sure this is a big deal).

It's also very long, which makes it difficult to get to the table.

Anyway, I really need to play it again in order to rate it (and that's unlikely to happen since I won't be buying it).

Edit: improved impression of the game after second play. The length is still a serious problem (would almost always play the shortened variant with 4 cards removed -- and perhaps with a timer device of some kind).

Edit: even more improved impression after two more games. The length is perfect with the short variant (4 dominance cards removed).

RATING: 6

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
 Dominant Species does everything that I like in games- a strong spatial element, an incredibly tense worker placement phase, heavy player interaction, shared development on a map that is constantly changing based on player decisions, asymmetrical powers, etc.

The two different area majority battles that occur simultaneously on the board is perhaps the standout mechanic here- it is a brilliant idea and works beautifully to create angst and brain burn. Dominant Species perfects many of the old paradigms of gamers games and adds some truly innovative ideas of its own to make it a unique and incredibly compelling experience. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Man, is there a lot going on in this game each turn.  It's almost impossible to do everything you want to do on any given turn, and understanding how one action will affect a future one is critical in really getting the best out of the design.  Am I the right person for this sort of game?  It's hard to say.  I mean, I could look at all aspects of the game and figure out what I need to do at any given time, but it will take me a long time, at other players' expense.

The game has an area control aspect to it, and those types of games elude me to a large degree.  I feel at a disadvantage when playing these games, and while there are other things going on in DS, the bulk of the game lies in holding majority in areas.  The separation of majority and dominance is an interesting point of the game, but that just creates yet another thing to keep up with during the game!  I like the game, and I really respect the design.  But I have to wonder if it crosses the fun/work threshold with me.

Despite saying that, though, I'm interested in playing again.

1 play: 3 players (one animal each)
1 play: 4 players

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I just love this game to bits. The depth is incredible and even the kingmaking aspect hasn't managed to put me off. With 11 games behind us, my group can nail this game in 3 hours flat, which is perfect timing, in my opinion.

Edit: After 23 plays, we have now pushed play time below 2 hours!

Edit 2: To avoid kingmaking, do not invite married (or otherwise) couples. One half of a couple is ok, both are not!

Edit 3: I realised that most of the people who dislike this game have played with a large number of players: 5 or 6. A few nights ago I played a 6-player game and it was awful! Total randomness. 2-player vanilla games are pure skill. 3-player is great and 4-player is acceptable. Warning! Avoid 5 or 6-player games because skill has very little to do with them!

Thank you Chad Jensen for this sparkling gem!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I am painstakingly amazed at what brilliance this game employs. Each and every turn is decisions built upon decisions that can enhance or deaden your previous decisions
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
A heavy game. The third edition is aesthetically better looking than the previous editions. Not sure if everybody would be into the theme and its abstract appearence may be off-putting to some. Have not played enough times as is very difficult to draft people into this game.

It sometimes boils down to negotiating your way with the other players. It's a game that is hard to plan anything concrete as the board conditions are ever-shifting, leading to a need to be highly tactical.  

Most of the people with short attention spans would end up annoying you by expecting you to do the house keeping for them. Be sure that you know how to score tiles during domination phase, as mistakenly misinterpreting the rules could result in a "broken" game. Factions are quite well balanced in my opinion. Not advised to play with people who frequently change their minds as is very difficult to roll back the turns. Only fun with 4 players and up, but be warned games can get very cut-throat.

Suggested to play without the cards that grant AP for a faster more intense game.

RATING: 3
Based on two half games, both of which ended because people got fucked over and didn't want to play anymore. There are lots of easy ways to make mistakes, and the penalties are so devastating that they can knock you out of the game permanently. (and the game is LONG)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Dominant Species is the best game I have played in years. Although many parts of it are very abstract in nature, the game does a tremendous job of creating an atmosphere of constant adaptation and struggle for survival. At times, just trying to move into a habitable set of tiles can get so competitive it feels like a knife fight in a phone booth. The Domination cards really intensify the effect, because being able to control them is often times more important than expanding your species or scoring. People will fight for them, intensely.

All of this drives the game to very competitive place. Feelings are going to get hurt, people are going to get angry. I have played with a number of different groups and I have seen it play out time and time again. You are actively driving other players to extinction and silly as it may be, you will take it personally when someone pops a volcanic eruption under your population center and instantly removes half of your species from the game. You don't get them back, so you WILL want revenge. It drives the game, so even if it makes the group uncomfortable at times, it is necessary in creating the game's undeniably intense experience. This is one of those titles that keeps you talking about a particular session for weeks after you actually played it. It's a hall of fame game, one that will stay in my collection even if I decide to someday get out of the hobby.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
All the parts fit together subtly to create a joyful experience. Notable for the fact that it's hard to be singled out and crushed by others.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
On this website, it suggests that the game will take up 2 hours to play; and they are not kidding.  If you love boardgames, playing with others, and have a passion for strategy, this is the game for you. 

Dominate Species may be comparable to Settlers of Catan or Risk, for players are bent on expansion and having certain resources available on territories.  

The thing that sets this game apart from the rest is that it does NOT have any dice rolling.  This allows players to be more serious when scheming, as the element of luck is minimized to cards (a selection that the players see, and so it is not a shot in the dark when thinking about them), and how other players are going to act/play.  So in this way, Dominate Species is like a chess or checkers type game, and both my friends and I found this to be rather refreshing.

The price tag on Dominate Species is a rather hefty one: I got it for 70$ from a store, and I am sure buying it online will not be any better with S&H.  So if you do not think that you can attend to a 2 hour+ game, you do not like strategy, or you are unlikely to have 2+ other people (though this game is really better with 4-6 players), then I would recommend either getting it used from someone, or not bothering to purchase it at all.  I personally thought it was a good buy, plan on playing it frequently, and thought it was worth the price.

In any case, I would recommend at least giving the game a try if given the chance.  This game is not for everyone, but in the realm of strategy games, Dominate Species has "dominated" my own like list!

RATING: 9.6
Harkens back to the AH days of Tyrano Ex.  A long but solid Euro game of area majority in a world being covered slowly by ice.  A good "decision management" game. I have to give this game my "gamer's game" of the year award.  There's enough going on and calculate to make your head hurt.  The final scoring can be huge and needs to factor into your strategy.  I've upped my rating to a 9 for this game.  I don't give it a 10 due to the length of time it takes to play, even with 4 players.  It's about one turn or 30 minutes too long for me and for what it is, but still an excellent game.  Maybe if the Ice Age card were shuffled into the last 10 cards or so might shorten the game as well as add variability to the end game planning.

RATING: 3.5
Life in Dominant Species is nasty, brutish, but far from short, it stretches on for what seems like 3.6 billion years. The poorly thought out drafting mechanism delivers stupidly unbalanced cards that will either obliterate someone or do something entirely meaningless. A lot of player interaction focuses on TAKE THAT / SCREW YOU mechanisms. Unfortunately this isn’t used to keep front runners in check because the environment you are competing in shifted and it no longer makes sense to do so at that particular moment.

Thematically this game fits very well, competition for survival along with drastic environmental changes mean you will likely go extinct due to some arbitrary misfortune. Too bad you can’t gracefully die off and play something else that packs more fun into it. (Play Evolution or Primordial Soup instead, you will still get eaten, suffer a catastrophe or starve to death but you'll have a lot more fun while doing so.)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This is the foursome love child of Die Macher/El Grande/Agricola/Primordial Soup.  You have the tight multiple interactions of Die Macher with the scoring and card selection of El Grande with the worker placement of Agricola with the evolution of Primordial Soup.  

The result is an absolute gem.  There are strategic aspects in the speciation/wanderlust/glaciation/adaption roles, combined with the tactical considerations of speciation/dominance/migration actions.  Add in assymmetric powers, which are always fun if properly, and you have a great game.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
What a delightfully vicious game! This is one of the most amazing euros I've ever played (albeit it can be mentally exhausting). A few hours of ultra brain-burning decisions and constant rivalry between you and your opponents. Fantastic combination of worker placement, area control/majority and special card powers. It's thematic, deep, rewarding and extremely interactive. And despite its complexity it's one of the most elegant heavy games I've ever seen.  Too bad it takes so long to play (that's the only major drawback) - it will hit the table once every few months at best (unless you play using an offical short variant - it works really well)...  Still, I'm blown away. Outstanding game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.5
For the first two hours, I would have rated it a 9, for the next hour a 7, and by the end, the 5.5 I gave it.

It is a really well designed game, in that all of its mechanics work together very well.  But, two weaknesses for me that drop the rating significantly.  First, it's just too long.  Taking out 5-10 cards and shortening the game by a round or two would be a phenomenal addition (subtraction?) to the game.  Second, there is a bash the leader problem here at the same level as the original Vinci.  Since scoring is open (albeit not quite as transparent as Vinci), you can see who is winning and who you need to bash in order to win.  And, of course, it is the right strategy in this game to bash them.  But, having one player get bashed for the last 90 minutes of the game so that he doesn't win and someone else does isn't really all that much fun.  

There is one more weakness that didn't change the rating for me, but probably should - the graphic design/bits.  Come on GMT - can't you enter the 21st century in game design?  Make the game look really nice; print on higher quality card stock, make the bits bigger; etc.

Like Vinci turned into Smallworld, maybe Days of Wonder can redo this game with really nice art design, cool bits and hidden scoring.

RATING: 7.8
All in all, a very good game with the only problem that it is too long. Our first play lasted 4 hours. We really enjoyed it but if it had been just 3 hours it would have been a great game, a 9 !
It's a worker placement, nothing terribly new but everything is mixed up in a very deep, vast experience , with many things to take into account, many ways to win, many tricks to play, many really tough and interesting choices The animals are really well balanced, actions are strong but not too much, the game flows easily: it just flows for too much time and the last turns drag slowly toward the end. We actually had the third player who won at the last turn so there was also a lot of emotions till the end.
If i had time and energy i would play another time soon.

Material is adequate. nothing incredible. Unfortunately in the migration phase, when you can move little cubes around, it's hard to keep track of all the movements.
During the first play it is not easy to remember the difference between two similar actions (depletion and waste land, maybe, not sure).

[EDIT]: after second play, years after, i found it still very long, still good, but I have a lot of doubts about cards and Domination action. Maybe it's just lack of experience but Domination seems a forced move and i dont like forced moves in games with several paths to victory.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Deep thinking strategy game for area control that is heavily confrontational. Many actions to choose by worker placement that can cause a chain of cause and effect. Up to six species fight extinction from glacial expansion using abundance, regression, speciation, adaptation, migration, wanderlust, dominance, and depletion. Seeds, grubs, sun, and other needs come and go on the terrain tile intersections. So many options to consider...brain hurt. Card drafts from dominance phase can create huge swings. I am blown away by the depth and the interaction of the game elements. The sequential and cascading progression of the action board is amazing.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Thematically sound and mechanically resolute, [i]Dominant Species[/i] is a schizophrenic arrangement of scoring opportunities that is capsized (and sunk) by overpowered card effects.

It's also long.  Like, really and truly long.  Not engaging. Not captivating. Just long. As in, "I'd like to use an Action Point to rewind time and choose another game" long.  Or, "I'm not having fun, but I guess I'll keep playing" long.

To shorten the game, my group uses a variant where 5 cards are randomly removed from the deck, but even with this "fix" DS still overstays its welcome by at least an hour.

I'd rather play any other (shorter) area control game than [i]Species[/i]: El Grande, Cave Troll, Kreta, whatever.  Area control games aren't my thing anyway, so I suppose the point is officially moot.

I don't like [i]Evo[/i], either, but I'd rather curl up inside [i]Evo[/i]'s box and play the game from inside than sit through [i]Dominant Species[/i] again.  If DS played in 75-90 minutes, I might give it another go.  But since it can't, I won't.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Very interesting game. You are playing a group of species and trying to keep enough of them alive to influence the land around you. It is a worker placement game and a area majority game. The special cards are extremely important but so are the other places to play each turn. Excellent game.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
The game is surprisingly easy to play from a mechanics standpoint, but is brain-melting in trying to decide what to do.  I like the interlocking cube majority versus best adapted ways of benefiting from a space.

Even though the game has a lot of possible choices, the overall game makes sense.  Migration does what you think it should, adaptation does what you think it should, etc.  That makes it much easier to handle the wide array of choices that you have compared to other games with a bunch of choices that are just a pile of arbitrary ways of gathering victory points.

The only caveat is that you can't play this with the AP-prone.  It becomes torturous.  The game tempts you to do a lot of calculation, but the play is dynamic enough that it won't succumb to sheer calculation.  You need to play more by the seat of your pants.  In that setting, it's wonderful.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
The design and playtime suffers from the repeated calculations of tile dominance -- 6 players took 5 hours. I enjoy pretty much everything else about it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
This is a beast of a game that has so much going on yet really isn't overly complicated once you get the hang of the steps and how everything plays out. That being said... you'll inevitably forget something along the way and get totally destroyed... or that might just be me.

For a game that I'm generally pretty horrible at, and given the amount of time it take to play, that combination would seem like (at face value) to set up for failure, however, it's quite the opposite as it is a game that I really enjoy.

I really like the player interaction, strategy, and asymmetry of the species. What I have found to date is that that I generally don't play to my species strengths or play too much in to what I perceive to be its strength that I leave myself vulnerable in other areas.

As a war game that masquerades as worker placement, it is hard to beat on many levels. Its main drawbacks are the amount of time that it takes to play a full game and the number of people required for it to truly shine.

As it currently stands, it's really hard to give this game an accurate rating because of the infrequency that I have played it and the inability to fully explore its potential. However, from what I have seen so far, it's a game in my collection that I will never mind bringing to the table regardless if that means a 3+ hour beat-down.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Damn it has a lot of cubes lol.  I love this game, but it hasn't found a solid place in my rotation because it tends to run long.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.1
This is a cool area control game with a worker placement mechanism for determining actions. This game is hard, the board changes drastically from when you choose your actions to when you complete them and for someone who doesn't play very often, it can be quite frustrating. That being said I enjoy the cut-throat attitude in the game and the theme of out competing your rivals.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Very originally themed worker placement. The theme of representing a family of species adapting to a changing environment kind of falls apart under close scrutiny (mainly because, more often than not, you're adapting the environment to meet the needs of your species, rather than the other way around), but as this supports a more dynamic gameplay in which you can really screw other players over, I can't in all honesty say it bothers me that much.

This game has a very high level of interaction, which, to my experience, is unusual for a worker placement game. Rather than being limited to blocking actions for other players, you can actively seek to wipe them off the board. This creates a far more dynamic game, in which players who are behind can significantly impact those who are dominating the board.

Despite that, and perhaps because of the theme, which avoids words like "combat", people in my playgroup who are not in general fans of cutthroat games enjoy this as well. You can blow others out of the water, but you don't have to. Balance seems pretty good as well. The cards are very powerful, and as getting them is linked to scoring, players in can snowball quickly, but there's generally always a way back into the game.

There are lots and lots of actions you can take, and there seems to be a huge variation in the strategies that lead to victory. I loved this game. Ok, so I was biased - I had to wait 4 months for the copy I ordered to arrive, so I might've hyped it a little in my head. But it certainly lived up to expectations and I have to call it one of my absolute favorite games.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Perfect. Just perfect. A must have.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Lots of player interaction, lots of worker actions available, lots of strategy. The card you take at the end of every turn can be pretty strong or completely useless. The lack of balance in that deck is my only real complaint.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Having watched many a nature documentary and being a David Attenborough fan, the theme of evolution and supremacy really shone through in Dominant Species. 

Dominant Species is definitely a heavy Euro game, with knowledge of the 25 domination cards playing a critical role during play. Implication is some time has to be spent understanding and remembering the cards. Fortunately, there are "only" 25 of them.

The final round of the game is also particularly important, with as much as 50% of your VPs coming from the Ice Age and Survival cards, as well as the final scoring of every tile.

The game feels more suited for fewer players, and is more chaotic with more players. Downtime is also an issue with more players. The artwork (3rd edition) is fantastic and enhances the theme.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Intimidating at first but very intuitive and quick to teach. It certainly isn't for everyone though - one of my friends into lighter games hated this one and it really dragged the experience down for us all.

The play time and slightly dry procedural aspects of this held it back and I got rid of it since it didn't hit the table.

< November 2012, Sold August 2014
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Too long and AP, but very interesting even with these minuses.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Great theme, good designer, tons and tons of hype, and I'm glad I fell for it. This game is all that and a bag of chips. I love it! The worker placement mechanism is very cleverly implemented, and the way the timing of the actions work out will make you curse in frustration, or snicker with glee. The fact that the area control features 2 different metrics of resolution going on simultaneously in each area makes ones brain hurt, but it certainly is well designed and evocative of the theme. The elements work in a great way to tie the entire package together.

I upgraded to the 3rd edition board, cards and tiles, and must say that I like them a whole lot better than the 1st edition. It made it much simpler for me and my buddies to keep an overview of the game state.

Dominant Species is easily the most epic game in my collection, not only in theme, but implementation and game length. This is one heavy and very long game. The rules are fantastically well written and easy to understand, but in execution the worker placement mechanism becomes too difficult to manage, as you cannot hold all the permutations in your head. I've learned that one can keep 7 things actively in ones short term memory, but this drives past that at 65 mph and leaves it in the dust. You are faced with so many if-then statements that you are forced to play more by gut and instinct. Sure, you can have some sort of strategy from the start, but this is definitely a highly tactical game, sadly all those actions are already locked in and in many ways the game starts feeling like a programming game ala Space Alert.

This is my game of choice for gaming weekends, vacations or long conventions, but it will probably not come out at our regular gaming nights at all again.

Enjoy the ride, it's epic!


[b]Ideas for a shorter game:[/b]
1) Give everyone 1 extra AP. (Not sure if this won't have the opposite effect, as we already tend to take all the Domination Cards each round.)
2) Remove 5-6 of each Element from the bag, to even out the draws a bit.
3) Remove some cards, the consencus (even included in the rules) state to remove Immigrants, Intelligence, Omnivore, and Parasitism. Many add Blight to that list. I am of the opinion that removing the AP modifiers will handicap the animals at the bottom of the food chain. The Insects advantage is the initiative to grab Parasitism or Omnivore before anyone else can react.
4) Play with fewer Species cubes per player (say 5 less).

The drawbacks of a shortened game of Dominant Species seem to be that the last couple of turns are the most exciting, as players are running out of Species cubes, the Tundra is most valuable, and the Earth has grown so large that migrating across it is difficult at best. Missing out on this doesn't sound like much fun.

[b]Cardless Variant:[/b]
The "cardless variant" by the designer is interesting though. All cards except for Ice Age are put on the board face down, and when taken by the Dominant player, kept in front of them until the End Game. They score Bonus VP as normal for how many Domination Cards they have in front of them at the end of the game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I like this one a lot.

RATING: 6
Too much going on here to make it really fun.

lets see, I can speciate, and add 3 pieces here, 4 pieces there, and 3 pieces over there.

Then they can fight, and kill 1 of my units here.

But then the third player can glaciate, and kill off all but 1 on this tile.

etc,etc.

Too large a permutation tree to feel like you can make good choices, and everything hinges on this decision tree.

An interesting game, but since this decision tree is so large and out of your control it is not as fun as it should be.

RATING: 8
UPDATE: Definitely better the second play, even though I came in dead last, due to my underestimation of the importance of endgame scoring.  Game flowed much better upon second play.  DS still seems one turn too long but captivating (for me) from start to finish.  Glad I played again, and would be glad to make it a regular in our circle's gaming stable.

I'm not exactly sure how to rate Dominant Species.  On one hand, it's got a lot of things going for it that I like - a strong theme, area majority, multiple ways to score, etc.  On the other hand, it feels overly long and chaotic.  My first game I shot out to an early lead after a couple of turns, then spent the next 3/4 of the game seemingly so far behind that I didn't see any way I could catch up to the leader.  I was some 20+ points behind the leader (5-player game) at game end.

That said, now that I know how the game works I would like to play again to see if it's just my perception that there's not enough ways to gain ground if you're behind, or if it was just my sub-standard play. ;)

In any event, the fact that I wrote this much about it and I would like to play again soon is pretty promising; I'll change my rating accordingly after my next play.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Awesome game, but often goes to 4 hrs or more, especially with 5-6 players.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
There are a great many excellent elements to this game.  The different animal powers are wonderfully balanced and flavorful.  The encroaching ice age works great (Settlers of the Stone Age-style).  Species competition, food chain order, adaptation, resource scarcity, all very cool.  

What ruins this game for me are the counter-intuitive dominance calculations.  There are two kinds of dominance, confusingly unrelated to one another.  One of them has to be tediously recalculated over and over and over.  Every time one of us got a token, lost a token, or added or removed a token from the board.  This could happen like 8 or 10 times PER TURN.

Another relatively minor complaint is that the domination card powers seem to be very unbalanced.  Like they got tacked onto the game at the last minute without being playtested.

I could not wait for my first game to end.  We wound up quitting after four hours.

I gave Dominant Species a 5, which was a composite of 8(I admire most of the game design) and 2(which is how much I want to play this game again).

I think this would be better with 4 players than 6...though then you lose some of the "food-chain order" coolness because the food chain gets so much shorter.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Update 21/01/2018
I dropped its rating because it's hard to get it to the table
----------------------------------------------------------------
One of my all time favourites, 

I've owned it for so many years and yet i've only played it 10 times. It's long. Very long. Most games take us 3+ hours because there are always at least 1-2 players new to the game. Area control is my favourite mechanic and the combination of scoring and domination is excellent. So many decisions with every single action you take.

Domination cards can be devastating depending on the timing they are played. There are so many variables that it's impossible to make any sort of mental calculations, at least beyond the current round. That's the kind of game i adore. Brain burner but not in terms of accounting and maths.

Thematically it feels so right. For example two animals sharing the same elements are always at each other's throats because they are forced to share the same spaces and are fighting for majority and domination. 

It can be chaotic and players' decisions determine the balance in the game. If players are left alone they can thrive. On other hand if you are an early leader or you are the one who owns and explains the game you can be targeted.Which is usually what happens to me. it's a mean game but it rarely feels personal if players are making logical decisions. That's a sign of a great game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Awesome game... Plays quick if you plan out an alternate move for when someone steals your action
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
iOS & Board
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
A unique themed game with a lot of depth. The rules are very clearly written and the game is well balanced. There is a perfect integration of theme and gameplay. Generally there is a lot to think about during play, there are many moving parts. 
The endgame scoring is massive and that means the game stays exciting until the last round. 
The different species play different and have general strategies. 

Some minor quirks : 
A few unpredictable factors are in the game: which elements will come out of the bag each round and what cards will come out the following round. There's a lot of mitigation of it by good play, but once in a while a combination can come out that you can't really do anything about. 

The card that gives an Action pawn might be a little too strong, especially if it's out in the first round. 


edit : I now have the upgraded components and the game looks a lot more beautiful and more attractive to play.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Intensely tactical, mostly short term planning, but full of options. You can get wiped out and come back, but your prospects probably aren't good. Some of the cards score a *lot* of points; player order and grabbing the first dominate seems important for these when they pop up.

RATING: 4
Very long with no engaging or exciting decisions. Too much going on for my taste.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.8
游戏体裁别处新颖，作为战棋大厂的版图试水作品，其严谨度和平衡性得到一定的保障，唯一缺点是游戏设计出的卡牌效果大小不一，对游戏的结果影响较大。这感觉好比在围棋中加入骰子，孰好孰劣留给大众来评价了。
【关键词】

RATING: 9
I'll always suggest this game - although I'm often the only one. It is such a clever theme and so cleverly entangled with the mechanics. Not great for those with analysis paralysis but great fun in my book
